reviewText:
In the spirit of Xcom.  This turn based RPG is a bit rough around the edges and is entertaining at the same time.  In my short playtime so far it has crashed several times.  The UI/Controls are a bit wonky with the iso view being just slightly not flexible enough to get a good view.  The upgradeable base and morale and stocking the supply larder with basics + luxury items is brilliance.  Lots of fun there and the raids into town/pharmacy are fun and tense.  Despite some roughness this is a worthwhile purchase I think.  time will tell if it has the staying power but it does appear to have enough in it to keep a zombie fan busy for awhile.

The weapon variety seems good (melee, guns and even a tazer)  Ammo is reasonably sparse making you treasure every shot and the action point based movements are a tried and true method to force good use of tactics.  Skills for the individuals matter and make a difference on how you will approach any specific situation and the sound mechanic is pretty cool. Using the firearms or bashing through a door is likely to draw attention .... is it worth it?  These sorts of tactical decisions make playing fun and engaging.

Get it on sale if you can and it's even a better deal.
voteText: 43 of 67 people (64%) found this review helpful

reviewText:
I was really excited when this game came out of Early Access- I like me some turn-based combat, and I'm a big fan of zombie survival as a setting.

Sadly it didn't really all come together, although it's not a complete flop- I think 4/10 is a fair score.

The game is spoiled by a combination of weird design choices and horrible bugs.

Design: The armour system makes no sense. No sense at all. If you wear the heaviest armour, you are literally invulnerable to all damage. You can wade into crowds of zombies, or even humans armed with assault rifles, with 0% possibility of death. Goodbye suspense. Also, boy o boy is the combat pretty boring if you're waiting for a dozen zombies to drag themselves over to you, and god forbid you start off with the wrong team-member in a crowded area- get ready to skip turns until it's the turn of the guy in front.

Bugs: I let a few patches go in and decided to give the game another chance. I spent about an hour clearing out a block of houses and looting. The last zombie on the map got stuck in a closed doorway to the room I was in, leaving my team stuck in a bedroom for eternity. This kind of thing is not uncommon. Also, if you aren't able to design a multi-floored building without having players stuck in combat with enemies on different floors that they can't see, stick to bungalows. (I cleared the entirety of the hospital one zombie at a time without ever being able to leave combat)

So yeah. Nice try, but pretty much ♥♥♥♥ed it up in the execution.

reviewText: Dead State is a very unigue, one-of-its-kind, single-player RPG set in a zombie-apocalypse environment. It has many interesting NPCs with different stories, strengths and weaknesses, that will keep players entertained throughout the game. Its turn-based combat system is old school, but challenging and even nail-biting at times. The foraging and base managing systems set a new standard for zombie-themed games, with hundreds of different items that can be consumed or used in many ways.  Overall, this is a MUST-PLAY game for all who are interested in zombie-themed games.

reviewText:
-AFTER MARCH 13TH PATCH-
I've never written a review before, but this game deserves one. The game has everything I would expect in a post-apoctolyptic world: starvation, a battle with morale, interactions with survivors, and of course fighting and killing zombies and looters.
I believe the best aspect of this game is interacting and rescuing survivors. Each survivor has such an in-depth storyline which creates an emotional attachment with the gameplayer. You're forced to make such difficult, yet rewarding, decisions which impact the entire game's plotline.
One controversial aspect of this game is the turn-based fighting. Now I may be in the minority with this opinion, but I think the turn-based fighting adds originality to the game. It makes the game memorable and stand out from all the other zombies game.
Another part of the game which is a challenge is the balance of morale. Your survivors are scared, depressed, and alone in this zombified world, and they look to you, their leader, to keep their moods up. If you fail at keeping your survivors happy, they will leave your shelter, steal food and weapons, or even mutiny against you.
This game is brilliant, and the latest patch made it even stronger. DOWNLOAD THIS GAME -- IT'S WORTH IT.

reviewText:
Great game !!!!! This game is about the only thing I found to a zombie, survival, base builder/Manager sim out there.

This game has the social tough choices similar to  State of decay " with a more important role in balancing upgrading your base with providing man power towards improving morale.

*********Things You should know*********

Combat in the game is turn based exploring and out of combat moving is not
-The combat system in this game allows you to do many of the things you would do if lets say zombies were real. For example:
You enter a block with a large Super Store
date: the path to the uber-lootable building is blocked by numerous zombies and obstacles that could hide even more zombies but luckily you had adopted an intelligent german shepard police dog. So you get the dog to lure the zombies in front of the building down an alley to the side of the building then returns once it lost the horde. now to enter the building
recommended: you decide to best leave your dog in front of the building to guard/alert you should the horde come back. The store is loaded with supplies that you so very much need. You round a corner and get pounced on by a zombie luckily your other compadrae was right behind you and sledge hammers the zombie in the back of the head before you became a torn open meat bag. Now you carry on with looting the building and come to an office door you open the door
hoursPlayed:
axe in hand ready to fight a possible zombie only to find a looter aiming a gun right at you.
He fires shooting right past your head. you duck back away from the room where the crazed gun man resides. Seconds later you hear pounding on an emergency exit where your pooch had lost the horde on the back alley of the building. They heard the gun shot. You and your partner high tale it out of there as the door busts in from the weight of the horde. The looter is now trapped in the room struggling to stay alive. You are half way out of the building as you hear moans and gunfire in your wake. You meet up with your loyal pup and flee the store now once again claimed by the dead.

-That is the sort of game play I love about Dead State I give it  5 out of 5

"

reviewText: The game has solid writing but just about everything else about the game its underwhelming to mediocre to downright boring. It can be a trudge to get through the game and I found myself playing through long periods of boring and/or frustrating gameplay to get to short spurts of good writing. You see my playtime count? That is one playthrough, that is me being careful like you're supposed to and stretching out viable resources - what you're supposed to do. There are just far, far too many problems with the gameplay to list them. There's even major, recurring issues outside of combat and they too are too numerous to list. While the shelter functions almost perfectly you'll encounter glitches and bugs that make the game tiresome and even disrupt combat frequently. Aside from that bugginess there are a plethora of questionable gameplay decisions outside of it. Zombies are terrible enemies for an isometric RPG and don't work well as antagonists for numerous reasons. Tie in that the game is so glitchy with the turn order I can't tell if they're supposed to be fast zombies or slow zombies and the main antagonists of the first half of the game are just really frustrating to deal with. The game isn't well balanced for the second half of the game, which is further hurt by extreme bugginess. The writing is quite good but you only usually get exposed to it at the beginning of each day. While there is environmental storytelling in most areas, with even some events in progress, its not enough to fill the gaps.\n\nThe gameplay is just too much of a chore for me to recommend the game for its writing, which while good isn't so good its worth trudging through the rest of the game for. The game would've been recommended if it had the gameplay of a title like State of Decay but since 90% of the game is average to downright tedious and boring I cannot recommend it, not even for a Steam sale. I got it on such a sale for $9 and while I don't regret my purchase I don't believe I could recommend it to others.

reviewText:
I have a very strong Love/Hate relationship with this game.  I love it because it is turn-based, concerns surviving the Zombie Apocolypse, and has RPG elements.  I hate it because it is just too <expletive deleted> addicting, which sometimes ensures my Monday mornings at work are impacted by my lack of an adequate amount of REM sleep.

Is it perfect?  No, but what game is?  And remember, this is just a game, a means of entertaining yourself.  Apparently, I have not spent enough time in-game to encounter all these bugs that are generating so much drama in the forums.  Regardless, if I find any bugs, I plan to communicate with the devs in hopes of fixing them, not go whining to the forum flamewars (grow up peeps).

I strongly recommend Dead State to those of you who like turn-based RPGs in a Zombie Apocolypse setting that incorporates group behavior and relationship management in addition to combat and exploration.  It is a challenging game and I look forward to many more (>100) hours of play.  Thatz a great value in my opinion...

reviewText:
Dead State has fantastic potential! After putting more than 100hrs in, I felt I had genuinely beaten a zombie apocalypse!

If you're heading into Dead State with a Dead Rising/Dead Island state of mind, don't. Dead State is a 'survival simulator'. It's more about 'what if' than 'wouldn't it be cool if...' and right from the get-go, it's all about doing what needs to be done to keep you and your team alive.

It has a great RPG system to it, but you don't level-up by smashing skulls. Instead, you gain EXP by saving survivors, scavenging for supplies and making the best decisions for your team.

With all these 'how will you die' survival horrors, it's actually refreshing to see a deep simulator where your objective is to make it!

After playing the 1.0 build, I've noticed quite a few updates that have ironed-out bugs and added even more gamer ideas. Double Bear seem like a great developer and Dead State will only get better from their loyal support.

Enjoy the apocalypse!

reviewText:
Even being a fan of turn-based games, Dead State only scrapes being a passable game to play if you have nothing else to do. There are a few good aspects, though the negative aspects overrule a lot of the enjoyment which could be had.

Good Aspects:
- The micromanagement of each person in your shelter and prioritising finite resources is satisfying
- Unique survivor perks and characteristics which adds a bit extra decision making when deciding on a team
- The leveling up system is odd, but appears to function fairly well, allowing you to scale well relative to the dangers of the outside

Bad Aspects:
- Combat - At the start combat seems ok, but the further in the slower, more tedious, and painfully boring it gets. During each turn of combat, the queue of characters will cycle through the entire list of characters on the map until it gets to a relevant character/zombie/etc participating in that combat. With the larger, more zombie-populated maps, I was sitting up to roughly 15-25 seconds per round simply waiting for the queue to cycle to the relevant zombie. Plus, when a zombie is in the combat area, but unable to reach a player, it will stand there for 5 seconds or so, letting out a bored groan, mimicking my own, made worse again when 4-5 zombie were bottlenecked.

It may not seem like a lot, but if combat has as little as 4 or so rounds, I am essentially waiting triple or quadruple the length of time than is actually necessary to finish combat. And, the more you play and the harder areas you get to, the worse the issue.

- Descriptions - You will need to use Google. A lot. Descriptions of the various skills, leveling system, and user interface are very poor, meaning you will either need to have a second monitor with a wiki page helping you understand the basics for the first several hours, or you will be re-loading previous saves after realising you screwed your character up.
- Bugginess - While not the worst game bug-wise, there were many instances of characters occupying the same cell and making it difficult to issue certain commands, a few times I was attacked by 'invisible' zombies, which only appeared during the second round of combat, and there were a few crash to desktop moments, though I can forgive this.

In short - big problems, which could be quite simply fixed, potentially raising the score from 4/10 to 7.5/10.

reviewText:
One of those frustrating games where ambition has outstripped ability to execute. The concept is great - managing a shelter of survivors of a zombie apocalypse - and there's a stack of looting, crafting and even diplomacy to do.

Unfortunately it's all held back by the combat system. It's slow, it doesn't feel like there are many options (no overwatch/defensive stance), the bottlenecks caused by the narrow grid system are more irritating than strategic and the AI is really frustrating - just had a prime example where a human enemy had two zombies gnawing away at him, but kept shooting at my unconscious character until she died.

It also has some dubious design decisions, such as requiring that your character be on every scavenging mission. Even if you have 20+ people at the shelter, and your character is best suited to leading behind the scenes, you must go out.

Not only does this discourage focusing on the leadership/negotiation skills, it means you're at a constant disadvantage as you have to either sacrifice a day of scavenging to rest or constantly have a character with half their HP.

Speaking of negotiation, it offers a lot of promise but is too reliant on hidden triggers. One example was when I had a heart-to-heart with a survivor and finished by asking him to ask how I was the next time we saw each other. I ran up to him with anticipation the next day...and only had the option of repeating that very same conversation. It made the whole thing feel empty and pointless.

The AI in general is a bit wonky. One location has a group of survivors lure you into an ambush. However, if you don't walk to the specific spot which triggers that, you can just stroll around them and loot all their stuff while they stand there blankly.

For all that negativity, I still recommend buying it if you can get it cheap. It is still more enjoyable than many games, and it's worth a shot to experience the positives; it's just depressing to imagine what it might have been.

reviewText:
Dead State is a RPG about surviving the zombie apocalypse in Texas. In terms of setting, the game nails it.  Since society has broken down you’ll have to turn your group into a bunch of scavengers in order to survive. This is a dangerous endeavor in Texas where firearms are plentiful, and some homeowners aren’t going to let you raid their pantries or medicine cabinets without a fight.

As leader of a rag tag group of survivors you are going to be in charge of determining who to take in, how rations are divvied up, what improvements to build at base with your meager resources, and how you will relate to outside groups like motorcycle gangs, militias, and remnants of the US Army. Sub leaders will emerge within your group whose council you will need to take into account. They may try to pull off a coup against you. Maybe you can accommodate them or maybe you can put a bullet in their head during a mission and blame bandits.

While I thoroughly enjoyed the setting, character interaction, and government game aspects of Dead State there were a few issues that might be major turn offs for some players. First off, it pretty much plays exactly like the old turn based CRPGs of the late 1990s. Think Fallout 2 with zombies. It also looks a little like Fallout 2 (as viewed through nostalgia goggles – obviously it is more attractive than Fallout 2 if you’ve played Fallout 2 recently).  I personally don’t like the art style because a friend pointed out that all the NPC’s have facial features characteristic of Down’s Syndrome (and now I can’t unsee that… thanks, bro). The lack of voice acting made Dead State’s NPCs feel a little flat. Vampire the Masquerade: Bloodlines’ NPCs were really interesting because of excellent voice acting coupled with great dialogue by Dead State lead Brian Mitsoda.  Also, be prepared for an assortment of bugs and crashes. I don’t know if there is anything game breaking you need to worry about but that could be a possibility.

I was able to get 175 hours of enjoyment out of it and I am actually contemplating starting a new campaign to try more stuff out. So consider this highly recommended, if you can put up with the flaws I mentioned.

reviewText:
HIGHLY RECCOMENDED!
The good: Excellent zombie sandbox game with among many other things, elements of RPG and Turn Based Combat.
I bought this when it was early and very incomplete and had high hopes for it to become something special...which I am pleased to say in many ways it has. For a huge zombie fan like myself, this game is something i've always hoped for. If an editor ever gets released, this game will be a without question must have for anyone who enjoys the zombie genre. A lot of freedom to explore and even the freedom to run your survival shelter like a total prick. ♥♥♥♥♥♥ at a couple of your lazy sub-ordinates? Take em out in the field and perhaps they will have an...unfortunate run in with the undead out there. Nice little storyline that doesn't really get in the way of exploring the overall game itself.

The bad:  Unforgiving. Your first run in with hostile survivors will make it very evident that you just might be outmatched and outgunned. Missing a shotgun blast at point blank range...with your last 2 shells...yeah that just happened. Can become a bit repititious as well, as some locales appear to be just more of the same stuff you've already seen. Prepare to save and reload often.

Keep in mind you can bring up console commands to give yourself a bit of an edge. This game will not hold your hand.

Again I am a huge zombie fan and gamer from way back....and this game took me away from a very modded State of Decay for a nice bit of time...which says a lot. This one is worth a buy for sure if you love gaming and the living dead.

reviewText:
TL;DR: Buggy and unfinished. Don't buy it. Wait for the 2015 summer sale, hoping it will be patched.

I backed the kickstarter and I was pretty excited about the whole game, especially the concept.

Turns out the only thing they managed to pull off is the concept, everything else falls painfully short.

Extremely buggy in so many ways. Sometimes pathfinding won't let you enter a room. Other times combat wont end even with no enemies near. Enemies and allies sometimes teleport through walls, or sometimes stack ontop of eachother and become untargettable. Oftentimes animations freeze and your characters just hover around.

Combat is generally very uninspiring. Not tactical, not exciting. It's a chore.
Looting also is very unimaginative, quickly becomes boring.
Inventories are a mess. Sorting doesnt work and managing alot of items is extremely frustrating.
Companions clearly have some effort put into them, but lack any meaningful interaction.
Balance is way off, both in combat and in managing the shelter.

Still, despite all it's flaws it's not a lost cause.
The world map is huge and exploration is exciting, also the shelter has a number of interesting mechanics.
If you can look past the last-gen graphics and interface you can find the makings of a truly good game underneath.

Sadly though, I can't recommend the game before it's extensively patched, or perhaps even modified by the community.

edit: typos.

reviewText:
I played it before release and have played about 15 hours after release. This game combines a lot of great elements that I love to see in games. I really wanted to recommend it, but no. At release this is more like a game that's ready to enter beta testing. The development team is still working hard on it, but it's nowhere near release ready. There are many known issues that have not been patched, some of which will cause crashes to desktop, like double-clicking at the wrong time.

There are unfinished features and overall a lack of polish. The trading/inventory management is extremely awkward. Tutorial messages will popup at inappropriate times if you breeze through the tutorial too quickly. Pathfinding is still very bad in spots. The main character frequently paces back and forth when doing commmon tasks like going to sleep to cycle a new day.

The tactical combat is very basic. There's no crouching behind an object for cover. Allies block movement. Characters and enemies occasionally stack in the same square which stops you from attacking/interacting with them properly. It's not terrible, but it's  nowhere near the level of X-Com or Shadowrun.

I would recommend this game if the price tag was $15 instead of $30.

reviewText:
Overall, I love this game. It delivers on the promise of managing a shelter, fighting for survival, tactical combat with very different approaches to the dead and the living. Given that it was made by a tiny, indie team on a small budget, this ambitious game delivers.

I did wait for the Reanimated update to start playing, and I think a number of earlier complaints have been fixed.

What I like:
I like the dual game of managing the shelter and then going out and exploring the world and engaging in tactical combat, almost like a role playing Total War game.
Set in the modern world!! A nice break from high fantasy for the genre.
Good opportunities to role play, with fairly interesting characters.
Combat is fun and tactical. Approach to fighting zombies and humans is very different. And the noise meter is a good system that adds a nice cost and trade-off decision to firing each round of a gun.
Maps are quite well designed. They capture the feeling on Walking Dead and other zombie shows - the world is your oyster, go around, scavenge, pilfer, but be ware. Around every turn a zombie or 10 could be hanging out, or you bust into a supermarket only to find half a dozen aggressive looters already there and they don't want to share.
The feeling of resource scarcity is real - you are generally always low on something, whether it is fuel, antibiotics, bullets, etc. They did a pretty good job of making enough systems where you feel a constant urge to go out and risk life and limb to find more of something.
Good writing and humor - item descriptions are fun, and some maps visually tell a story without any dialogue. There is a faux-twinkie factory, and an ominous church filled with dead inside. I am sure there are more like it!

Cons:
Though much more stable than previous versions I guess, I still get a few crashes and bugs
Characters feel a bit shallow. There are a good amount of them and probably more I haven't found, but I do wish they had more depth and other branches of dialogue, and more interaction across them.
Interface is very clunky - especially the inventory. Splitting items is a pain. Trading items between team members requires a special move, instead of being just built into the inventory. Reloading and unloading guns is done oddly and you can only do it in certain screens or menus.

reviewText:
Don't, just wait until it is patched. Don't go near that buy button just yet. This game is still half cooked. I've played enough of it to know that although it is a great game, in time, right now save your money. Come back and visit once in a while to check how it is going, but the game still suffers from a range of issues.

The game still plays out like a static puzzle game where you will start repeating the same cycle of 'grinding' time and time again. There is nothing dynamic in the game world, your memorable moments will be far and few between. So many parts of this game are underdeveloped and simply tacked on, yet all of them could benefit from more development time and just some more tuning. The combat is simplistic, pre-2000 RPG games had better mechanics for combat, whilst the narrative and character progression is just so thin.

Dead State will either become a great game a year from now or it'll be a developer-myth about great ideas with poor execution.

reviewText:
Dead State is a game of good intentions marred by unpolished content and occasionally flawed execution.  When it works, it's a delightful experience reminiscent of the original Fallout and other such games with an interesting world and endearing characters.  Collecting loot from locations, rescuing survivors and interacting with them, upgrading your shelter, and equipping your characters all prove to be engaging stuff.  The first 30 days are great fun as you struggle to explore a strange and hostile landscape.

That said, the game ends up with several critical flaws. It's unfortunately buggy and will crash on you quite frequently, the UI is occasionally frustrating to sort through for important information, and the combat is underwhelming due to mechanics that become imbalanced in the mid to late-game. The game just steadily begins to run out of steam after the first month as it gradually runs out of ways to challenge the player.  You'll mostly be sitting around as you wait for the game's endings, which themselves don't do much to really resolve the player's emotional connection to the characters and story.

Dead State is a game I cautious recommend.  It tries to be the Zombie RPG we all wanted 10 years ago and succeeds fpr the most part, but in doing so it feels exactly like an unfinished Iso-RPG from 10 years ago.  Dead State isn't perfect, but I guess it manages to be good enough"."

reviewText:
It's just not fun.  Plays like something from 15 years ago.

The Last Stand - Union City has more base building depth, is more fun, and it's free.


Dead State forces you out on EVERY mission - no sending teams out to do something unless you're a part of them.  This diminishes the feeling of being a leader and makes the gameplay quickly repetative, which might not be so bad except that the combat is so boring.

Zombies and looters will single you out EVERY time.  This makes it hard to keep your health up and makes it unenjoyable to be forced to go on the missions.

The base management is unenjoyable and essentially plays like a worse version of free web games.  Everything feels flat and uninspired.


I can't overstate how slowly this game moves.  There aren't any parts of it that I find fun.  It would be more exciting to just read a good zombie novel.
voteText: 20 of 30 people (67%) found this review helpful

reviewText:
Dead State is what I expect from an apocalyptic RPG.  It left me with good memories of “Oh Crap, what did I just do” and “Wow, that worked out well.”

The combat is fun.  Managing the shelter is fun.  Handing out luxury items to boost characters morale is not so fun.

Toward the end it gets boring waiting for the endings to start, but if you have a well stocked shelter you can just end the days and get through it quickly.

The bugs are annoying, but they do not break the game other than the the occasional crash to desktop (remember to quick save!).
voteText: 22 of 34 people (65%) found this review helpful

reviewText:
Overall the game is worth buying if you like a slow pace zombie game focused on group story survival.

Cons:
Combat mode just doesn't fit. It would work if battles were more group focused. Example if zombies fought in groups together so that on a map you would have maybe 3 or 4 major fights which you can fully enjoy the tactical control of the combat system. Currently, you will quickly grow bored killing sometimes one zombie at a time.. some maps have probably 50+ zombies; very mind numbing.

Story:
Whoever wrote this games story needs to get some real life experience. Don't get me wrong, the direction of the story is awesome but as soon as one part starts to get interesting the epic idiocy comes out in full.
Examples without give out too much details:

The group members do not respond as if the world just ended by a horde of zombies. They will try to take 'time off' for insane things like headaches, diarrhea, etc. You wouldn't tell your captain you had a stomach bug in the middle of a battle nor would you 'take the day off' if zombies could at any moment run the shelter over. For that matter, they all are pretty blah about the experience.

Personally it feels like the designer got their sixteen year old emo kid to write the story.

Despite the short falls it's still worth getting.

reviewText:
Updated for Reanimated Version:

It took me several attempts to get into this game, but am now hooked. I'm at about day 15 and am happy to report that the writing gets better and all of the features I was looking forward to start to open up quite a bit (shelter upgrades, new survivors, interesting but tough choices, and personality management).

I am a point and click guy, but will admit, there are times the combat can get pretty tedious. There are some layers of strategy that can be satisfying (ie; using the noise meter and zombie hordes to your advantage to take out looters) BUT you really need to take time in between battles to manage your inventory before heading out on another run. They do, however, alleviate some of the micromanagement by automatically stocking shelter items each time you return.

Your survivors will randomly need to take some time off due to sickness or other reasons, so you will have shuffle your scavenger party every once and a while (this is a good thing). Your survivors also level up, but at a slower pace than your main character.  And while you can't allocate the points manually, you can occassionally suggest areas you would like your other survivors to improve when they do decide to level up (which is fine, I guess. It goes along with the concept that you can't control everybody at your shelter. You have to mange personalities through dialogue choices and finding items in missions).

For me, the UI wasn't as intuitive as I was expecting when it comes to information and inventory management...but that's a tiny gripe.

Aside from those gripes and small pathing issues, if you give it a little time, the game does get interesting. It's certainly worth 20 bucks and has more depth than I thought it would. The demo will give you a good idea of gameplay mechanics, but as I mentioned, it really picks up from about day 8-12.




-------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------


I've been following this prject before kickstarter many years ago and am an early backer. While the development has been slower than I had initially hoped (due to some global issues affecting some of their remote team members), there is enough here to get the gist of the type of game they are trying to make. And it definitely has some really great potential (exactly what you want to see in an Alpha).

While the updates have been slow moving, when they do implement an update, you see a pretty significant impact. It's somewhat playable as is, but still needs a lot of work. You are paying to help test and give feedback. They have only released the first seven days and there is much to do. And while we all want more, they are still implementing story, maps, features, etc. . If they released anything beyond seven days, it would spoil the story and other surprises they have in store for us when the full game is released.

Back this now while it's on the cheap. This game has too much potential for gamers to let it slip into obscurity.

reviewText:
In the modern zombie apocalypse, you take shelter with several other survivors in abandoned school to fend off zombies and not-so-altruistic survivors.
The zombie-infested modern world is depicted very nicely albeit brutal, where you can see how humanity quickly goes back to being medieval.

Will you stay humane in this maddness to people around you, or become one of the predators yourself, preying on the weak and abusing everyone around you just to survive that another day?
You can do all that and more in this very unique RPG game with turn based combat, strategic and planning elements and lots anf lots of dialogues.

It is really hard to compare this unique game to anything, except that it has been heavily influenced by older RPG titles like Fallout.

All in all, this time spent reading about the game is better be spent playing the game yourself, have fun!

reviewText:
Early Access Review

Considering turn based games have been around for decades, it's hard to explain why this one stuffs it all up so horribly. On the surface this has a lot to recommend it; recource gathering, base building, missions and more besides, and no doubt that make might for a fun game. But the combat system is so irredeemably awful it makes getting into the game a tricky notion.

The typical action point system only comes into play once you're in combat so you're free to run around until then, but once you enter combat, good Lord does the game go south. For a start, you can't attack on a diagonal, which makes precisely no sense. Square on fighting is the order of the day. Secondly, there's no way to bring up a list of key commands so if you need to change view for instance, there are no on-screen icons to do it (a staple of these kind of games surely), you're kind of stuck. The whole game lacks that kind of simple clarity. Thirdly, it's too easy to batter someone on your team (why does the game allow this without at least a simple 'are you sure?' check?).

As a result, once you enter combat it turns into a farce of repeated misses with whatever weapon you have equipped (early in the game you equip a weapon which doesn't show on your character who then gets advised to equip a weapon by everyone he meets before going outside - top work!), shuffling your characters around to try and get to the right square to attack and then using all your action points hitting your own team. It's just rubbish from top to bottom.

It might get better and I'm certainly going to persist playing it as it seems to have genuine depth, but it's frustrating and counter-intuitive to play. I was hoping for State of Decay meets X-Com but this falls far short of that lofty aspiration.

Ho hum.

reviewText: If you like turn-based RPG's, I highly recommend this one. I played Suikoden back in the day until they stopped making it for the European market, and the replay value of Dead State is kind of like that of Suikoden: You play through, then you play through again to get things perfect. Then you set it asside and pick it up one day when you remember what a fun game it was.\n\nI love collecting the characters, interacting with them, and scavenging. Killing the zombies is fairly easy, but battling the gun-wielding humans can be a pain in the ♥♥♥ (but that's part of the fun). I like improving my headquarters and the crafting. I like how my decision making and interactions have consequences, and I like following along with people's stories. I also have to give the developers special props for not deciding for me that the main character is hetero. That was a pleasant surprise.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

I'm only posting this out here due to the mass amount of trolls attacking this game for no reason as I would not recommend anyone to purchase a game that is in Early Access as there is no reason to unless you want to help the developers out with testing and feedback.

1. This is not a timed demo. The game does not expire after 7 days. The initial build is called The First Seven days because it only features content from the first seven in game days.

2. This is not a paid demo. This build is an evolution of the 3 day demo that was shown at PAX. It is a way for Kickstarter backers to get a progress report to see how far the game has come along

If this was released in the condition it was in, it would be commercial suicide. It's buggy, it's crash prone, and it lacks many features. Unlike actual demos that exist for finished games, this is not a demonstration of the final product.

You can either save a measly $5 to pre-order a game that isn't done and get access to content that is not even in beta form yet, or you can wait 3-5 months for the game to be actually finished and try out the public demo that will be available to everyone for free while reading reviews and make the decision for yourself.

If the word demo" was absent and it was simply called The First Seven days
date: then I guarantee you there would be no public backlash as the content featured here is the same as the initial Early Access builds of Wasteland 2

The firearms in this game are far too underpowered to be of any use against anybody, living or dead. One of the worst parts of this game is the hit chance for a gun. reviewText:
I would really like to write a positive review for this game, sadly I cannot.
The combat thus far is simplistic - at best, lacking giving any tactical advantages to combat. Unfortunately this causes the difficulty to be... excessive. I think so far I've reloaded Brady (near the beginning) around 10 times, from looking online, I'm not alone in that.
The focus on melee, means that the game devolves into surrounding an enemy and hitting them. Unfortunately the human enemies seem almost super-powered compared to your guys, surviving multiple axe, bats and shotgun blasts to the face.

I'll be following the game in case things like cover mechanics, crouching, overwatch get added in, but for the time being, the combat is overly simplistic, lacks difficulty options and has a number of crashes that really should have been resolved by now.

A pity, it had a lot of potential.

reviewText:
WARNING: This game starts off slow and easy but the learning curve is pretty steep. Yes, killing a single zombie is a cakewalk. Yes, the shelter occupants you start with are a pretty good bunch. Yes, it seems like once you get a chain link fence up all your troubles are over.

They are NOT.

The game will actually let you fall pretty far behind the curve - and then murder you. It will certainly monkey wrench your plans and will make running your shelter difficult. If you are not careful people, including you, will die in one, two rounds of combat. Don't let the simplicity of the graphics or the basics of combat fool you.

Play at your own risk. :)

I knew I was going to spend some time with ths game when I found myself zooming in on the map so I could see the details, read the spraypainted graffiti on the wall, and try to figure out just what story was being told with the scenery in a house that was no more important to the storyline than holding three zombies to fight and a little bit of random loot.

I like strategic games, I like building games, I like RPG's, and I really liked the Fallout series of games. Any game that is going to give me a dog companion (a perk available in the game) to face the post-apocalyptic future, zombie-filled or otherwise, is going to get my attention. A shelter filled with unique occupants with interesting backstories, single player combat that I have to worry about more than my current health to survive, and wanting to see what new thing happens tomorrow is going to keep my attention for a while.

IF you prefer FPS/realtime over turn based games, cannot stand bugs in games, or want the latest and greatest in game graphics think twice before buying this game.

IF you like games where you go back to earlier saves to try something different, unexpected monkey wrench" challenges to your plans

reviewText:
Dead State is not a perfect game but something about it keeps pulling me back to play it.

It is slow and requires a good amount of planning before you leave your shelter and during battles. The modes of difficulty adds a good amount of replayability as it forces you to rethink your strategies.

If you are the sort who likes to mull/brood over every action of your character and you like zombies, consider giving this game a go.

This is not for you if you expect to run into a group of zombies and start bashing heads willy-nilly.

reviewText:
I know there is a lot of negative reviews about the bugs and i wasn't sure if i was going to get this game but i read some of the positive reviews and i decided to go with it.  It's a very fun game and i'm really enjoying.  It's nice to play a single player version of a survival game.  I played h1z1 and dayz and while those games are fun its really hard to enjoy the game when you get killed on sight and lose all your stuff.

I'm not in to writing a big a review of the game.  Most people have already gave a good review of it.  I'll just tell you a little story.  I was on a run and on the way back, i found a camp.  So we go check it out and start taking stuff.  Well there was people there telling me not to take there stuff.  Well i ignored them and they starting attack us.  So i killed them all and took there stuff.  Well first i beat them down and knocked them out and than did a final blow to them.  I go back to the shelter and one of the guys at the shelter told me that i shouldn't do that.  Just kill random people and take there stuff.  I told him i won't do that again but i still do it.  Another time, i got a random encounter on the road where there was a car crash.  There was a guy standing next to a dead body next to his wrecked car.  He wasn't saying anything so i wasn't sure what to do, so i just killed him.  No consequences on that though.  I think it was suppose to let me recruit him but i think it was a bug because he wasn't saying anything.

The bugs in the game aren't that bad.  Every now and than, the game will crash but it takes a long time for that to happen.  The game autosaves a lot so its not really a big deal if the game crashes.  A little annoying but whatever.  It's still worth playing and i hope there will be dlcs for the game.  If you are wondering if $29  is worth it, i would say yes.  You could wait for a sale but i didn't and i'm enjoying the game a lot.  As i get further in the game.  I'll add to my review. Overall, this game is addicting to play.

reviewText:
okay, i am going to try and give as good a review i can on this.

first of all i believe people should give this game more of a try.

ORIGONALY i was VERY on the fence about this game. after hearing of massive bugs and the event that went down during the steam winter sale. i was hesitant to buy this game, but then it went on sale and i thought, why not? so i shall give my reasons why i support this game and what ive seen, bugs and all.

#1 the bugs

YES there are many!!!! BUT, most are small annoyences that can easily be fixed OR avoided.

1 corpses tend have there body model one place, but acctually be somewhere else. so if you try to attack a zombie and are confused as to why your charecter is wandering off a different direction, you know why. this bug is a little common, but it useually doesint cause a major problemb or major frustration.

2 be CAUTIOUS around 2 or more floored buildings!! these tend to have lag and are very glitchy/ wonkey!! ESSPECIALLY ON THE STAIR CASES!!! SO try to avoid saveing in these areas and go slow. you can eaither take your chances or avoid them. second storys are useually rare or far away from your base. so you wont reach them till your far in game.

3 charecter AI i dont find that bad. they tend to do stupid things, but i feel as long as your not running far ahead and stay close to your team they tend to navigate fine. running ahead too far makes the navigation a little confused. this does not mean you have to stick close to them like babys.

you have to assume they will go straight for you or take the shortest route to you. if you run around the zombie hoard while your far ahead and your teams just now catching up, guess whats going to happen. so always keep that in mind and that your team can lag behind a little.

4 random crashes. i have only had 2 (knock on wood) so far. but the game auto saves everytime you enter a area. there is also the quick save button F5 and a quick load button F9. so when the crashes do happen, they happen very quick and you can just quickly reload the game.

5 so far no major lag. lag tends to only happen when a lot of zombies are suddenly aware of you or appere suddenly all together. and agian as mentioned above, in 2 or more floored buildings. it rarely happens.

6 mutiple bodys on a single tile in the same position. mainly zombie bodys. useually you have to glide the mouse slowly over the stack to select the different bodys becuase they merge/ cover each other. happens as often as you let it. zombies useually tend to stay seperate unless you funnel them down a hall or something.

7 dead state is not very happy with windows 8. you CAN play it on win 8, i am proof of that. but in order to play it on win 8 you have to go to the games main file and set it on windows 7 compatability".

reviewText:
I really liked this game even though there were quite a few issues with it like:
- Random crashes (thankfully the game autosaves every time you enter a new area so it more or less makes up for it)

But on the plus side:
+ The game has an interesting story and it revolves around the people more than the zombies surrounding them.
+ The choices you make matter, like they would in real life. Reminds me of MEffect and DAge.
+ Had two people murdered and then one of the murderer's killed herself. 10/10
+ Killed coyotes, militia and military.... ended up getting out by bus since obviously I'm bad at making friends. Sadly lost Sir Charleston and Bud (still torn up about it).
+ Max became unhappy, hopped over the fence and went on a killing spree.
+ Aggro Moss randomly asked to have sex, so sure why not.

reviewText:
Dead State has so much gristle and fat and not much protein.

If I were more willing to save time, I would have wrote a review condemning the game's length and amount of Monty Haul gameplay - because you have to scavenge SO MUCH in this game. Of course, this means going around to all the various places in Central Texas, dodging every zombie and murdering every looter to fill up your backpacks with as many ramen noodles and luxury items as you can carry. TIMES INFINITY. I wouldn't mind if there was more to interact with in the world (and there really needs to be more stuff to do to break up the monotony of scavenging all the time), because having to loot gets so damn boring after a while. I ended up skipping entire days towards the end of my playthrough because I was really sick and tired of having to go out and ♥♥♥♥ing pick up the groceries. And I hated not being able to delegate this task to the two or three people sitting around in the shelter once all the improvements were built. This mechanic, while it fits in really well with the world falling apart and even adds an 'Earth Abides'-style flavor to the proceedings, drove me up the ♥♥♥♥ing wall and onto the ceiling, down the wall on the other side of the room, and back. Like a really angry hamster determined to get out of his cage.

So why didn't I just quit the game and play something else?

Here's why - this game has some very, very interesting storytelling. When people talk about this game being a spiritual successor to games like Vampire: The Masquerade: Bloodlines and Arcanum, they're talking about the solid storytelling. Brian Mitsoda (he worked on Bloodlines and Arcanum) and two other people made this game, and Brian did such a damn good job with the writing that I kept going despite hating what was going on with the game. And that storytelling is what held my interest throughout the entire game - I nearly could forgive all the monotonous scavenging if it meant more lovingly written, well-researched bits about how the world fell to the zombies, about astronauts losing their ♥♥♥♥ on the ISS, interactions between survivors, between militia groups, between the outside world and the little emotional ecosystem going on in the shelter. Those moments were beautiful and fun to experience.

I really had to fight to finish the game, both inside the game and outside. The scavenging took such a mental toll on me, but the storytelling kept me coming back for more. I don't doubt that this is going to be a cult classic among RPG enthusiasts, easily joining the ranks of the great RPG games that don't work all that great but have such wonders to show anyway.

You know what? To hell with it. I recommend this game, but  only if you bring several audiobooks or your backlog of podcasts to go along with it. If you don't, the monotony will drive you crazy (unless you're one of those mutants who runs around in a field to beat up slimes so you can grind your way to one-shotting Sephiroth at the end, in which case there is no hope for you). It starts out strong and ends strong, but everything in-between moves so damn slowly I nearly quit several times. You've been warned.

I have held off buying Dead State after seeing some people upset over what they felt was the game leaving Early Access too soon to benefit from the Winter Steam Sale.  I have been watching the game for a long time but decided to wait until it went on sale to pick it up.  It seems like Doublebear has been doing steady patching, while maybe not to the level some people want, updating none the less, so when it went on sale I went ahead and decided to pick it up.   I love turn-based games and RPGs and Zombie stuff so it I figured I would roll the dice and drop $20 on it and see what I got.

So far with a couple hours under my belt I am really enjoying it and I haven't ran into any bugs.  The UI is a bit frustrating at times and a couple of times I wasn't sure what I needed to do for stuff like swapping inventory.  A quick glance at the manual resolved those issues.  The game can be counter-intutive at times but counter-intutive isn't the same thing as game breaking bugs.  During my play (I admit I haven't spent a lot of time yet) I have enjoyed the game play.   It does feel like XCOM with Zombies instead of Aliens.   Yes the misses will frustrate you sometimes, but that is the genre.  The game isn't easy" but it isn't "unfair" either.

People can fuss over if Doublebear released the game too soon as a greedy move or not.  I don't know what the game state was back in December when it launched

reviewText:
Ok, so where do I start, because I have alot to say. I think if you look at the 113 hours of play time for dead state that I have  on record, you can see that its a game that I enjoy playing thoroughly. Then I see people with 0.5 hours of play time, writing bad reviews for the game, and clearly they havent actually played the game. I find every aspect of the game to be amazing, from the base building, to the combat and discovery and group management.

Does that mean that the game is without flaws? Definately not. There are things about the game that I would like to see changed in ways, but the devs did say that we can expect more patches with changes and additions. I just feel that some guy got ♥♥♥♥♥♥ off, and he got all his friends on board to do bad reviews on the game, atleast thats what it looks like. Show me another game where they have all of my favourite aspects in one game, eg base management, character progression, exploration, looting, the list goes on.

Some people might argue that the game was taken out of Early Access too quickly. I could understand why people would be upset about that....if all the patching and content also stopped, but thats not the case. DB devs posted that continued patches and content are planned, and by the amount of patches in the last few weeks, I can see they keep their word.

I've played many otehr games, games that cost more, and I've felt truly robbed by some of those whishing i could get the time and money spent back. Dead State is not one of those games.

I for one, wish that there were more games like Dead State

reviewText:
I've just finished my first playthrough of Dead State and I definitely plan on replaying it at some point in the future. In short, I'd say that it's definitely in my top games for 2014.

The game is a bit of a curious mix of survival games (think resource gathering in something like This War of Mine) set within a framework of a RPG playing quite like Fallout 1 and 2. After a brief intro sequence you are soon aware that the zombie apocalypse is happening and you are soon put in charge of a shelter in a Texas town called Splendid. It's your job to make sure any survivors (you will find many who you can invite into the Shelter) living there can, well, continue to survive. You talk to people, solve conflicts, assign jobs. And then you wander out into the world seeking resources.

The game is viewed from a top-down perspective with a camera you can spin around.

Gameplay:
There are a few different gameplay actions you do during the game. As described above, the Shelter is your base which you need to improve. This is done via a Job Board where you can assign tasks to your fellow survivors such as building things, be a doctor, or come with you out into the field to get supplies.
This is all dependant on the game's RPG system where you can invest points into various skills such as Ranged Combat, Leadership, Medical skill etc. All survivors you meet have their own set of skills (which you don't have any control over, but will continue to grow over the course of the game) which make them suitable for different tasks.

There is a base management aspect of the Shelter. You need to keep it stocked with food, gas for the generator, luxury items and medical items. There is a morale stat for the Shelter depending on how well you do.

The survivors also hang around the Shelter where you can talk to them and get (fairly brief) bits of their stories. You can also ask them if there's anything special they'd want from the scavenging hunts. Someone may favour whiskey, someone else a cigar. This will raise their mood. If a survivor's mood goes down, they may end up leaving you.

Also, each morning there are little interactions, situations that arise in the Shelter. People may be arguing, someone may need to talk to you about something etc. Sometimes there are Crisis Events which is regarding bigger decisions in the Shelter. The characters involved will agree or disagree depending on your choices.
The writing for the characters is very good most of the time. It's down to earth and believable most of the time. There are a few exceptions but mostly the writing gives the game a real human feel which is exactly what a game like this needs. You can also find data items" which can be found in the world and decrypted so you can read them. These items vary from the Dead State equivalent of Twitter messages
hoursPlayed: message board discussions etc
voteText:
mostly about the outbreak of the zombie virus. These are *fantastic* and present a real nice backdrop to everything that's happening.

I also have to give the developers kudos for including characters with a form of mental illness. Too often in games do they treat mental illness as just being CRAZY! But Dead State does it seriously even while it may not dive too deeply into the subject either.

During the day

reviewText:
So apparently, zombies are faster, have more powerful attacks, and have a better chance of hitting you than you do of hitting them. No matter who you select for your first party, its like watching the three stooges try to fight the undead. Miss, miss, miss, get eaten.

Zombies can also sense you if you are directly behind them. No sneaking allowed.

Also, they have 9 action points, which is as much or more than your starting party members. Which means they can shuffle much further than you can move, while apparently getting free or almost free attacks, which is infinitely better than the 3-8 AP required to attack them.

All of this topped off with the fact that your weapons hit them for 7-25 damage, up to about 50 with the sledgehammer. This is out of a 50ish HP pool they have. Top that with the fact that they can hit you with anywhere from 7-62(?!?!?!?!) HP, after shuffling as far as you could move, out of your 90-110 HP pool.

In a nutshell:
-can't tank them
-can't kite them
-can't evade them
-can't sneak past them
-must rely on luck to beat them
-if you don't outnumber them 2 or 3 to 1, it has a high probability of a loss.

When the devs manage to botch what I heard was a good game before Reanimated"

reviewText:
I've decided to write a review for this game to try to curb down the negativity around this game. I've read many reviews that claim this game is awful, unplayable, so full of bugs that it's not enjoyable and after playing 75 hours of it, I will have to disagree. I'm not saying it's a perfect game or doesn't need more work and polishing but it is still a pretty damn fine game on it's own.

Now as far as bugs go, I've encontered a few but not nearly as much as other people claim there are. There was one instance of a zombie disapearing and being unattackable while still existing on the map and attacking you on it's turn and every once in a while the game crashed. But other than that I've been pretty much bug free.

What I enjoy about this game? An intresting story/setup where being the leader of your group of survivor of a zombie apocalypse isn't just about mowing through wave after wave of zombies and calling it a day. Taking care of your shelter and your people can be just as fascinating. The combat while not super deep has some interesting layers with positioning, noise making and panic mixed in the simple but effective turn based combat. There are some nice RPG elements added that give some replay value and I absolutely love how you can influence certain events/characters simply by the way you treat them. I also enjoy looking at the shelter evolve with time both from upgrading it but also from smaller things (food in the pantry for example) and wish there was even more of that in the game.

My biggest complaint with the game as it stands is how unbalanced it is. Maybe I've just played that type of game too often or maybe I'm too efficient" for what the devs intended but after only 30 days in game all shelter upgrades were built. At day 45 I've discovered what looked like most of the locations. And because of the perks I took I had enough fuel and food to not have to care about it for another 3 months
date: I had enough antibiotics to be able to shower my people with them
recommended: my fence was nearly indestructible and I had enough weapons and armor to have everyone equipped
hoursPlayed: even characters I knew full well I would never take in the field and even then I was throwing weapons and armor in the recycler despite not really needing any more parts. My overall morale was so high that I think people were happier than before the zombie apocalypse. And now I had to just pass each day until sopmething else happened. And it became a bit boring at that. So I decided to make another game where I would put myself restrictions on how much and how fast I would do things. Every day I would only go on one outing for one location only. Doesn't matter that my inventory is not even half full
voteText:
doesn't matter that I'm still at full health. It sure made the game go at a slower pace and makes it longer before I'm done with everything but I find it disapointing that I have to put myself these restrictions instead of the game making me take hard decisions on what I need now and what will have to wait later. (think X-Com for instance)

I also have other small issues with some desing decisions (like the inability to advance to clock until after everybody is done working) but again overall it is an enjoyable game with a good concept that I hope the devs will keep polishing and making better with time.

Oh and for replay value I hope one day they come up with different maps so that people who played the game don't already know where everybody is or where important things are."

reviewText:
Dead State I would say is now in my top 5 best zombie games around, even though it is still in the early stages. First would say while the game is out of Early Access, there are still quite a bit of bugs and glitches but I have not come across any game-breaking ones and the game does have an ending. But the game is still being cared for by the developers and still getting big patches and fixes every other month or so.

Now that's out of the way let's start on the game. Dead State is a survival focus RPG where you play as a created character who survives a plane crash and later wakes up in a school with other survivors. The school is your main base and so the main focus is to help build it up while also going out to find supplies and other survivors to join you. It is cool that your base does change when you build upgrades and the March patch now let's survivors roam around, giving it more life-like. The only thing I do wish is more stuff you can do in the base or also the look changes based on the survivors you recruit (mainly them bringing in personal items to decorate).

The gameplay outside the base is similar to games like Xcom or any squad based RPG. You go out with a max of four people and when you arrive at locations, you mostly just look for supplies while fighting off the undead and hostile living. A nice thing is you will have to use different tactics when fighting zombies then living, since the undead aren't as smart and can be dispatch faster. However the good thing is they keep it bit realistic in the sense that taking on one undead or two is easy, but taking on a big group can be deadly. The equipment in the game while plenty, sadly they are not random in stats like Diablo. Also many survivors you recruit will have different skills that can be useful both on and off the field.

reviewText: Dead State is clunky, buggy and slow near the end. It's also one of the best indie games I've played this year. A post-apocalyptic zombie game where fighting zombies is the least of your troubles, your task is to keep a shelter of ragtag survivors afloat. This means keeping it secure by building/maintaining your wall and posting guards. Keeping your food and water supply going by looting abandoned buildings (or unabandoned ones), building a well and gardens, and raising chickens. Trying to keep your food refrigerated (and stop your survivors from rioting) by keeping a steady supply of fuel for the generator. Dealing with the other surviving factions, either through diplomacy" or force. And so on...\n\nThere is a fair bit of combat
recommended: it's a matter of chugging through and killing everything so you can loot the map. In most cases
hoursPlayed: either your party is properly-equipped for a combat scenario (in which case you will eventually win) or it's not (in which case you will lose
voteText: probably quickly). This is a big reason the game feels slow nearing the end: you know you can kill everything
helpfulPercent: so now you need to chug through and do it. This is especially true for the zombie maps
votesHelpful: since a "hard" zombie map is just one with a lot of zombies on it. Human enemies will wipe the floor with you in the early days
votesTotal: but by the end game
votesFunny: there are only a few encounters in the game that will give you any real difficulty. Even some of the scariest-looking ones are actually quite easy with decent equipment. So it's the shelter management aspect where the game shines.\n\nIn Dead State
commentsCount: you have a great deal of control over all aspects of the shelter's management. You're not only responsible for meeting those basic needs (food/safety/electricity/morale) and assigning work duties
column16: but also internal and external diplomacy. You choose which survivors to recruit
column17: how to deal with other groups of survivors
column18: how to deal with the various cliques in your shelter
column19: and what to do about criminals and other crises. There are a lot of different ethical choices to make that don't boil down simply to "plus karma" or "minus karma" like many other games. Is it more wrong to turn away a survivor that you know is useless
column20: knowing they will die
column21: or to let them in and risk starving everyone in the end due to lack of food? What about attacking other camps for fuel to keep your shelter from falling apart? Does it matter if they are "bad guys"? What counts as a "bad guy" and are you sure you aren't one? :)\n\nAnyway

reviewText:
I recommend this game with a few reservations.

First, it's not for everyone.  The game can be very repetitive.  Managing a group of survivors and locating resources to build and feed everyone sounds fun, but what it amounts to is little more than going from one area to another, clubbing everything to death, and putting all their food/fuel/ammo in your inventory.  Then doing it over and over again.

Second, the combat is not very good.  I found it poorly paced.  There is a very basic early game, middle game, and late game, but the jumps between them seem don't transition well.  It's all based on armor, really.  Having better armor suddenly makes you immune to so much damage.  Combat pretty much boils down to doing the same thing over and over again, with very few interesting mechanics.

Third, the game is not paced well.  This goes hand-in-hand with repetitive.  There are very interesting storylines and elements, but there are large bouts of nothing followed by sudden bursts of activities, particularly close to the end where there bouts of nothing become longer and longer.  The game could use a BIT more activity/story.

With all that said, this game is interesting, fun, and contributes to the genre in a much needed way.  The devs are actually patching/making improvements, so I consider that a strong plus as well.  Some bugs remain, but they're definitely working on it, and I didn't run into any major issues (although a few annoying bugs were present).  I enjoyed leading my group through some tough situations and exploring post-apocalyptic Texas, meeting new people, and exploring a variety of environments.  There is some difficulty in building morale/food stores in the beginning, but this is actually fun and contributes to the difficulty of the game (something that is lacking at a certain point).

One final word.  The game has some political (ridiculous conservative/Texan stereotypes) elements to it.  If you're sensitive, you probably won't enjoy this game.  It was  bit heavy handed at times, to be honest.  Still, I enjoyed this game overall and would recommend IF you have a high tolerance for reading text, doing repetitive tasks, and some amount of roleplaying".  You should also
recommended: really enjoy the genre as well!"

reviewText:
Bought Dead State on sale.  Wanted to get it based on the demo and that it is squad based.  However, given the comments didnt want to pay too much.  Even in the Demo saw how annoying bugs could be.

Overall, I have to say a resounding thumbs up for the game though.  It is exactly what I wanted and hence however many hours in I am through the game I felt it fair to let others know who like me have been on the fence.  I like squad based tactics and so I am really most interested in the scenarios for getting supplies.  I like the combat and even enjoy just turning up while I fight is already going on and watching two looter groups fighting it out with each other, attracting a load of dead guys and then being overrun by them.  I then clean up and take all the loot!  Excellent fun!  I also enjoy the tricky encounters, usually where better armed looters/militia control an area and arent interested in parlaying.  Surprisingly I have also enjoyed running the shelter and developing my character in order to do that.  Admittedly the shelter begins to run itself after a time and you get so much food and luxuries that you could hold out until armageddon but it is a nice touch.  Havent got the lab yet but everything else is done.

So why wait until on sale?  It is still bugged.  It is a little annoying to see your guys walk through a locked door!  Or right through a car.  Also frustrating to not be able to get to loot which has been placed in a position that is inaccessible (rare though).  Early on (possibly demo) it was real annoying to have killed a guy taken some excellent loot only to get back to the shelter and it had gone missing and no I didnt forget to pick it up.  I think the worst faults, so far at least have been in the hotel  in Austin.  Great idea, real enjoyable combat, difficult and demanding.  But moving between floors is a real pain.  Could it not have been made a bit easier?  You will find it almost impossible to move up or down unless your players are in the right position but you cant move your players to get into that position.  Having one person in the right place should be enough then an automatic move.

If you enjoy squad based tactics (old school xcom not the new) and you woul like to try something different then this game is worth getting, you just need to work out what price you are willing to pay for it.  I got it at £14.99 and that was fine for me, under a £10 get it no questions asked.

reviewText: Early Access Review\n\nWhile this game is certainly in an early state, it seems impressive so far. The game is fairly simple for now, but there are a lot of features not currently implemented that will make the game much more complex. reviewText:
Dead State.  What really should be an indie darling hasn't quite managed to come into it's own.  Let me clarify, the game is interesting, challenging and, depending on your definition, fun.  What I would consider it's core issue is that it was built with the same engine powering Age of Decadence.  Why is this important?  Well, Age of Decadence is quite a unique style of RPG and it's engine was tailored to it.  Since Dead State is a more traditional RPG, I just don't think this engine choice has done it any favors.

Before I get into why, I must give my recommendation: If you are looking for a more classical take on zombie survival that takes its cues from a pen and paper role-playing experience, there's a good chance this one is going to be memorable to you.  And for that alone I give it a recommendation, it isn't a bad game.

So why the longer review?  Largely just because at it's core it's a budget product and that shows through in every single place you look.  Combat, for example, is fine if you imagine it like a board game (it plays like one) and use your imagination, but everything feels so static many things would be more compelling in a book: The zombie lunges for your throat!  Luckily you push it aside!"  It is a very spartan affair with a simple animation and a barebones sound effects.  While you undoubtedly get into situations that feel genuinely tense
date: it's because the premise is done very well
recommended: not because it has compelling on-screen action.\n\nThat may not bother you at all
hoursPlayed: but larger issues arise in continuity and premise.  So many things are just presented matter-of-fact and completely accepted without any involvement from the player in spite of objections.  The best example is the premise itself.  You run the shelter
voteText: you very well may be a competent leader.  However
helpfulPercent: you are just some person they rescue from a plane crash.  The shelter is already established
votesHelpful: everyone already knows each other

reviewText: Dead State is a great turn based game with a hardcore survival aspect to it. You have to recruit as many people as you can while you feed them and equip them for the hard times ahead. You also build up your base AKA the school and there are tons of upgrades for your school from a chicken coop, garage, farm and so much more. The part that most people complain about is they cant keep people happy or other stupid morale problems they may have(they lack people skillz). Just like in real life not every one you have in your town will see eye to eye about certain topics because the game is gonna throw a lot of random events at you that you need to deal with to make some people happy or even angry with you. There is perma-death if you are sloppy and get one of your guys surrounded and 3 or 4 zombies drop down on him for a quick snack you can beat he is getting back up but not as a human. Other complains I have read is that people think this is an alpha but your wrong the developers love this game and you can tell because they are always updating and fixing bugs for you. Come on they just released a nice update not to long ago and some companies would have made it a DLC but not these guys. There is also crafting, anything from armor, weapons, and even upgrades for your car once you get there. On top of that your played character is fully customizable from the way he looks to what kind of skills he/she has. You want to be a medic sure, you want to be a bad a$$ with a sledge hammer max melee skill, computers, gun skill, and a ton more. I have 86+ hours and I still haven't cleared out all of the areas on the map and even the map will throw random events at you. If you like zombies turn based hardcore survival games this will be right up your alley. This screenshot is just a taste of all the thing you have to do in 1 day to make sure sh$t doesn't hit the fan.\nhttp://images.akamai.steamusercontent.com/ugc/46505482712255338/9C4AD90CA32930F607A8FF14229CD4C93F55E3BB/\nAnd your people can only carry a certain amount of weight so deciding what items you need are crucial for your survival.

reviewText:
First things first: Just like anchovies or hot sauce, THIS GAME IS NOT FOR EVERYONE.  TRY THE DEMO BEFORE YOU BUY.  The demo will give you a good feel of whether you will like the full game.


Even though I hit the Yes
recommended: button—this is more of a mixed review. (I wish there was a middle option.)  Dead State requires deep thought and sometimes a touch of research.  There is more than one way to play—but you have to figure them out.  Although I personally liked going back to get my stats just right for my personal play style in the demo, not everyone will enjoy doing so.  This is not meant to be an easy game for those that want to just smash up some zombies for an adrenaline rush and gore fest. The game isn't something I'd recommend for the player that just wants to have some easy fun.  It is quite the opposite.\n\nThe game isn't very forgiving of mistakes and the right answer isn't simply handed to you.  Options are limited, negatives for the team are abundant and the player character is the only fully customizable ally.  You're forced to work with what you get, even the other survivors.  There is no “hone my skills to perfection by grinding first” easy button.  This game is meant to intrigue your mind and push your planning abilities.  For those hard core players that want to nitpick the details and get things just right, I'd say download the demo and dive in.  The save files even carry over from the demo.

reviewText:
Let me start with this, I have owned this game since it came out because I love the concept of it. I started playing at the initial release, but I did not get into the game because, quite frankly, I was overwhelmed by its complexity. I tried again a couple months later, but still did not get into it. I saw that the Reanimated edition was released and finally dug into the game, giving it the time it deserved. I can now say that I love this game and am 100% addicted to it!

This game is complex, difficult, and so SO rewarding. It's been said before, but this game is basically Fallout 1&2 plus X-Com plus Walking Dead. And this combo works so amazing! Sure it is not perfect, and could use a little more polish, but the game is so much more than the sum of all parts and is one of the best gaming experiences I had in years.

The negative reviews on Steam seem to all complain about the morale system and/or the bugs. I can't really speak to how the game was before the Reanimated edition, but I will say there was only 1 bug that I ran into. It was a dialogue bug that happened during a random encounter, where the guy I knocked out was talking the same text as he said when the fight started. I hit him one more time with my bat to kill him and that solved that problem... I didn't see any other bugs, which is impressive considering the scope of this game.

As far as morale... this is the end of the world! It is supposed to be difficult to keep a group together. I struggled through at first and had to make some rough choices about whether to kick people out of my group or not (which I did). But as you progress, it is possible for you to make things work. Overcoming these obstacles is so much more rewarding.  The people that complain about morale are essentially saying the game is too hard, the end of the world isn't meant to be easy and I wouldn't have it any other way.

In closing, don't let the negative reviews keep you from trying this game. At the least, download the demo and dedicate enough time to it so that you understand what this game is all about. Once you do, you will find a gem of a game that you'll love and find nearly impossible to put down.
