reviewText:
I've followed this game before I even bought it and I'm pretty happy with the content, I've played this game from beta 4 until release. There is still room for improvement and the Devs see it and will update the game as time goes on. The combat in the game is turn based, if you are careful you can avoid combat completely. The NPC interaction is what I really like, I hope they add more personal quests and crisis moments.

I'd also like to see more base upgrades and research, and interaction/events once you get the upgrades. With so many people at the base late game there should more options to allocate the survivors and missions/crisis tied to those.In the future this game could be a 10/10, right now it is a 7.5/10 for me.


***SOME POSSIBLE SPOILERS** The best moment for me so far was when I was on a scavenger mission with fresh survivors, I walked into a downtown area, it looked looted so I decided to proceed with caution. While my team was looting I decided to send one of the survivors to scout the area... and then I saw it... the park...  shards of metal everywhere and what looked like an elderly woman and a man impaled to the benches, I quickly gathered my team, but it was too late a heavily armed raider group got the drop on us. They knocked down the scout nearly killing her, I rushed the rest of my crew over to save her life. Fire, metal and blood, flew through the evening sky, my combat medic rushed over and secured the downed survivor.

Things looked like they were changing... then the boss came out. Our pistols and bats did little to slow him down, and we were surrounded.

I suddenly remembered my melee specialist was holding on to an assault rifle and my ranger happened to have the ammo, we were able to take out the raiders one by one, my melee specialist picked up a shield off a dead raider and rushed over to deflect incoming fire while the scout and medic found cover, my ranger managed to pick off the last raider, and we managed to walk away with no casualties, hardened by the experience and the new equipment.

reviewText:
A bad interface and rudimentary controls ruin what could've been an interesting game.

Inventory is hard to manage.
A person wants batteries, I found batteries... how do I give them the batteries?

I played an entire game (died) before realizing I couldn't 'use' bandages without first putting them in the medical bag.
I haven't figured out why I can't put codine in the medical bag, ... it's not full...

Why must I physically run around the shelter to perform management tasks?

Why can't I 'hold action' ... or maybe I can but the interface doesn't show it to me??

I have to wait... while the zombies ... jiggle ... at me ... ?

It's very easy to misclick, spend your action in the wrong way, and die.
Moving onto a square where a corpse is is HARD - you have to find a non-corpse pixel.

The log window shows exactly what happened ... but it is tiny.  Seriously, it holds two actions!?

Is it possible to rebind the control keys?
What are the control keys?

reviewText:
I have requested my money back on this game.  I consider it an Early Access game that requires additional work.  Reasons why it is early access:

Game Balancing issues:
Morale Penalties are crippling
It is easy to get injured, and you are out several days unable to collect food, so your team starves.
Combat is very hard - I could forgive this if there weren't the other 2 issues

Design:
This probably won't be fixed, but they really should simplify shelter management.  Manually walking everywhere is not fun.  If you had some shelter management screens instead, it would be much better.

Reason to like it:
I really love the concept.  The problem is the implementation.  Maybe a year from now, they will have a more balanced game.

reviewText:
Overall a fun game, I haven't finished it yet, but I'm at the point where there is no challenge.  It blends a few concepts well, and while I found the game overall very fun, I do have a few issues that I think keep it from being great.  I may not play it again, but I would definitely be interested in a sequel or the same concepts taken in another direction.  If you combined most of the concepts of Dead State and State of Decay into a 4x, I think it would be a very interesting game.

7/10

++Map design, can't say enough about this, it truely feels like you're living in a zombie apocalypse.  From the wrecked cars, ransacked stores and homes, trails of blood, graffiti on the walls warning of zombie inhabitants, to the somber reality that many will simply take their own lives in their houses with their loved ones.  Double bear did a great job setting the environment
++Moral choices, did a great job here.  You have several dialog choices, when I made my decision it seemed to be something I would say in that situation.  NPC's that join your shelter will remember dialog choices you've made with them and bring them up in future conversations
+Crisis and random keep it interesting, hostile human NPC's can be turned against zombies


--Game is to easy, once you get past the first few days, other humans are the only real competition.  They are easily avoided, or distracted, and you can come back later and whipe them out with better equipment
--Item durability, nothing breaks, leaving you with stacks of items and weapons.  You can recycle them in later stages for parts, but I prefer a more realistic game and would like things to break and have value
--Useless items, there's a large variety of weapons and items, but I spent 80% of the game using aluminum bats.  Zombie s would die in two hits and most humans were no problem, even if they had guns.
-Micromanagement is pretty bad starting off, but gets a little better.  It gets annoying having to run to the storeroom to swap items, the job board to assign tasks, and the exit zone of the shelter to reach the map
-Map is stagnant, no roaming hordes of humans or zombies, once you clear an area you have no reason to return
-

reviewText:
Dead State, is a great game. It uses an isometric view, turn based combat and base building/management NPC interaction system.

The plot has so far been excellent, with well written background stories for NPCs. The dialogue, and the interaction really makes you feel like you're dealing with the daily problems of life in the apocalypse. You must scavenge for supplies, repair your base, and upgrade it, But you have to deal with the people you care for as well. Keeping up moral, finding personal items they need, while assigning them tasks and job schedules around the base.

The interface at first seems abit clunky, but took me very little time to get used to it. The sound & graphics, while not cutting-edge, are done very nicely. One thing I'd really like to point out, is the areas you visit while looking for supplies or running errands. Every map area, tells a story if you look. Very impressively done, for example I was looting a local neighborhood and every house every block, you could see the damage or the carnage and piece together what happened there. A car slammed into a power-pole, the trail of blood as the driver tried to escape to a house... The door smashed, his body half devoured in the doorway ! Just little stuff like that seriously adds to the ambience, and feel of the game's setting.

I also would like to point out the leveling and skill system, is well done. You really do get the feeling that each level is really going to help you survive. You don't have to reach level X before you can survive on your own ; each of level you gain does give you the sense of accomplishment. And so far most skills, that I've gained/used have a purpose, have a use that just might keep you out of the hands of the Dead for just another day...

The bad... The game does have some bugs. I haven't really experienced anything to severe, or to frequent to prevent me from playing on. So far I crashed once, loading a save-game. Just once, and reloading the game and reloading the save went fine on the next attempt. I know there are some odd dialogue mix ups that others have had an issue with ; But so far I have not.


Over all, a well done game that is enjoyable.

Likes:

* Gameplay - it's just okay not the best or even great lets just put it - very simple.
* Content - the dialogues/script could've been improved. They should have worked on this - it would have been the selling point of the title.

Dislikes:

* Path finding issues and over simplified combat system - this could've have been made better as I said too simple (no crouching nor scaling its like playing pacman... so flat)
* Graphics and sounds - its forgiveable but yea.... I actually turn my sounds off and in windowed mode since the graphics is not the best.
* Bugs - it does load

reviewText:
Firstly, Dead State is a diamond in the rough.

Let me say that I don't relate to people who fiercely defend titles and developers where the products are incomplete or have problems.  I've seen fans who jump onboard and immediately shout down anybody who has negative criticism of the game.  I pay for (and expect) quality, and really struggle with the new era of gaming which puts the public in the chair of tester.

Having said that, I really enjoy Dead State.  A *lot*.

It was formally released early December (about a week ago), and there are still a pretty wide range of improvements that could be made to the game.  The thing is, even without them, the game is fun.  It's quite immersive .. insofar as it pulls you into the story and the concerns of your survivors.

A lot of games try to achieve immersion these days - but they have some kind of false idea of what immersion means .. making a game grindy and laborious may be exactly how it feels to chop down a tree in real life - but you soon get bored and realise it's just a game.

What Dead State throws at you is relationships and a foundation of morale and needs that drives them, and then lets you try and survive in an open sandbox in Texas.

Scavenge, deal with zombies, deal with friendly and hostile survivors, try to satisfy the needs of your community - those are the basic imperatives of the game.

People interact with you, there are branching conversations - a very significant amount of dialogue.

On the downside is that some elements feel a little unpolished.

I find the combat to be fun and tense, and the environments you nervously scavenge through to be beautifully drawn .. but the combat mechanics themselves feel a tad simple and unpolished.  People have complained about lack of stealth, cover .. and yeah, I agree - there are some of the tactical systems in the game that could use a second look.

What would that achieve ?

It would take a GREAT game and make it a WONDERFUL game.

Game is still very good in it's present state, I recommend it.

reviewText:
For those who are into zombie-apocalypse games, this game is a welcome new addition. You survive a plane crash and are taken to a shelter which you must lead. The goal of this game is simple: survive. Every day will be a struggle - there are many threats in this apocalyptic world of Splendid, Texas. Not so splendid anymore.

The game is both a Fallout-like RPG as well as a turn based management game. You are in charge of managing a shelter which means gathering food, building upgrades such as fences to keep zombies out, finding survivors who may be able to help you get to safety, and dealing with crisis events such as a gang threatening to destroy your shelter. Each survivor has different areas in which they contribute to shelter management and it's up to you to manage the resources. In addition, there are conflicts and events that happen every day and it's up to you to deal with them.

If you know Fallout's combat system, then you will know Dead State's combat. All in all the combat is relatively easy - but there are a few encounters where you will literally be in war against a small army of guys equipped with military gear and assault weapons so don't take everything for granted.

The looting can get repetitive - it's pretty much kill everything, search containers, grab as much as you can and clear area. Combat is *usually* very easy, but there are modes this game has that will make it oh so much harder. And also, be very careful of what you say to fellow survivors. It takes just one bad statement to make them absolutely hate you. But this is a stressful time, after all. There's an achievement for rescuing all the survivors - some found randomly.

All in all, it's a good game, and I recommend it. 7.5/10.

reviewText:
This is one of my favorite games. I love what they did here with their approach to survivor management. So much fun to recruit, utilize, and manage so many personalities. The conflict and the factions set up throughout the game kept me engaged and wanting more.

Admittedly, there's far too much combat that gets far too repetitive over time and the inventory management is a complete drag once you have seen all of the item variations a few times. Playing in iron mode is cool in concept, but this game is far too long for me to risk losing all of my progress based on a few bad rolls. If consequences were less immediately dire or potentially game ending, I'd hop on it in a second. I was fine with losing some people through story events or even in combat late in the game once it was clear that I'd be able to finish it. The ending was disappointingly sparse on how the characters made out, but the journey there was well worth while to engage with them on the way.

Crazy fun. Want more.

reviewText:
Dead State is... Let us say, a strangely designed game. When you start to play it, for the first few hours, it is very interesting and engaging, if you, like me, can disregard very outdated graphics, somewhat clumsy interface and occasional bugs.

At first, survival feels really hard. Every day, yout scavenging party goes out to find food and fuel, and usually can just about bring enough of both back to prevent Shelter from dying outright, but not enough to feel safe. It's a real struggle and it feels interesting. Even more interesting are dialogues with your fellow survivours.

Unfortunately, it seems that time or other constraints prevented DoubleBear team from really completing this product. When you finally find horses that allow for faster travel (and, therefore, for two expeditions per day!), you beging to gather more food than strictly necessary for survival. At this point, the second part of the game should begin, but it doesn't. Most of the important events are tied only to day number, not your actions. And since survival is no longer a day-to-day concern, you start to feel bored from clearing same-looking supermarkets, houses and camps.

The problem is compounded by many bugs in many scripts. People do not notice completed quests (thankfully, this mostly goes only for minor tasks). People disregard events that already happened. People give you information about locations you have already visited. The worst moment, however, came when one game faction reportedly wiped another, but when I came to their old site, they were there, along with a duplicate of character that came to Shelter with the news of disaster!

The ending, when it comes, seems rarther aburpt. There are a number of endings, some of them more anti-climactic than others, but I must say I'm not very satisfied with them.

A few words about combat. It's not particulary good, but it's not particulary bad, either. The dead stop being a serious threat quite soon, but armed people remain a problem nearly to the very end, especially in large numbers. AI is bad, but it doesn't matter too much. (And at least it's better than in JA: Flashback). I'd say the combat is on the par with Wasteland 2, which is not saying much, but it's not awful.

Despite everything, I had fun with this game. I liked exploration and texts, even when they were bugged.  I wouldn not recommend it for everybody, though. You have to be tolerant of crashes (fortunately, quicksave is VERY quick!) and bad graphics. Still, I feel like a lot of love was put into it, and it shows, even if the end product is somewhat mishappen.

I'd say you should wait for patches, but so far there was only one, and with the number of crashes, I'd expect the developers would try to hurry with fixing at least a few of them, so I do not have high hopes. Still, even with all the bugs, I managed to finish the game, so at least it's better in that respect than pre-patch Arcanum was :)

Dead State can best be described as Walking Dead Meets Fallout. With Brian Mitsoda of Vampire The Masquerade, this story driven game will let you decide if you are either a LaMOE or a Crusoe in this zombie shelter game.

The story takes place shortly after you wake up in the middle of a world that has gone to hell in Texas. After the cops found you and stitched you up along with two other survivors. You are tasked with at first making sure the shelter doesn't fall apart and take responsibility for the people that you choose to bring into the Shelter and make sure they have enough fuel, food and parts to get through each day in one piece.

As a zombie shelter game, there is notably less railroad" situations where you will ineveitably lose allies. Theoretically you can end the game with every survivor alive and well when you finish the game unlike in State of Decay which ineveitably have you lose people to the zombies wherever you like it or not. That said
date: it's freeform so you can choose to be the few beacons of hope in a bleak genre or choose to bring out the worst in humanity as you kill those that are useless. Leave survivors to die or do internal purges after a mutiny by sending any member who was loyal to the mutineer to a suicidal march.\n\nCombat wise the game plays like Fallout and Wasteland

reviewText:
I've put a lot of time in on this game, I was one of the kick starter backers who wanted to believe but was soemwhat jaded on the promised returns even at that time.

The Truth: This is an old school isometric RPG and is faithful to that lineage. It is hard as balls (unless you want to save scum) it's not terribly intuitive to start,  and the graphics evoke a very specific little bit dated" style.

Now with all that said
date:
if you are the sort of person that has fond memories of about fallout 1 and 2. The Baldur's gate series and a host of others in that game you are going to like it. You've been weened on hardship and know how to savor when things finally come together after the sting of perhaps some very bitter defeats.

The Good: The game is a faithful re-imagining of old school iso RPG's. Yes it trades on a lot of nostalgia but there is also a lot of solid game play and interaction here. There is a wealth of stuff to explore  and characters to balance out and it feels like you have quite a bit of freedom to grow. You can pour hours into this game and have extremely knife edge victories against serious odds. The crisis events and other things pressed on you are interesting and add a definite personality management aspect.

The bad: The games interface is clunky
recommended: inventory management is a PITA (pro-tip you can manage ally inventory fromt he main shelter inventory
hoursPlayed: not just your own). Likewise it really really needed a means to check an ally's overall stats from the main shelter screen. I suspect this was an intentional design decision but it hurts the game more then it helps my immersion. Poor combat scaling: Don't get me wrong I like that if you bring a knife to a gun fight you'll get your butt kicked but on the other hand melee feels really under whelming even when you've crossed the distance through the hail of gun fire. Conversely guns start out awesome and just stay that way sans noise and ammo concerns. Lastly the game really really needs (and at least thus far I havn't found) some sort of trading mechanic to get goods you need for stuff you have a surplus of. I've got arrows

reviewText:
Dead State often gets compared to Fallout but I think that's unfair to both games. It doesn't have Fallout's dark humour or intricate combat system but what it does have is a fairly complex shelter management simulator. Basically the game is about managing your squad, your resources, your shelter upgrades, and all the survivors who are working in the shelter when you go on scavenging runs (including the shelters overall morale and each survivor's individual mood).

A fairer comparisson would be State of Decay or Jagged Alliance 2 (the original). The game isn't about your character surviving in a post apocolyptic world but about a group trying to scrape by in one. The turn based tactical battles are not an end in themselves, they're mearly a way to get more food, fuel, parts and medicine so your shelter can survive longer. Your character levels up but you have no personal goals: it's all about keeping the others happy, alive and away from each other's throats.

If you liked State of Decay (but thought it'd be better as a turn based strategy) or loved Jagged Alliance 2 (but wished it had zombies) then this could very well be the game for you.

reviewText:
Dead State is a survival/horror RPG with strong base-building elements set in the zombie apocalypse. (Think Fallout Tactics but open-ended with a strategic/resource management layer). As the elected leader of a small group of survivors, you must go on runs for supplies, locate and rescue other survivors, allocate resources and gradually build up your shelter from a bare-bones school into a fortified complex. You must constantly deal with not only the hordes of walking dead, but perhaps more importantly, the living, who in many cases are even more dangerous.

Everyone you find has their own story, their own motivations, priorities, and attitude towards life and what is happening out in the world. As your shelter and group grows in size and reputation, people will eventually begin coming to you, leaving you with a choice as to how to deal with them. Letting in everyone may seem like a good idea, but eventually you will have to deal with the personality conflicts that arise between certain members of your group. Threats to your survival will arise both from the outside and from inside the shelter itself, forcing you to make tough, black-or-white decisions about how to deal with them. Food shortages, supply shortages, morale problems, and epidemics of disease are daily specters. Do a bad job in dealing with these issues, and other strong-willed members of the group may decide to challenge your leadership, putting you at risk of being thrown out of your own shelter.

Combat is squad-based, turn-based, and tactical. Traveling to any of the game's many scattered locations to scavenge for supplies invariably results in hostile encounters with the both walking dead and rival groups of hostile scavengers or survivors. Each member of your group has a specific set of skills that may make them suitable as a melee fighter, ranged combatant, or combat medic, and it is up to you to equip and assemble your squad with those things in mind, using whatever weapons, armor, equipment and medical supplies you have managed to scrounge or manufacture. The pros and cons of various weapons and armor, the layout of external obstacles and the internals of buildings, and proper noise management all play into getting your scavenging team in and out of dangerous situations alive and, hopefully, with backpacks full of badly-needed loot.

The game does have some interface and gameplay issues, and there have been alot of reports from users about crashes as well as glitches and bugs ranging from annoying to game-breaking throughout the game's release history. Personally, at 60 hours/50 game days in, I have not encountered anything more than a few minor glitches that, while annoying, have not seriously impacted my gameplay, in addition to a few isolated crashes. Luckily, the devs wisely included an automated bug-reporting tool with the full game that will allow you to notify them whenever there is a crash. I would advise anyone who buys the game to backup your save files just in case something catastrophic happens. I will admit that the game could use a few more updates, in my opinion, but more in terms of things to be added or modified rather than fixed outright. Overall I feel that the basic mechanics of the game are solid, providing a compelling and realistic simulation of trying to lead a group of survivors through the zombie apocalypse. I definitely recommend it to anyone who enjoys open-ended RPGs or turn-based strategy games.

reviewText: Become the leader of a small group of survivors during the zombie apocalypse! Manage your base (allies, materials, shelter improvement, etc) while exploring places around you to find more resources and survivors. Exploration and combat is like in the old school turn based tactical games (well done and challenging in my opinion, must pay very much attention every single step against zombies and other survivors).  In my opinion a very good and entertaining game if you like (i) zombies (ii) turn based combat (iii) resource management. Single player only but very rewarding gaming experience.

reviewText:
Now it's been sometime, I'm posting a new review in place of the old one back when it was still in Early Access.

I've been very interested in this project since it first appeared on Greenlight and have been following it's progress. It's a turn-based zombie survival game where you manage a shelter and have to deal with many harsh situations that may happen based on the survivors you have as not every survivor is as steady minded as you could imagine. Some look for love in the wrong place, others are mentally disturbed (due to what has happened and the situation you are in now) and you can even recruit animals to the shelter which give their own moral bonus, but also eat into your food supplies too.

All the characters in the shelter have their own personalities. Some can even point out new locations where there would be a large storage of weapons or food based on their life before the disaster struck. Some can be very likable like the Loving and helpful Renee or others will be blunt and emotionless like the officer, Vic. There are multiple endings and hours of replayability with the many different dialog trees. I have not yet completed the game, but I have gotten far into it and built everything in the shelter, of course trying to gain enough food and fuel on each excersion to keep moral up becomes difficult with more people.

Now I'm not going to say the game is perfect. There are still bugs in the game and issues where bodies will share the same square, however the dev team are still working on this game and want to make it the best experience for all of those like me who are craving for a zombie survival game where you are responsible for the survivors and all the survivors have varied and interesting personalities.

If you are still uncertain, I'd suggest playing the demo to get a good feel for it. It has that wonderfully nostalgic feel of Fallout 1 + 2 as well as Wasteland.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

I Love This Game! It's perfectly balanced with script and action figures.

Further improvements that i want to see,

Random encounters should be arrange as same areas with different and respawnable enemy/loot seeds. I don't want to enter same area that i already entered and killed/looted everything in it. This would improve the immersion beyond the main story line and specific locations that have names.

Adding some events that may occur repeatedly could be totally awesome. You encounter crisis in the game as the time flows and you achive some main situations.  Adding random 'minor' events could give the player more challange and also i would love to have meetings about daily problems.

I often use mods when i finish the vanilla. It's refreshing, so maybe it would be good to have mod friendly game mechanics?

Did i say I Love This Game?

reviewText:
I only played Reanimated, following my usual rules of giving games at least 6 months after release to solve the main problems. I finished the game, fairly completely, maybe missing 2 or 3 characters due to time, and I also saw two of the possible, positive endings. As an experience, one of the best games I've played in a long time, coming close to the original JA2 experience and surpassing it in certain places. Played on highest difficulty levels, but not iron man (I have a job and a family...;-))

Pros:

For this gaming genre, a very refeshing theme.
Early game captures the survival aspects well, with shortages of people, food and equipment.
Interactions between characters are quite deep, with serious and not obvious consequences to your actions. The game is not afraid of serious issues and does not give easy answers.
Zombies behave like zombies in combat...be careful and quiet, and they are easy kills.
Writing is very good - I especially enjoyed the final discussions after one of the endings, and the little touches from the characters.
Combat is fun, and you feel a strong progression in skill as your stats and weapons improve. Humans are a significant challenge early game, with military almost overwhelming, but only difficult in large numbers at the end.
Lots of easter eggs! The RPG codex was a highlight...
Cons:

The base building aspect is over by about halfway through the game. I would like to see many more options here, as even the weapon options are not that interesting.
I am not sure if I missed something, but several directions seem to be undeveloped, particularly related to some of the skills people have. There were some very interesting possibilities sugggested and an obvious ending or two absent.
Still a few bugs in the quests, especially when you do them out of order.
Even at the highest level, infection is too rare. Having more infections, but with the possibility of cures or longer term suppression would have balanced it better.
You must take your own character on missions. This makes a combat build important early on.
A great pity that an unfortunate early release and negative feedback seems to have killed future games.

reviewText: I haven't played for too long and while I will agree with most that this game has potential I'm starting to wish I had saved my money.  Combat is already getting REALLY repetitive whether it be bandits or zombies.  Equipment and inventory is a hassle and I can't believe it's as interface unfriendly as it is.  The shelter just has people standing around even if you assign them jobs and nothing really feels alive.  All of these complaints may seem mundane but when they add up it feels like a game that slowly lulls me to sleep or frustrates me.  If it was $10 i'd say sure but for $30... I feel let down, especially with all the die hard reviews saying this was good but it feels too much like an old game with half the personality.\n\nI remember playing Baldurs Gate 1 and 2 and even Fallout 2 and was blown away at the time by the story telling.  Not only does Baldurs Gate 2 look better than this and that's a title that's MUCH older, but it's less buggy and the world felt more developed.  I put in many hours just to get my moneys worth but I believe DoubleBear rushed this and dupped people into buying an incomplete game which was vastly overpriced.  Sorry DoubleBear, I know some Devs on your team put their hearts out into this, but when it all adds up it just wasn't worth it.

reviewText:
RIP Dead State killed by the Dead State Reanimated update, died way to early in its life. It will be missed!


My true first Negative review.
This is one of the worst days of my life.
I followed this game since it was first announced or hinted about.
I pre-ordered it as soon as the ability came up.
I then I started playing it on steam.
I was happy but was looking for more from this game.
Then came out the Reanimated update which basiclly destroyed the game for me.
Zombies weren't zombies anymore in my opinion but more like the infected from 28 days later in my opinion.
No more sneaking up and getting in the first attack / beginning of the combat phase with an attack to the back of a zombie.
The claim this was to increase the difficulty is the lamest claim I have ever seen for a game.
From every post I read the biggest issue that I have seen is the fact that you could become nearly invincible to zombies at a point in the game.
That there im torn between, I like it because thats just human nature at the same time takes away from the game itself.
A simple answer, give zombies the random % chance of penetrating the defense / armor class of the victim instead of this detection crap they currently use.
Even the recent posts since the Reanimated update declare the change really hasn't changed much other than making the beginning that little more difficult.
It also destroys the immersion in the game for me and by posts several other people as well.
If they put an option to turn it on / off would resolve this issue for me.


This was once a dream and now its a nightmare from which a new dream is waiting to be discovered to replace the current nightmare of Dead State Reanimated.

reviewText:
Many of the other reviews have already said it: the game is more chore than fun--and that's further reinforced by a clunky UI and stale writing (not bad, mind you, just stale).

Combat--which might be expected to be the highlight--is generally dull and poorly balanced (on hardcore at least) with zombies/looters almost invariably sensing you from behind, with no stealth emchanism to sneak up on them effectively--and then even with a three-on-one in close combat the very real chance one of your members will take serious damage, as you whiff far too often from point blank range. Combine this with the sparse mechanics, like the noise level, which is poorly explained/clumsily executed (compare with Invisible Inc's alarm meter, or Thief's noise gem, both of which clearly and intuitively provide information while being stylistically coherent inside the game world) and you get a scenario where you can neither effectively sneak around and loot nor effectively tactically engage foes.

Base building and management suffer from an abundance of materials as opposed to a scarcity (not necessarily a problem, in and of itself), but it gives more of an impression of inventory management and 'finding x item to keep y character happy' as opposed to a struggle to survive, quickly lapsing into tedium,

Sadly, like so many other turn-based games of the same ilk, Jagged Alliance 2 came along over a decade ago and set the high watermark that so very, very many of these games have broken themselves against over the years. Kudos for the effort, but zombie games aren't exactly a scarce genre, and many of the others, from low-fi indie gems like Rogue Survivor or Neo Survivor, through mid-rangers like 7 Days to Die, all the way to high-gloss AAAs like Dying Light, pick aspects and do them better.

I don't think this is a 'bad' game, and I applaud the devs for the effort, but I'm really not motivated to play something this tedious when there's already a definite feeling that rewards for the invested time will be minimal.

reviewText:
Dead state the game with potential that just simply falls short.

When i first saw this game i thought it would be a great game with micromanagable features to make everyones experience different and in a way it is but there is so much that is missing in this game to make it really great.

First of all if you are buying this game hoping for a breeze then you are FAR FROM IT. This game is challenging. Not just challenging but almost unplayable at points due to the general difficulty right from the start. Now i played this on its base difficulty with no \iron man" or "survivor" options enabled and this game is still ridiculously hard.

Don't get me wrong. I love a good challenging game
date:
it makes me feel alive and puts me to the test. But this game takes it way too far as after a good 9 hours gameplay i still feel so weak against everything. I had 3 fully equiped survivors out on a mission but we got stuck in a room and only one could fight at a time meaning that the endless horde of zombies waiting very politely outside the door ended up getting the better of me ONE BY ONE.

Not only is it hard when it is supposed to be but the features it lacks makes it even more fustrating. Want your guys to take cover behind an obstacle to avoid missle fire? Nope. Want to climb on top of a nearby building to escape a zombie horde? Nope. Want to simply trade an item within your shelter to a friendly survivor? Nope.

These are just many of the infuriating events that can occur to you and happened to me basically every event. However this game isn't all bad. If you feel inclined to challenge yourself to the point you regretably put a hole through your monitor than be my guest because this game has so much to it and can be so much more. I just think that for a "survival strategy" there has to be some element of strategy other than just luck and using the right weapon.

Unfortunately the good outweighs the bad for this one so i simply can't recommend :("

reviewText:
This is game has great gameplay, but still a bit buggy.

I love the mix of turn-based strategy combat, base-building, character recruitment, and survival elements. I don't like the frequent crashes to desktop.

I'm confident that they will continue to squash the bugs and make the game more stable, and once they do, a really addicting (and stable) game will remain.

Overall, I recommend the game, with the caveat that you should avoid playing in ironman mode so you can save frequently to mitigate the crashes.

reviewText:
This game proves once again — to make an immersive game there's no need to have an AAA-game engine. The most important thing is the story. Here you have the Dead State, where story unfolds before your eyes, and you really feel how you become a new leader of a small community during apocalypse. Yes, most dialogues become repetative soon, but in the mornings you always have some situations happening, and you need to make decisions which affect your gameplay.

You need to keep your small society happy, fed and safe; you may set tasks on job boards, and recent game update made it so that NPCs are actually animated basically, and it adds some immersion too.

Pros:
- Interesting random situations, good decision-making game
- A great mix of Fallout/Wasteland2/Fallout Tactics/XCOM and even... The Sims :) Turn-based combat and real-time movement, when time is running only when you want it to run, makes gameplay run smoothly, at your own preferred pace.
- Good dialogues, not very short, and not too long — you won't get bored reading them
- Immersion is great

Cons:
- Some repetativeness in NPC dialogues
- Some UI issues
- I had couple of glitches and CTDs while I was playing, but fortunately there's a quicksave and autosave function
- Background music is great, but it is repetative


Future suggestions, although the game is in it's final state, I see that devs still actually change some things:
- It would be great if there was some voiceacting involved :)
- More randomness to the radio? Dynamic news?
- Ability to send additional scavenge parties without the leader?
- Loot balance? I'm on my day 31st now, still can't find any DVDs for recreation room, while I have lots of DVD players :)

reviewText: Pretty good survial zombie game. Moral dilemmas and keeping your community alive are the main challenges of this rpg. reviewText: Great little gem, the graphics aren't impressive and the UI looks a little bland but don't let them fool you, the game itself is very good, you get to explore a dead world, face hostile survivors, avoid (if you want) to kill innocent ones, even if they are rather aggressive and manage your shelter by building upgrades, negotiating with the people inside, dealing with the forming factions, listening to requests and making decisions. reviewText: As a diehard Fallout 1,2 and Tactics and State of Decay fan I was immediately pulled into this game. It took a little getting used to, but once you pick it up it is immense fun. I know previous releases have been buggy and there was some negative comment removal issues, but I was fortunate enough to pick up the Reanimated edition so I've only experienced one bug so far on 4 different playthroughs.\n\nThe gameplay is slow. It's not a zombie slasher/shooter although there certaintly is plenty of turn-based head crushing. This is a game for those who want to manage a group of survivors through the zombie apocolypse ala Rick Grimes style. The characters are well written, the conflicts are dramatic and well thought out. You get attached to some characters while others you may have to leave behind and others you'll wish you had. A must have for dark, mature themed tactical fans and open minded zombie genre nuts.

reviewText:
If Fallout 2 and State of Decay had a ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥ child, this would be it.

Edit:  Seriously, this is a very good game.  The plot can be gripping if you allow it to be.  The characters have personality and they can get on your nerves, but if you want to keep them [you do want to, you need their skills and manpower] you'll have to placate them.  It's not impossible to make everyone happy, but it does require some effort.

The turn based combat is a lot of fun, even given how much of it there can be it never really came off as tedious to me.  There are even a few situations where you can manipulate the undead to help you in wearing down some enemies for you to swoop in for the kill.

The story and atmosphere are immersive and it's was easy enough for me to lose myself in the game, especially if you have a favorite character personaily or concept to role play with.

I most certainly endorse and would recommend this game.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

Game delivers exactly what it promised: Team-based, 3/4 tactical zombie survival / base management in open world environment. There's a lot to sink your teeth into with this one. Basically you lead this bunch of survivors and every morning you get a quick briefing of things / place to explore before setting them to work and you and your scavenging party set out to find some resources to survive another day.

Throughout your travels you'll come across other survivors, some good, some not so much. But its you against the zeds so every live body helps. There's lots to explore and different modes of travel, and the shelter will requires lots of upgrades to turn it into a haven amongst all the chaos around you. There are items you need to collect to improve survivor's morale throughout your travels, in turn they will give you advice and mark locations on your map for you to explore. The overland map presents lots of random encounters during your travels, some good, some bad.

The shelter is what it's all about. You are constantly struggling with the other survivors to turn this little elementary school into a bonafide ZA haven. And it has all the ability to do it, with 2 floors and multiple rooms you will have everything you and your survivors will need to survive the nights of Splendid if you plan accordingly.

Combat starts off appearing simple but as you get more followers and more weapons you can then start to have very tactical battles, with different status effects and AOE biological weapons to help keep the battle in your favor, making impossible-looking battles into 3-round wipe ups if you're careful. Both ranged and melee are viable (I stick to melee, this is a ZA)

The maps run from classic overrun parks and hospitals, to dark scenes of lost hope, to some really...unique scenarios that I wouldnt have expected. Games like these are what makes all the risk of joining an EA worthwhile. Would highly recommend.

reviewText:
This is a very interesting game, I can only give it a so-so rating.

The graphics, it's pretty lowgrade and very cartoonie. So if you are big on visuals than look elsewhere.

The idea behind the game is very good. Set in a zombie end world scenario, you are a survivor trying to survive day to day by collecting resources and gathering npc party members in a stronghold. You character is fully customizable in terms of skills and stats. The NPCs are not, only a few choices in game on which way they will specialize, but those of use played Baulder's Gate and some RPGs this is a minor inconvinience.

The game play is not bad, u have to manage ur shelter/stronghold. Collecting, gathering, or fishing for supplies day after day to keep everyone fed and fuel for the generator so you have electricity. You need electricity for alot of functions in your shelter so it's best to keep the fuel stockpile full. Meds and other supplies also is needed for the shelter. The constant threat of hunger, low meds, and lack of fuel keeps you running out to grab more and explore more. This is very good part of the game and keeps the days rolling.

The Combat is very basic, i mean it in a bad way. no cover system or anything. extreme linear movement in a square grid system, firearms have very little range and there is preciously little ammo making using guns frustrating. Also gun fire or loud noise attracts random zombies, they spawn at edge of map and walk towards the sounds, it's a good idea but then it's really lame because only 1 zombie come, well per noise meter raised. Sometimes they dont come at all, i mean there should be some indication or more zombies. It's very frustrating you cant take cover behind a stone pillar or  a tree or the corner of the house and you see the enemy shoot right through obsticles. So combat in this game is pretty terrible. Im comparing to earlier games like wasteland 2 or xcom. This needs work.

Story is very good and there are unexpected turns, you can't keep everyone happy is the underline theme.

So in this state I cannot recommend the game because I simply dread combat everytime i runinto it and it's every few minuts while scavenging. I get so bored.

reviewText:
*Disclaimer: I know one of the artists as an internet friend*

This is a wonderfully difficult game that seriously makes you think about your decisions. Unlike a lot of other games that are in this thread you gain exp by completing tasks, not killing zombies. Knowing that turns the game into a huge puzzle that given some time you can work your way through with minimal causalties. Be prepared to want to restart a couple times because if you don't pay attention and miss something important you will likely end up dead. My biggest advice is to PAY ATTENTION!

Having played through Vampire The Masquerade: Bloodlines I enjoy Brian Mitsoda's work, and as the head writer on the project expect some in depth, thought raising dialogue. I would seriously play throguh just for the work he was able to do with this.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

After played this game for about 6 hours, I can say that it is absolutely worth buying.
Even it's an early access title, you can see already the main mechanics the game provides.
The setting is well choosen and has good overall atmosphere.
Having reached the middle of the demo (after 2-3 hours of gameplay) the game starts getting real addicted.
The random encounters make the game even more a thrill as you never know who you cross when returning to the base after a successful looting day.
You will have even the possibility to take decisions which will impact the storyline and so give you more than one way to play the game.
The fact that noise attracts the zombies and enemys around is giving a tactical benefit to the game as you need to decide how to take down the different kind of enemys.

I would recommend this game to all the fans of the old Jagged Alliance series and Turn-Based-Tactical-Shooters out there.

reviewText:
A good zombie story really isn't about the zombies and here is a good zombie game that also really is not about the zombies. Lead survivors, manage a shelter, and discover how quickly you start to resent less useful survivors when you have to go out daily to get food and gas to keep everyone feed and happy.

Very happy I backed this on Kickstarter and greatly anticapting the full release.

...Post release and post December Patches...

Now out of Early Access I would still happily recommend this game to fans of turn-based games. Light RPG system with light base building/managment involved. I wish the RPG aspects were deeper but the game is still very enjoyable and quite engaging.

I personally have not had many bug issues. Only seen a couple bugs myself and they did not caused a crash or even stop gameplay.

reviewText: This game could have been one of the best ever. It has flaws typical of a low budget, indie production, despite that I couldnt stop playing. I don't like the game engine to be honest, the graphics/textures are not that good, but at the same time it has little nice details like seeing what you equip. The management part is very nice and so are most of the dialogues but it's the combat that'll take most of your time. It could be better with something like an overwatch system, a real initiative system, STEALTH... No it's mostly random misses and avoiding agro. With better combat this game had a formula to surpass XCom! But don't get me wrong, it's still awesome to go scavenge for goods and see looters run into zombies!\nThe tutorials are too short, and I was googling alot of details, had no problems but a more casual player can feel in the dark about some things. Though it's a game that its clearly worth a try.

reviewText:
So far, the game is LONG and HARD. Straight off the bat, you'll be hit with a minus ## in morale - don't worry, just keep going out and try your BEST not to get your guys KO'ed. If you see a red skull show up next to a character, HIGHLY SUGGEST that you reload (game autosaves everytime you enter and leave an area) - red skull means infected and will NEVER go away.

Love the tactics that can be used in the game, tons of loot EVERYWHERE, there's quite a bit of realism, like the hacking mechanic in the game, and though annoying, panic and horror does make battles harder or easier (depends on which side gets hit by those run for your life!!" character freak outs).

Pros:
- Dead State uses a REAL map from Texas (the only area that seems made up is "Splendid") for the game map.
- Lots of different types of enemies.
- Sound alerting the undead/infected is a plus for realism.
- Large number of built upgrades (as well as equipment modifications).
- Unlike a lot of zombie games
date: there are TONS of recruit-able allies.\n- There's a vote system (once Vic gets back).\n- Can pick lock doors
hoursPlayed:
or simply kick the door in.
- And a powerful yet unstable psycho character can join you (sad when I lost him).

Cons: (a lot need correcting and fixing)
- Typos and spelling errors EVERYWHERE!
- Tutorial mentions that you can sneak up on enemies (FALSE).
- Animals and Crawling infected are far more likely to KO player than those standing up! (WTF?)
- Feeling of being forced to build places (allies want it

reviewText:
-I won't lie the game have issue at the moment,Nothing game breaking but still annoying.If you hate game with bug wait for patch to fix them.

Dead state is  INDIE game where YOU get to lead a group of survivor in the zombie apocalypse/survival RPG(the words zombie will never be mention in this game.)Get food, gun and other useful item while you walk trouth the ruin of post-apocalype Texas with your band of survivor Hoping to see the light who make you safe once again....
....Or the the flash from a gun right in your face.

Dead State is RPG tbs(turn base system) with is more closed to the original fallout 1 or 2, Than a tactical turn base combat like x-com or even xenonaut(Meaning that you can't crouch or take cover behind object) but still offer trustful combat situation with is allies who react diferent from one to a another toc ombat or even.

greath amount of event that will occur durent the game

reviewText:
I am edditing my review, I want to be heard and since my Fierhorn79 account is banned and my super old Fierhorn account was perm banned by steam at the request of Doublebear for ban evasion. *The Highlighted Review Below*
(Brian's DoubleBear statement) http://steamcommunity.com/app/239840/discussions/0/627456359689053892/
My reply to Brian and Dead State Devs
I wanted to take a minute to both defend myself and address Brian and Annie Mitsoda's statements.
When I saw that Brian Mitsoda made a response it gave me hope that he and DoubleBear would address that main reason for my review not just the fact that the Review was wrongfully flagged by someone at Doublebear and then continue into a rant trying to discredit me. That main concern being the business decision to move a game from Early Access to full release during the Steam holiday season. The game on the release date had a long list of known bugs, several of them either game or story breaking. Yes there have been patches and some of the bugs have been fixed, but this does not cancel out they original concern. The choice that was made looks like Doublebear tried to trick gamers into buying a game thinking it was finished when in fact by DoubleBears own known issues list on the day of release it was not done. I and now I think others feel that a company should be held accountable for these type of actions.
I have never asked for an extreme punishment, all I expected was for Doublebear to say what was going on to cause them to do this and to issue an apology to their loyal fans. Is open communication too much to ask for from the people who funded your game. Instead of dealing with my concerns directly Developers and mods have tried to silence myself and others.
This game would not be a reality without people like me with our little 30 dollars. The attitude that I have seen from DoubleBear has come off at entitled and ungrateful for the opportunity that has been given to them.
Now onto less important stuff. My defense.
First of I want to say I was deeply offended by Annie Mitsoda's personal attacks on me on tumblr. Being called a @ickbag & #ucker was far less offensive than the way she disregards my 30 dollars. Just so you know that 30 bucks is three hours of my work day. I might be nothing to you but I put my hard earned money towards your dream.
http://imgur.com/p97JvCI
http://murderblonde.tumblr.com/post/105832304380/exhaustion
Brain and friends at DoubleBear continue to claim I engaged in abusive comments towards both the devs and mods" and this is why threads were locked and deleted. This is not the case
date: I as well never harassed anyone. They can't provide screen shot of where I did any of the things they claim because they did not happen. What screen shots of locked and deleted threads they do show are just snippets without showing what anyone else is say. I was never off topic
hoursPlayed:
never directly attacked anyone. The claim that I harassed DoubleBear requesting a public apology be given to the community is just absurd. I was the only one on any of these forums to get banned when there were people making direct personal attacks on me that were defending the developers that were not even given a warning by the DoubleBear mods.
1)First thread was shut down for no good reason.
2)Second one I thought maybe they shut it down because the attacks on me. I knew I did not break the rules so I made another post pasting most of the OP and then adding another paragraph to make it new. This was right away shut down.
3)Third post was a little snarky post about how they shut down post that are on the top that are critical.
4)Fourth post was actually made by another person. This is the one I got banned in and I did nothing except ask Brian to say sorry. Never broke a forum rule once. No warning just a ban. Yes you will notice #114 &115 are back to back but that is only because the I did not copy the second part over from my wordpad. You will notice that there are several posts in between #115 and my next post. Too bad the devs only provide what I say in a attempt to manipulate the way this looks.
http://imgur.com/tjdBGs9
http://imgur.com/Tj84fUi
5)I by this point was not happy. I felt like an American being silenced and someone who my 30 bucks and support was being treated like trash. I contacted the mod(Caidoz) through a private ban email. Its funny how they just provide one snippet of the conversation and deleted the email from my account so I can't provide a picture. Yes I did say I can just create tons of alt account in this private chat. I wanted Caidoz to know his ability to silence had no power over me. I never once said I was going to abuse this and mass spam threads or upvote my own review. First of the time and money it would take to get 300 accounts is ridiculous.
http://imgur.com/l0XxiVX
I have had this alt account for 6+ years and I did not use it until now to defend myself after many attacks.
So with all the above being said I am a forgiving gamer. If DoubleBear publicly apologies for the early release and explains why they did it then I think everyone should forgive and get behind this company to help them finish what I think will be a great game when complete. On a personal note I think Brian and Annie Mitsoda's own me a private apology for the slander and attacks personally against me.
Fierhorn79
**********************************Review**********************************
Wanted to start off by saying I was a huge supporter of this game pre Steam Early Access and during early access. I enjoyed beta testing the game for DoubleBear and helping them to use the EA process to better the game.
I think the game is a blast even in its frustrating buggy state.
Now onto the reason why I think people should not buy this game or support the company DoubleBear for any future games until the Give a public apology.
I don't know about all of you but I found Kickstarter and Steam Early Access to be a wonderful breath of fresh air. I was sick of big AAA and medium sized AA Developers and Publishers pushing out 3/4 made buggy games that after I paid full price for had to wait months before it was patched up and enjoyable. This was the norm and I was sick of it.
So I started supporting only EA and Kickstarter games

more than I could afford at times. Dead State is one of those games and I was very happy to support Doublebear.
Sadly DoubleBear betrayed its fans and sought to deceive new buyers into believing that Dead State was a finished product in order to take full advantage of the Holiday shopping season. Brian and the Dead State team had pages of known bugs and some of them were game and story breaking.

We the gamers are there Publisher and we were not on their backs pushing them to release the game in a unfinished state in order to reap the profit from the Holiday season.
My over all point is that when small gamer funded games pull the same fast one as big AAA developers something has to be done about it. This type of behavior and not be rewarded.
These type of actions corrupt the new system from within. If this is allowed to happen then we get get a bunch of small studios acting just like the AAA ones because they can.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

Okay, so I'd be one of the first gamers to tell you that I do not buy early access games, even if i really want to play it, i dont want to ruin the finished product for myself. Well this game changed that for me. Specifically, it was reading reviews from people hailing how awesome the game was with over 500 hours logged into this game - an early access game with that many hours clocked in by one person really grabbed my attention.

So, going out on a limb i decided to get this game - figuring hey, I'll at least get access to the full version when it comes out, and probably cheaper than if i waited.

A good choice, I think. Now I only just started playing the game, but holy crap is it addicting as all hell!

So, to start, the main gameplay of this game is a turn based RPG, much like Fallout 1 and 2 (hell even the UI is layed out the same for the most part), except you have a party of 4 that you take out on ventures with you. But the game is so much more than that.
The travelling around and fighting is actually a small part of this game. The core of the game is that you're basically the leader of a Zombie apocalypse team that found themselves barricaded in a School. The school is your base, and you can upgrade the base with tons of different things, like a better fence, a workshop, a garage for fixing and building cars, and so much more.

So how it works, is the game day starts at 8 am, and you got free roam of your school. You can go around talking to your team members, ask them about their attitude and certain things they'd like you to grab them from the field such as soap, or chocolate or what have you (getting these items for them will increase their morale, which plays a huge part in this game, but I'll get to that).
You have a white board in the cafeteria, where you can allocate your members to go do certain jobs during the day, each job takes varying hours (and will decrease if you get another member to help them with it), mechanical jobs will go much faster if you have someone with a high mechanical skill doing those jobs.
Each member has their own set of skills (as well as the PC that he chooses at the beginning of the game, and can increase as you 'level up') and you decide what jobs they do depending on their skills.

While the rest of your team is doing jobs (you can have the PC do some of these various jobs, but you cant do anything while that happens), you can pick a team of up to 4 members as your raiding party. With these guys you can leave your base and get to travel the map (which is literally a map of texas, with all the interstates and towns and cities and all that). Travelling the map takes time, and is slower or faster depending on your travel method. At the start, you can only travel by foot, but later on you can get horses and even cars to speed up the process.
As the time goes by during the day, your members back at base will be doing their tasks you assigned them, while you are finding random super markets, hospitals, neighbourhoods, and so on and looting any materials you can find, weapons, food, luxuries, parts and tools and so on.
However, you MUST be back at your shelter by 3 am, otherwise you get a game over (im pretty sure, i never let myself be out that long yet), so obviously you cant travel too far from base without some sort of transportation.

While going to various locations, you must avoid or kill zombies, who are not only hostile but if they get a bite on your allies while their health is low, they infect them. Your allies, if infected will go up to 3 days without treatment before they will kill themselves or turn into zombies and attack you. There are antibiotics you can find that as long as you have them in stock, your allies will take them staving off the infection (but not curing it), so you can keep infected allies indefinitely, you just need to have a supply of antibiotics.
You can also find other people, looters who are hostile and you must kill to survive, to even other survivors you can recruit to join your cause. However, watch out when firing guns off liberally in a battlefield, as it attracts zombies, and getting guys infected is the last thing you need.

On top of all this, the most important part of the game is your shelter Morale. You have a morale level that goes up and down depending on recent events and moods of allies. Every ally has their own morale level that can be increased by giving them special items, keeping a stock of luxury items on hand, and even having other allies do jobs such as cooking for the crew to bring morale up for everyone. Morale is affected by everything, ranging from having broken generators (or no gas to run them) to the amount of food on hand, to having a secure base or what have you.
If morale with people get too low, they may find that they are better off out in the wasteland and leave your crew, to even if morale is so bad for everyone you can have a mutiny and your crew will outcast you from your own base.

This game is so damn addicting, I wish i had more time to play it haha. I would recommend this game to any RPG fan out there, specifically if you like survival horror. A solid game, and worth the money for sure. I would even go as far to say that this one could be nominated as Game of the Year, especially if im only playing an unfinished product so far.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

Such potential.....

Thing is it looks and plays like a N64 game, the animation are laughable but yet it still could be fun.

BUT there are no difficulty settings, yes weird i know, im only on my third mission i think it is and they tear my team apart, leaving 2 or 3 of them standing full health with guns and even shotguns, the balance is pathetic tbh.

Oh and i have hardly seen any Zeds, every enemy is a Human Looter, sheesh.

If you want TBC then go for Xcom, Wasteland 2 and The Banner Saga, all of these are far far superior and polished than this, as they would be as this one is early Release, but you can see the style etc they are going for.

Its just the little effort in things i notice, but the graphics are terrible, the animations are from the 80's, all forgiveable if the gameplay was addictive, and it is not, as mentioned the difficulty is very very hard and there is NO difficulty settings at all, combined with the poor, even terrible unbalance makes it a hell to play.

I wont reccomend it till its further down the line , but keep a eye on this one it ccould be good in the end, but with the unbalance its just infuriating to play, its certainly not fun.

reviewText:
Rating: 5.5/10.

I've been playing this since early access.

Pro:
- The story-line is good, bring out the taste of the old RPG like Fallout.
- Interesting decision making that will affect the storyline.
- Highly replayable with different character class.
- You can f**k a pretty chick, but only once. I'll give 10/10 if you can f***k all the characters anytime you like, I mean come on in zombie apocalypse dire time we need this.
- They did add and change the game feature based on the suggestion from the early access players.

Cons:
- Until now the character face customization is still not available in full version. When asked they replied the developer will add in this feature when they got time.
- Not worth current price, wait for less than 10 dollar or so. Better spend your money on Wasteland 2
- Wait until they fix all the F**king bugs, it's still buggy and the developer started to slow down because the sales had slow down as well. *they claimed to fix when they are free (or when people are purchasing this game)
- The developer company is greedy. The developer had raised 330K Dollar in kickstarter, which is more than enough to finish an indie game like this and startup a new company. Not to mentioned they got sales on Steam.

In conclusion:
Game wise, really mixed up.
Recommend this game but just buy Wasteland 2 1st and wait for 80% sales. Not worth the current price.

The later you buy this game the better

reviewText: Amazing game.  Buy it!  The writing is terse but perfectly composed:  you get to know these characters and care when they die, or turn against you, or become disillusioned with your leadership (yes, all this can happen organically within the game system).  This game creates a tremendous sense of atmosphere and freedom:  every place, however insignificant, has a story if you look closely, and the game throws plot events at you at a slow but believable pace that lets you explore and deal with the crises that emerge naturally from the dynamics of the world and your own play style.  This is one of the very few times I have felt like I do when playing a tabletop RPG with a truly excellent GM.  This writer knows what he is doing.  Plus... this is a very satisfyingly long game, especially given the price:  look above to see how many hours I've given this game and I haven't finished it nor can I guess how it might end other than... well... badly.  But that is the apocalypse!

For the money that i payed for it, i can ignore the bug's but now the game is finished (to soon

There was another update, so that´s positive. I will have to play the game again, to see what´s what. After i do that i will edit this review.

Conclusion, I liked the game and i don´t have any regrets buying it. No it´s not perfect, but it´s something else.

reviewText:
Fun turn based zombie apoco game.
Great for a indy title.
However, I do believe small additions can make this game great for any production level.
It needs a bit more customization. Don't force the main character to remain.
Have it if he dies you can continue as the other survivors.
So it becomes group focused, instead of a single leader.
Taking a few notes from XCom this could be a amazing experience especially for a Ironman mode play through.
I personally believe you need voiced dialogue for the responses. But it is understandable not to, it would increase the story for me at least. With out the emotional reaction of the voice actors it is no where near as impactful.
Aside customization of your own character, and maybe other survivors in your group.
They have done a great job with the items you get, and luxury items.
They could extend a bit more, but that at this time for the first entry is well done.
Instead of it focusing specifically in Texas. Maybe have it focused around a country.
This is near the start so it makes sense for walking distance places to have supplies still.
But, it would make it more interesting if you traveled across a landscape to get supplies.
Such as multiple states. As well it gives the opportunity for different environments.
A lot is here, and the fundamental system is great for what it is. But it could be great, as of now it is good.
I suggest picking it up if you are a turned based RPG fan.

reviewText: There are plenty of detailed reviews out there that detail this game's pros and cons, so I'll try to keep my review succinct. I managed to spend 48 hours playing this game, and I enjoyed them. I found the combat enjoyable, scavenging was fun, and upgrading the shelter was satisfying. But this game is not everything that was promised to be. Interacting with survivors at the shelter was a lifeless experience. Crisis" events were very rare and sometimes made little sense. Crises also had little lasting imapct; besides a one-time morale effect
date: they were never mentioned again. Certain story and character arcs were clearly cut short. You will almost never be able to find a creative solution to a problem- outside of multiple choice crisis and story events
recommended: your choices will have little consequence. In the late game
hoursPlayed: you will likely have a glut of resources and will be able to simply go on cruise control.\n\nThis game had a lot a promise and only partially lived up to it
voteText: but there is fun to be had here. The 70/100 metacritic score is fair. I can recommend this game as long as you temper your expectations."

Anyways if you like either Tactical games, or zombies, or sandbox games, or exploration games, or shooting dem bad guys, or just scavenging your enemies bodies for cool new stuff then you must buy this game.

To simplify, this game is an strategically more detailed XCOM but with Zombies instead of aliens. Thik of it as XCOM Enemy Unnown - Zombies Ultimate Survival Edition" if you will.  I mean freaking zombies

reviewText:
Surprisingly good!  I wouldn't give $30, but would value it at $15-$20 easily (grab during a sale).

I've loved turn-based squad strat games since JA2.  I'd still rank that as the top; give 2nd place to Silent Storm (up until they bring in the unicorn suits of rainbow bright), and give this one 3rd place.  Just finished my first full playthrough:

PRO's: Solidly done turn-based squad strat game.  It's got a base with lots of upgrades, tons of loot, decent selection of weapons, limited resources (ammo, grenades, fuel, etc), good character progression, zombie killing fun, base management, character interactions are fun, etc.  Basically it's got a LOT of stuff done RIGHT.

CON's:   Not as many different weapons or upgrades as I'd like (thinking JA2 again); approx 3-6 per ammo type (7 ammo types; maybe 20-25 weapons total).  The side stories are limited in content and usually amount to: bring character A to place B from their past; get special dialog, end of quest.  Not bad, but could have been made into much more.  There are a few bugs; I had about 8 crashes total over my playthrough, but with ample auto-saves you never lose more than the last 10-20 minutes.  Last and biggest complaint is the simplistic AI.  Dont expect you're enemies to Mcguyver up an ultralight and surprise you with an L-shaped.  It's just not there, still: what do you expect from zombies?

Still a postive experience; really recommend this one if you're a fan of the genre.

reviewText:
Pros:  Great game, lots of relevant moral decisions.  Interesting characters, cool weapons and loot.
Cons:  Still pretty buggy.  None of the bugs I found are game breaking, but they can be annoying.

Overall, I say the game is worth the money.  At this time I've got 36 hours in, only a couple restarts, and I still have plenty of game to go.

reviewText:
I would recommend this game when it's on sale. I liked the gameplay a lot at first, until of course about 40-45 hours. Tryed my best to like it but I can't. I am a fan of turn-based strategy games.

My negative opinions

1.) Waiting for the zeds to load
2.) The graphics look cheep and agonizing and get annoying to look at
3.) Lag spikes depending on how many zombies in a zone
4.) The buttons, inventory, and other options are setup badly and should be easier to handle
5.) Minor bugs.
6.) Shelter design is poor and getting around the shelter is sloppy
7.) Camera

Brief Explanations ^
--------------------
(1) Annoying as ♥♥♥♥, waste of time, and the number one reason. Waiting for AI to wait a turn even if they don't need to move that round should really be fixed (2) They should have better avatars (3) Can get really laggy - on two story buildings and when dealling with large number of AI (4) Looks like something out of a free online game
(5-7) minor issues


Overall, this game gave me high hopes from the store page, but left me with a bad taste. Maybe ide have 150-200 hours if the creators of Deadstate wanted to make a good game.

Only recommend on sale!

reviewText: Dead State is a different approach to all the Zombie games out there. The game is driven by npc characters personal stories which are many of times linked to missions and side quests. The game's main focus is not on combating zombies but base upgrading and keepings your surviving npcs morale happy and keeping them safe in zombie apocalyptic world. Combating zombies is only an obstacle to these objectives and your base can come under attack by the living and the dead. Among your npcs are personalites that may clash with each other and even you the\nProtagonist in the story. Zombies can kill you if you dont plan an attack when you approach them in a turn base combat. Outside of combat is free roam. Think of this game like This war of Mine" meets "wasteland 2". The developers seem to be continuing to fix bugs and add more contents to this final release game..."

reviewText:
Dead State has positives and negatives.  I expected a completely open world which, frankly, has been a standard since Might and Magic and Baldur's Gate.  I restarted the game to carefully follow the tutorial.  Then I had to figure out myself how to find locations on the map when they're not already marked so I restarted again because I lost a day or two.  Later I learned that you will not find some locations until an ally tells you about them.

Despite that, I found Dead State to be fun and engrossing.  The shelter, the upgrades, the morale system, and the crafting system are all excellent.  Combat is flexible and you can approach a fight in many different ways.  I spent about 30 hours on the first 16 days and enjoyed it a lot.

After that, I started to find some of the religious, political, and personal issues of the allies to be a pain in the butt.   I just wanted to survive the zombie apocalypse not be a politician and social counselor.   If there are zombies around your fence, aren't people going to be a little more concerned about survival.  Some of these allies that  show up are just plain unrealistic.  It's like Dead State turned into some nightmare, reality show.

Finding comfort items and medicine for allies was great.  Looking for family members - awesome.  Beyond that, if things are brought up I'd rather look at it through the lens of surviving the immdediate threat of zombies.  For most people, I think a safe place from zombies is more than enough to keep their morale up.  Just my opinion.

So I'm giving the game a qualified thumbs up.

reviewText:
I have exactly 100 hours of a single play through in this game, so I figured I would give a quick impression. This has probably been my most enjoyed zombie apocalypse themed game yet, and I have played almost every offering on the market. The game does need smoothing out and some balancing and some randomization for the map and big story events or end game would go a long way to make the game more replayable.

That said, the scavenging, base management, and combat is all addictively enjoyable. Even the character development was very well done and each path of skill advancement can have a huge impact of how you tackle the zombie apocalypse (i.e. you are not required to be a combat monkey to succeed).

For fans of turn based RPGs with base management elements, I would highly recommend you pick this up!
