reviewText:
This game can be enjoyed immensely by the type of expectation you have.

You will experience the following during this game:

A) An enjoyable strategic experience that is unique
B) Some inconsistancies as this is not a AAA title
C) Some frequent crashing as the developer continues to update the title

There is a lot of charm to the game. I find myself playing continously coming back for more even though I know the game does at time crash and can be inconsistent with expectations on how to manage your headquarters.

As long as you understand this is a small development team working very hard on a unique experience you will enjoy. If your expecting XCOM level polish you will be disappointed.

The game accomplishes what it primarily attempts- a strategic, loot diving headquarter developing zombie game.
voteText: 6 of 11 people (55%) found this review helpful 1 person found this review funny

reviewText:
Full disclosure: I backed this game on Kickstarter.

What is Dead State?  It's a game that does a similar premise to State of Decay, but in a different way.  Instead of a 3D action game, this is an Isometric X-Com-a-like with traditional turn-based combat.  It is not an easy game early on, with difficulty decreasing as better equipment is found.  I *cough* resorted to some save scumming (reload and come back with more firepower) if I misread who the foes would be or wandered into a place that ended up having unusually tough enemies.   I managed to beat the game after 79 hours of play, but managed to defeat it on my first try.  There is a bit of grind-y nature to discovery, looting and zombie-battling.

All in all, though, I enjoyed the game enough to play through it entirely to see it through.  I did lose interest around Day 70 and more or less had to power through the next 20 or so.  I don't know if I'll play it again since I was sucessful.  I can see if someone doesn't manage to beat it wanting to try it again, though.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

Dead State (Demo)

Story: 6/10
Gameplay: 6/10
UI: 4/10
Multiplayer: NA

Difficulty: Moderate
Price: Not Worth It

Pros
-Giving your survivors jobs to perform at your base adds a nice simulation aspect to the normal action zombie shlog
-Exploring and scavenging abandon areas is fun
-Attacks have a bit of variance depending on the weapon you're using
-Environments are well designed and have personality to them

Cons
-Very buggy, prone to crash or have the screen go all black
-Actual combat with zombies can be frustrating when it happens in enclosed areas (allies can't move past or through each other)
-UI is very unintuitive, you can even attack your own party members if you click on them to select them
-Actual zombies aren't much of a threat when compared to insane scavengers
-You'll never encounter more than a few zombies, and as long as you engage them wisely, they are never really a threat
-Turn based play doesn't feel right for a zombie game, at least not for this game

I really wanted to like this game, I have been excited about it for years as more and more news of it's release came to light.  It seemed like the people making it were really into zombie culture and were promising a well made zombie simulation game.  Unfortunatly, I don't think they were too experienced when it came to designing actual gameplay.

The story is pretty generic zombie-survival fare.  You wake up after surviving a plane crash surrounded by a bunch of people who saved your life when they brought you to their safehouse and patched you up.  From there, you are basically given jobs to strengthen the safehouse and you try to survive your first week in zombie land.

The actual gameplay is little more than making sure all your people are in the right position when you start a fight with a zombie.  If you do it right, you'll kill the zombie almost every time without it even noticing you.  If you do happen to be noticed as you approach the zombie, it will get a free attack on you and possibly beat you down pretty badly just in a few hits.  If you have a group with you, sneaking up on a zombie is a crapshoot unless all your party members are stealthy.  Once combat begins, you basically hit the zombie with debuff attacks then hit it with power attacks until it's dead.  (Blunt weapon for zombies, edged weapons/guns for humans usually works well)  If you're fighting humans, then there is a bit more of a challenge as they often have at least one pistol guy in their group.  (And, unlike most games, getting shot really hurts.)  Also, their gunshots may bring more zombies, but I've never had them bring an amount that worried me, (2 or 3 tops) which was a bit of a disappointment.

I think the feel of the game is the most disappointing thing.  The zombies in this game don't seem like a threat that should have brought down society.  Most areas in the demo only really have a few zombies to deal with and they just aren't that scary. There should be the danger of hordes, being overwhelmed, and getting tired from too much combat.  None of that really comes into play.

That said, this is just a demo so it's possible the final product will be much better.  However, this game is not worth the $20 price tag they are asking.  Wait for the final product or until they lower the price tag to something more reasonable.

reviewText:
Based on the latest release of - Dead State: Reanimated.

Progress through Dead State proved reminiscent of pre-millennial RPGs such as Fallout 1/2, Baldurs Gate and to a lesser extent, Vampire: Bloodlines. I'd consider this the highest praise I can bestow a game.

The creative minds at Double Bear were involved in the creation of such cult games and have succeeded in achieving the sense of wonderment I found absent both in Pillars of Eternity and Wasteland 2, both of which attempted the same trick of capturing the essence of these earlier titles. Personally, I found both PoE and WL2 shallow interpretations, with story, immersiveness and game mechanics triaged for improved graphics. I suspect both titles will be forgotten while the legacy of their predecessors will continue.

Given the teams behinds those particular titles were also involved in the creation of what I consider the golden-age" era of cRPGs
date: I'd just about given up hope of finding another immersive isometric RPG. Maybe the real minds behind the greatest RPGs had left the business
hoursPlayed: or transcended to a higher plane of existence. Maybe
voteText: like myself
helpfulPercent: they were tired of the excreta being squirted out and trotted about as the "greatest RPG of all time" every few months. Maybe it was time to find a different hobby.\n\nThankfully
votesHelpful: at least one of the minds involved in the creation of cult classic RPGs is still among us.  The sense of an expansive and hostile world awaiting exploration
votesTotal: the advancement of both your character and relationships within the base alongside combat that retains old-school strategy but boosted with modern animations is unique among modern RPGs.\n\nThe personal interactions are significant
votesFunny: with extensive dialogue trees that vary depending on your own actions and the emotions and morale within the base. Plus
commentsCount: there are a huge number of friendly NPCs
column16: with 90% being unique and memorable. As an example
column17: you can negotiate with a Vietnam veteran to kill his infected wife and join your base. You can either encourage his martial mentality
column18: or relegate him to the kitchen. He can end up drunk and you can either admonish
column19: mock him or give him time to recuperate. You can improve his mood with cigars and bourbon. You can encourage him to recover his old combat skills or serve the base more domestically. He can confront and threaten you if your leadership suffers
column20: and you can either regain his support through negotiation or shoot him in the back as he leaves your room and insult him as he bleeds to death. Such extensive interactions are present with the majority of the NPCs within your base. This isn't Dragon Age type fluff
column21: you aren't bored with slowly voiced over descriptions of the sexual preferences of Quinari princesses in the lands of make-believe. The topics of discussion are life and death
column22: the answers are realistic
column23: sometimes grim
column24: and darkly humorous or a distraction used prior to a sneak-attack.\n\nYes
column25: the zombie premise has been overdone. Yes
column26: there are bugs (Fallout 2 and Bloodlines were also released in such a state). Yes
column27: it can be hard to maintain morale and food in your first game. Yes
column28: you may found the graphics not the greatest. If the screenshots are repulsive to you
column29: this won't be your preferred game type. This game has depth and complexity
column30: not 4D-quantum-parralax-10.1 reflective sunbeams accentuating the convexed-v-synced-bump mapped textures of the player characters rear end
column31: each bun modelled with a 6-point physics skeleton for life-like jiggle as you waddle around. This isn't style over substance.\n\nThe Easter Eggs
column32: such as the Friggin Chikin scratch card and bill-board signs
column33: plus Dougs nerdy advice about attacking those crazed meth addicts with critical hits to their eyes is appreciated fan-service to those of us who immersed ourselves in such iconic RPGs almost two decades old. Dead State may seem out of place in the current horde modern RPGs
column34: however it restores my faith that future RPGs can retain the same complexity
column35: intrigue and challenge that made their predecessors so renowned.\n"

reviewText:
The definition of the success, to me, is how addicted I am to this game. This game totally got me addicted! It is a successful rendering of Fallout 1 and Tactics. My wife was like, what the hell are you doing? Why are you glued to the computer day and night." I haven't experienced that since the original days of Fallout.

Indie games rarely draw me in. But I must applaud this game's success. Some reviews complain about picture quality and easy level of the game. It is exactly what I am looking for. This game is for those who miss the old days of Fallout 1 and Tactics. I am enjoying this game very much. It caters to a specific group looking for a specific kind of game. It is not for everyone.

If you dislike action
recommended: RTS and prefer old fashioned turn-by-turn
hoursPlayed: RPG games. Then this game will be for you."

reviewText: I tried the demo and it seemed interesting. So I bought it for $8 bucks on sale. That's what I feel this game is worth. The combat is rather simple once you figure it out. Z's will attack the closet person for the most part and if you have a fire ax/sledge it's game over for them. Guns are pointless because they alert everything in the area (which is realistic). You can add" stuff to your shelter by saving up enough parts and working on it for a number of ingame days. This adds a slight bonus and takes away from the monotony slightly.\nSo basically every day you go out and do the same thing
hoursPlayed: and luxery items to make your people happy. With combat rather simple it's a rinse and repeat grind waitng for the next addition to fisnih so you can  start buidling the next "addition"  that will add another slight (and I mean Slight) bonus to your base. And then wait as your people make weapons/grenades for you.\n\nI wish steam had an meh okay button instead of recoomend or not. It's not a bad game but it's not an amazing game either. It kept me interested for 18+ hours but seeing as there is no real story line beyond just collecting loot I don't think I'll put much more into it."

reviewText: Another time where trusting an early access developer has backfired in my face. This game is not done, not even close. Its buggy as all hell and combat is clunky at best. They just shoved it out the door like many others do when they aren't making as much money as they were hoping to make and say screw it, slap a done badge on it, and drop it as is.\n\nI really wish I could have recommended this and honestly I thought I was going to be able to. But its just another failure that could have been great had they decided to finish it. The base building is lackluster at best with the only noticable differences being the wall lightly changing as upgraded. Other than that every upgrade is invisible. Your characters will actively be morons and take dangerous routes unless you purposely pick their route out piece by piece to prevent them from murdering themselves by walking into enemies...Its just sad. Let down again.

reviewText:
I recommend this game. It is fun, it is challenging, it has good gameplay value. You will enjoy it for 40+ hours, you get ok value for your money.  It's not particulary buggy, it plays well and is balanced. So that's all the good bits.

Unfortunately, the game, even the reanimated game, seems like it was never really finished. Unless your not very good at playing these type of games, you will probably level out your base and fully kit out your team a long time before you get close to actually finishing the story line.

I never finished the story line, towards the end of the game, it just became a grind, all my people were sitting in the base playing video games, it got boring, even the story got a bit boring, like they had used all their inspiration in the 1st 20+ hours of gameplay.

So overall, this is a good game, but it makes you kind of sad, as with a little more work to pace the story line with the skills and gear progression, this would have been an amazing game.

Enjoy.

reviewText:
Combat is taking an important place in Dead State and sadly, gameplay is very lacking in this regard.
Although it's very close to what Age of Decadence (which I liked), somehow here, it feels boring.

Music didn't help, I just want to throw my computer out of the window listening to it -_-

Conceptually Dead State is still good, the first attemtp of a A-RPG at a zombie outbreak, enough char customisation to satisfy your anyone's taste, with handfull number of perks.

But in the end, you'll find the game to be very repetitive, without any mechanic holding you to play it.
What it needs is real base assaults, real hordes of zombies invading maps at random, better combat mechanics with much more options for weapons (targeting heads etc.)
And then it could become interesting on the long run.

reviewText:
All in all, I appreciate a game that brings the element of base building along with zombie combat. I don't tend to be very good 1st-person, as I fail at the twitch factor miserably (lol). However, it would be nice if there was a clock on the top of the screen at all times and pack animals, so we don't have to run back and forth to get everything. Also, more chickens and how about the ability to grow more by utilizing the roof and two other patios (so called because they look like the one that currently has the garden. Lastly, what about wandering zombies? When my party is our scavenging, how come they don't run into zombies in-route? I think these are easy additions (BTW - I'm in software as an SDET).

Now, if you really wanted to do something fun, you'd allow us to move to another location or add/remodel the shelter/school. I'd love to get access to the roof areas (including the other two patios). Now, this would be a big change, but one that would breath some more life into an already interesting, if not grindy game.

Anybody else have ideas?
voteText: 6 of 12 people (50%) found this review helpful

reviewText:
Attention!
I previously wrote a review NOT reccomending this game but I changed my mind.
Yes the game had issues that forced me to stop playing after say 8 hours. Yes it is still buggy and sometimes feel unfinished, but this is a game that rewards patience. It has a steep difficulty curve and has some dodgy gameplay mechanics at times, but it gets better.
I have now spent around 15 hours and I come back for more.
What I like:
* Varied locations with a lot of attention to details.
* Subplot told through collectibles that has suprising depth. Yes you can miss it and that is the lack of handholding rarely seen today.
* A truly believable story of what it means to be a leader of what could be the last of humanity.
* A cynical undertone of contemporary politics.
voteText: 1 of 2 people (50%) found this review helpful

reviewText:
Now that I've put in a few hours (12) in the game, I can make a pretty comprehensive review on this title.

First off- Dead State has rough edges, surely, but overall, it's an enticing zombie survival game, with emphasis on squad and shelter management, improving your abode while trying to weather out the apocalypse. You'll set up your base in a school in a fictional Texas town, trying to make ends meet without succumbing to the horrors of the zombie apocalypse, which is not limited to the shambling dead. The game makes good use of the setting, providing a few differing factions and splinter groups set up in the ruins of the world, each striving to survive- sometimes at the expense of others. You won't be getting many warm welcomes, and most of these will turn out to be ambushes, so that the thugs in question can loot those canned pineapples from your carcass.

Thankfully, not all of Texas is going to meet you with guns blazing- sometimes, diplomacy is the way to go, and investing in the skill trees can net you surprising results, varying from avoiding armed confrontation with hostile groups, to negotiating new location information, talking depressed survivors into fighting for another day or even recruiting some of the tough-as-nails survivors to join your growing community. Naturally, characters of nominal importance are the only ones you can actually recruit- you can pretty safely discern hostile troops from their lack of name, and the ubiquitous looter gear they're armed with.

After 12 hours, I can safely say that I am glad I backed Dead State- it's proving itself to be pretty much all it boasted, albeit with a few rough edges. I find myself playing 'just one more day', trying to meet up daily demands and the missions on the To-Do list. You're free to explore the end of the world, utilizing your own judgement and goals, although it does pay to placate and bribe your growing group of survivors every now and then, just to keep everybody happy, healthy and ready to eke out a meager existence in a world filled with ravenous undead, trigger-happy looters, gun-toting militias, renegade cops, mercenaries and just ordinary people trying to survive at all costs.

Pros:

- Solid tactical gameplay. Aside a few odd glitches in the 1.0 (multiple enemies occupying single tile, some impr. weapons losing their ammo charges- pepper sprays, nail guns and the like), you can pretty much plan, and execute raids on the many locations in the game, sometimes taking an active part in offense, sometimes defense, and every once in a while, just playing both hostile survivors and the zombies against each other.
- Stealth versus guns-blazing approaches- you're free to use your own judgement in how to deal with each location, but the game will most likely toss a zombie or two on maps where you announce your presence by three rounds rapid.
- Varied locations that, although using same buildings from time to time, are still distinguishable from each other.
- Emphasis on Survival, instead of shooting one thousand zombies. Stealth, planning and a bit of cloak and dagger can get you in and out of many situations where most games would provide you with one option- violence. In Dead State, violence is usually the last, least desireable option.
- Different characters with various backgrounds, motivations, likes and dislikes, which are factored in the daily business of your Shelter. Some are nearly joke characters, while others have to cope with the tragedies arising from losing their loved ones to the zombie plague.
- Good range of skills, weapons and choices for improvements on the home base
- Great concept art, character portraits

CONS:

- Still a bit buggy. Expect they will sort 'em out in the future patches, but be ready for clipping foes, misplaced pepper spray and nail gun magazines, one or two zones where Turn-Based-Combat trigger is broken and the fight will continue, despite no active hostilities. One shut-in recruitable survivor dialogue which should end up in violence, does not.
- The game really doesn't give you a heads up that initiating hostilities towards obviously hostile survivor groups first can lead to a MASSIVE negative morale in home base. You see a crazed shooter, you better have them initiate combat, or suffer the consequences.
- Static game zones: Sadly, once you've cleared out a game zone, there's nothing left to do there. And you can't mark these looted areas off your map, but have to rely on your own memory.
- No way to mark vital resources on the map, like discovering and making note of a sack of concrete mix you'll need later for HQ upgrades.
- Some of the menus are still a bit difficult to navigate/ too small to read on higher resolutions.
- Survivor inventory management in the HQ is a bit tricky to locate, but once you pick up on the drop-down menu on the upper left corner, you're set. Also, ammo dividing can be achieved with the CTRL-click on ammo stack, after which the portion allocated can be moved to the HQ stockpile, and distributed to your survivors.
- No real soundtrack or voices, sound effects that stick to mind.

reviewText:
Update: I still haven't beaten the game, but there are a few things I'd like to add to my 10-hour first impressions. The positive recommendation didn't change though.

Characters still feel bland. The dialog is, for the most part, very generic and there are many characters in my shelter that I barely know, and didn't even bother to get to know their names. Part of the problem here is that, what makes them special (eventually), comes by way of them taking the initiative to talk to the player about their problems or ideas. Those events trigger at different times, and not very often, which means that most will probably remain forgetable for a long time. This system is fine as it is, but I believe there's much room for improvement there.

As I found more people, and as I invited them to the shelter, the game became significantly more interesting and I became much more immersed in it. In the morning of each new day people will talk to the player making requests (like not working today), suggestions and other stuff. There are also crisis events that trigger rarely and result in a meeting between the main characters forming a makeshift, small council to discuss an issue. The role of the player is as the leader of this shelter, so he's expected to have the final word in these matters. There will be some moral dilemmas along the way which at times made me really feel responsible for these people well being.

As for the difficulty, I described it as escalating quickly in my first impressions, but after getting good equipment and weapons, along with leveling my character with a focus in combat, that difficulty curve quickly peaked and now is taking a big dive. Combat is way too easy now, especially against zombies. Apparently the main character can't get infected, which, along with the fact that they can no longer do any damage even if they hit me, makes them just an annoyance. Other humans still pose some challenge from time to time, but it's rare. I expect another spike in difficulty soon, otherwise I'd have to say this game has severe balancing issues. In terms of shelter management, even with a character build not meant to excel at that, it has become easier lately as well, though not as much. Raising morale, getting enough antibiotics to keep infected survivors alive, and getting fuel are the main causes of tension. It became incredibly easier after getting a horse, and I expect it to become even easier with a car, so again, I expect events to trigger that will put more strain on resources soon.

As for bugs, I found quite a few. I recon many are supposed to be fixed soon, but at the time of writing, there will be some glaring small issues that indicate lack of polish. The only really bad ones were crashes, which only started happening recently, but twice in two days, in which I lost some significant progress. It's my fault for not saving, but an auto-save feature would have been very welcome.

One thing I'd like to test is its replayability. I want to create a new character that is all about running a shelter, managing people, leading them in combat, but not being a good combatant himself. That should make the game harder, and I like the idea from a roleplaying perspective, although I don't know if a second playthrough can be different enough for that to be fun. On the other hand, I'd like to beat the game first, but I have no idea if I'm close or not.

So there, my opinion of the game improved dramatically because I got totally hooked as time went by. I recognize how hard it must be to balance the tension between the combat and shelter management parts of the game, and for the most part, it does a very good job at it. The text below was written much earlier into the game.

reviewText:
Base management, turn based combat with free flow open world exploration, simple yet powerful levelling system...WITH ZOMBIES!

If you enjoyed the original Fallout series you will love this game. Along with the turn based combat and exploration, a well implemented base management adds an extra element of planning and strategy. Levelling is not based on kills, but rather on a goal system, meaning farming every kill on a level is not at all necessary, and avoiding combat is at times the best strategy. I have not played many hours but already I can see this will be one of my games of the year.

The game does seem to be a bit buggy at this stage (from my limited playtime), but the devs are definitely on top of things and are listening to their playerbase, so I do not see this as much of a problem at the moment.

reviewText:
This is a great mix of squad turn based strategy mixed with zombies.

Pros:
- Entertaining and tough battles, similar to Fallout Tactics or Wasteland
- Interesting mix of characters
- Background stories and characters make the zombie apocalypse seem real
- The tense interactions with the characters at your shelter feel like you are just barely holding it together
- Later on, you need to carefully consider how you grow as your resources start to get tight

Cons
- Many of the conversations with characters have only one right way of responding. No incentive to take a dark turn
- While the crafting is interesting, it would be great if there were many more recipes

reviewText:
Great old school rpg fun. With all the baggage that entails.

Zombies are boring but the conflicts that all disasters create between people are interesting. Dead State understands this, and that's why it manages to remain captivating despite the overdone subject material.

It's a turn-based rpg and you travel the post-zombie-apocalypse wasteland in search of loot to bring back to your shelter. There's loads of combat, base building, and managing the personalities in your base. The combat isn't anything to write home about, but it's on par with Fallout 1 & 2.

The writing is really great, and one of the best parts of the game is reading through the dialogue you have with the people at your shelter. There's tons of opportunities to be a truly disgusting person without being stereotypically evil.

Like all great old school rpgs, however, it's got its fair share of bugs. Don't get me wrong though, it's very playable - there's nothing game breaking - but slight annoyances can add up if you're sensitive to that sort of thing, you little babby. Save often and keep multiple saves to avoid headaches. Graphics are fairly dated, too - although the character portraits are quite pretty.

I've played about 26 hours of it and it's definitely super impressive, coming from a small indie studio.

More like this please. Maybe with a robot apocalypse next time.

reviewText:
I wish there was a maybe button for recommendations.

So to start this game still should be in beta stages with how many major bugs there are. I have not run into many game breaking ones, other than ones that cause crash to desktop. I find if I do not save at every opportunity it is garneted to crash at a bad time. When people come to the gate once in a while the camera gets stuck there.

The gameplay itself is fairly fun. I do enjoy the mesh of real time exploration with the turn based combat. however line of sight  seems a bit off at times, and seems obstacles do not effect how hard it is to be hit or hit others with guns, ie on the other side of a table or car hood.

The shelter is neat as it changes, though a few upgrades could be changed a bit, as there is plenty of ground outside they could have used for farming rather than the small things on the roof. one needs to get the 25 % food reduction perk rather soon as food consumption gets rather high while getting 10 additional moral per day is rather underpowered. this shows additional balancing should/needs to be done.

The moral system itself should be reworked a bit s it seems to easy to keep I up. maybe put a upper limit on it and have luxuries be consumed as needed rather all at once. not so sure how to improve that system but it can be worked on.

TLDR Bugs lot of bugs, they need fixed. but otherwise an enjoyable game.

reviewText: So far I have about 8 hours into this game and been loving it. Unlike many games these days it offers challenge without artificially padding the stats of NPCs. reviewText: A combination of old-school (some would say antiquated) turn-based RPG mechanics and survivalist simulation. All over the map in terms of balance and characterization, and the UI is shameful across the board. Over the long haul, however, Dead State's charms begin to manifest.\n\nIt will take awhile before the game starts to get going. A safe bet for the first-time player is that you'll be about 10-12 hours in before the first character conflicts kick in and you start exploring places more spectacular and atmospheric than deserted small-town main streets and suburbs. Story content is gated by in-game days and it takes about a week (each day an hour or more of gameplay, depending) before things start to really happen. If you can't devote that kind of time or don't have the patience (and not everyone does!) then it's a take-or-leave game. It squeezes surprisingly little from its premise otherwise (there is SO MUCH you could get from a hardcore RPG set in a zombie apocalypse), and clearly marks itself as an earnestly made first game from a new developer. I would say that if you're into 90's Interplay classics, have time on your hands and really, really love zombie fiction, it's worth the $30. Otherwise? Wait for a few patches or get it on sale. But it's worth the look if you're into turn-based RPGs.

reviewText:
I am not normally the type to write reviews, but I feel that Dead State is worth a break from the ordinary.

I have been playing since early access (First Seven Days release) and gone back for multiple playthroughs with each patch release right up until full release.

End result, over 300 hours played on this game and I dont feel I have wasted any of them.

YES, there are bugs, some of them are immersion breaking, some are annoying, but nothing OVERLY game breaking. The Devs are incredibly quick to respond to any new bugs found and are continually consulting the player base to find and eliminate bugs as they happen. To me, this is incredibly satisfying as I know my opinion as a consumer is valued.

As to the game itself?
If you are looking for a pulse-pounding thrill ride as you slaughter increasingly tough and varied monsters in graphic ways with an assortment of zany and idiosincratic weapons....
Look somewhere else.

Dead State is a htoughtful game that encourages you to plan ahead, from catering to the needs and wants of your fellow survivors to deciding when, where and how you and your team will fight.
Sometimes it is better to sneak through an area, get what you can and get out quietly.

I found I was investing into the fellow survivors, thinking outside the game to better understand thier motives and how best to make them work. A sure sign of good writing (Although you may not believe it simply from appearances)

Finally, if like me, you have played more than your fair share of RPG's (especially from the 90's and 00's) the isometric viewpoint, the turn based combat and even the JRPGesque base and NPC collection will tickle all the nostalgia bones and keep you coming back for more.

tl:dr?

A great game that may still seem a little rough around the edges, but a must have for any RPG and/or Zombie Survival fan

reviewText:
I would recommend this game if you enjoy the genre or RPGs in general. Although the combat is lacking a bit in depth, it is enjoyable for the most part, and the exploration is interesting.
Yes, there are bugs, but with each patch it gets better, and the current build has been extremely stable for me, although ymmv depending on your system config.
One of the best parts, in my opinion, is the character stories that play out between days, and the different characters you meet while exploring which include several famous names from movies & past games.
Being a story driven game there is good bit of reading involved, so if you're not into that you may not enjoy it as much.
The writing is excellent, and is quite funny at times as well as dark & somewhat disturbing at others.
As it is right now, I'd give it 7/10 because of the technical drawbacks, but with continued support, patches & polishing, as well as future DLC, it could easily rise to a  10/10 game. (In my opinion)

reviewText:
HUGE Potential, HUGE let down!

Being a XCOM veteran I was full of excitement at the thoughts of this game and everytrhing it was supposed to offer, however on starting the game it was a massive dissapointment.

The fight engine has left too much to luck and odds how hard is it to hit a zombie from the front with a sledge hammer?" well according to the programmers its 5 times more likely to land a hit from behind than in front. This being so it takes four team members two rounds with two to three hits each to take out one enemy. I could understand odds being used on XCOM but why with melee weapons and why such appaling odds. And to make things even worse a gun reload takes a full turn. Add to this multiple enemies and you're in for anal decimation.

All in all a great idea destroyed by mismanagement of game dynamics.

If you're looking for a great zombie apocalypse RPG than buy State Of Decay. A lot better and more fun it has better graphics
hoursPlayed: costs less and more lifespan.\n\n"

reviewText: I really wanted to like this game, but in the end I can't recommend buying it in its current state even after multiple patches.\n\n+ Combat can be tense in the early game before you get good weapons/armor because you don't want to attract too many zombies or human enemies all at once. Note emphasis on early
date:
see below.

+ Base management can be fun, especially once you get lots of survivors who then start interacting with each other which can lead to interesting crisis events. Probably the best part of the game.Seems to clearly draw from Suikoden, what with being able to recruit lots of characters to your home base who have vignettes and even being able to build a suggestion box to read often humorous suggestions from them.  Until you get a lot of survivors the base is pretty dead though.

+ Can scratch that loot tick before you get tired of looting. Nothing like opening a single container and seeing a ton of nice loot.

- The game still has a lot of bugs including ones patches claim to have fixed (see: certain stairs in the hotel only working after rejiggering your whole party position so you can use them, enemies especially zombies clipping into each other while moving and merging into one tile, etc) which can make playing a chore.

- Combat breaks very quickly after the early game. You start finding armor that lets you ignore damage, quickly making zombies irrelevant and humans who don't have guns higher tier than the armor you're wearing irrelevant until eventually you have such good armor there are no longer enemies that can threaten you without critting. This cuts both ways and eventually the only significant way you can damage certain enemies is on crits, especially the really annoying ones with riot shields who you should basically not bother with if you aren't critting them with weapon types they're least resistant to. You can find and craft various gas grenades that trivialize combat against human enemies who aren't resistant to gas, which is like 90% of them including the top tier ones since you just blind or even knock them out and then pummel them while they're helpless. A zombie game where zombies quickly become irrelevant because your armor is so good they do nothing to you and humans become almost irrelevant soon after has serious issues.

-The interface is one of the worst I've encountered in a long while. You spend a lot of time looking at inventory screens, and because of that what might be minor problems in another game or taken alone quickly add up to become frustrating. There is physically no way to drop an item you realize you don't even care enough about to recycle (see below), you have to dump it into a container somewhere on the map. If you want to move things from the car to your base's stash that don't auto stock, you have to first move it to your main character and then move it into your stash (hope you invested in strength!). You have to move things one by one from character inventories to the trunk in the field because you can't move things from multiple characters inventories like when you trade between characters (another interface issue because you have to actually select it as an action on the field by right click cycling through other options instead of just pressing I" when you're not in base). I can go on. Again
recommended: these might be minor issues in other games or taken alone
hoursPlayed: but since by this games nature you spend so much time messing with inventories it adds up very quickly. The idea of getting loot in a game with a large emphasis on looting actually became a chore that I began dreading.\n\n- You can recycle things you don't want into "parts
voteText:
one of the resources in base management once you build a building. This is just completely ridiculous. First of all, once you build a recycler, you no longer have to care about parts because you can recycle trash items into more parts than you will ever need. This is a game partially about resource management where you can build an easily accessible building that lets you ignore one of the resources. Let that sink in. The other issue is it encourages you to pick up every piece of garbage you encounter so you can turn them into parts encouraging the most base loot hording behavior. This is already annoying if you're a lootaholic in games like Elder Scrolls series, but compound it with unfun messing with inventories and you can see why I never wanted to see another inventory screen in this game again. They nerfed this building at some point in beta and its still ridiculous. Guys you don't need to try to make every bad idea you come up with work, just delete it and move on.

- There isn't really any story until extremely late in the game. I'm talking like 80+ days in. That might appeal to some people, but by like day 30 I had my base pretty much set up and no longer had resource issues. That left 50+ days of basically going through the motions for the sake of it. Resources quickly become irrelevant when you get good transportation so you can bring home hundreds of pounds of materials home in a single day from no longer challenging maps. Lets not even talk about recycling.

- I don't care about graphics in RPGs but if you do... play another game. Not much going on in the audio department either.

I don't want to keep going because again, I really wanted to like this game. I think they have made an admirable effort considering their situation and resources. But that the people behind it made an admirable effort doesn't mean you should buy a game, and in its current state after beta and multiple patches I can can only recommend this game to extreme fans of the genre who are also extremely forgiving. I like to think I am in that category most of the time, but this game in particular soured me.

reviewText:
Game is not worth buying at the moment.  Every aspect suffers from huge amounts of bugs, many bring game breaking bugs.  Particularily the endings (if you havent been hit by a bug which prevents your storyline progression) which kills the entire last 1/3 of the game...  Even bugs which themselves are not inherently game breaking can interact with other bugs or wonky mechanics in order to essentially turn into a game breaker.

The one place the game has the potential to shine is the interaction between survivors, but even that is hampered by poor implementation and bugs.  All other aspects of the game are mediocre to begin with, but then made worse by shockingly bad implementation and glitches.


Leave it for a few months, say 3-4 months from when this review is posted.  Should be enough time for them to have patched most of it, will probably be good at that point.  But if you dont really give a ♥♥♥♥ about buying and playing unfinished games you should get it now, fun enough.


Also the company itself is dodgy in many ways (googling it will be better for you than me posting it here), if you are the kind of person that uses that as a qualifier for your purchases.

reviewText:
A really good turn-based, zombie RPG from DoubleBear with base management and pretty good writing.  There is a lot to explore and a good variety of items.  Interesting art style and great variety of NPC's.  The noise mechanic is also cool.  Enjoyed attracting zombies to a fight with scavengers to pit them against each other.

The game has a pretty steep learning curve if you don't read the manual.  A lot of things are not obvious nor intuitive.  The UI is a little clunky and there are still some glitches in the release version, though these are not really game-breaking nor take away from the overall experience.  Mostly some weird moving animations or inability to access containers the first time they are clicked on.

Overall, a pretty solid game and fun to explore.  Hopefully some future patches will clean up the bugs and they do some work on the UI stuff.

reviewText:
This is a a great game.   The combat is great.   The resource management is cool.  I want to know how randomized things are. If the Map is different everytime. I could play this game for years and years.

It is nice how you can out strategize the zombies.   You have to make decisions that don't affect you for days.  The job board is a great concept.

It is one of the greatest innovations in games. Thank you for making it turnbased.  I had bought it in early beta when I saw turn based zombie but wasn't much to do. I have over 50 hours into this game and I still have so much to do. I think it could be very interesting depending on what kind of character you build.  This will dramatically change the game. I only want to finish this game to start a new one and see how it changes things.

I would give this game of my highest recommendations.  I am enjoying it like the first time I played Xcom or Jagged Alliance.

Don't delay!  Play it now. I might end up buying a couple of friends copies just so I can see their enjoyment with the game.

(I am not much a reviewer more of a game player but I had to say something about this game!)

reviewText:
As far as indie releases go, these guys got it as smooth as anyone on release day. There are bugs, which are getting squashed. So far none of them have really bothered me or my game and im really diving it this game. One bad patch came out and was quickly rectified, which happens to the AAA devolepers too. I wouldnt really hold it against doublebear.

The game itself hits my sweet spot of gaming. Turn based, rpg, strategy gaming with base building. The closet analogy game released recently would be Wasteland 2. So its easiest to compare them and would be relevant to most gamers too:

Dead State (DS) has base building which i love. Wasteland 2 (WS) doesn't have this, and the way that game was made makes it seem like it SHOULD have been in there. The way the second half of WS was written it seems like it should have been included and it to me it felt like a great chance to extend that game was ignored.

WS was too campy in my opinion. It made far too many referential jokes and nods and what not to the previous game and the genre in general. I felt that was a mistake. DS tries and succeeds in maintaining a better immersion in the zombie filled world and takes itself seriously. So over all DS beats WS in its game world.

On the negative side DS needs to be balanced still. Combat goes from wildly hard to wildly easy. Not long into the game only a few characters can mow down a battalion of zombies with little effort. That being said, the inclusion of so much fighting other humans can be tricky. You will find in the long run, its the living humans that are truely the real enemy in the game. But im sure as the patches come, feed back is gathered, and balance is achieved, this won't be a negative for long.

Graphics are passable for the game, but they bog my machine down way more then should. If you have a low end machine you might run into problems with graphics on anything other then lowest settings. My machine is middle of the road and i have to run middle of the road graphics. While comparative games generally run much better. This is probably an optimazation issue, which of course, tends to get taken care of in patches. From the already released patches it seems like they are trying to get this ironed out.

There plenty of stuff to find and loot in the game. Much of it though is not anyting more then having the words FOOD and LUXURY ITEMS written on a holder card and given different names. While they may be 1000 items inthe game, 900 of them are functionally identical, but the fact i can horde up toilet paper and candy bars makes the game feel more immersive then it really is as far as loot is concerned. I almost wish the game made a distinction though between toilet paper and tooth paste and it didnt just all end up as one pool when you bring it back. But that would probably have made the game turn into a consumables stockpile sim, which i might like, but i bet most gamers wouldnt. So I accept the way it is, and be happy enough with it.

I would have liked more base building features. Base defense battles (which may or may not be included but i have yet to see one). More weapon and armor types (though honestly there already a lot, but i just would like more).

My biggest gripe is the lack of documention of some things. I find data items before I am told how they could can used, so i spent a long time trying to figure out why i couldnt access them in the library. I also got confused when unlocking blueprints inthe workshop had the same icon as the actual item construction. So i did blueprints and couldnt tell know could build the item, i thought it just made more blueprints. But fortunately the devolpers watch the forums and answered in minutes (literally minutes) and i got it sorted out. But its a good sign the game is complex enough to not be instantly figured out, but i would have liked better tutorials/documentation.

If you read this whole review, you will know i am whole heartedly recommending this game. This game had me up til the sun rose the day of release playing it. Its probably been 2 or 3 years since a game did that to me. Thank you to the devolpers for making this game!

reviewText:
This is a pretty awesome game for a while-- but the story flat out stops around half way though. By 30 game days in, I'd upgraded everything, acquired everything and had enough materials to just skip whole weeks at a time without paying attention. There was no end goal and no indication that I should be doing anything.

After looking it up online, I'd found out that the game just --ends-- at around day 90. Day 90?! I finished all of the content by 30! And without spoilers I'd add that the endings to the game offer no closure or sense of accomplishment- they're just events that stop the game.

So avoid. This is a game that could have been good, if the last half had been finished.

reviewText:
Played game some and can definately give a good critique now; I hope reveiw is  NOT seen as negative, but the constructive criticism it is. It appears that game makers do check these critics or we're just in sync with each other; thank you for the updates already made to game.

Creators have added a way to attach own pics but I have to leave this critique for now because it's still relevant to a degree:
Character creation looks promising, but currenty selections are girly men and rough women. Also you apparently have to have some peircing, tattoo, or hair style fetishes because thats what's offered. character progress either as a preprogrammed set of improvements, or the main character can select where the points go. However, there is no xp bar or knowledge of when or where those improvments are coming from. you just check character screen every so often and go - yay!

Inventory screen is severely lacking. When you return to base, only main chacter is accessible. Meaning he/she has to have all property on self in order to go through it. There is an auto remover for community items, but the items npcs are carrying are unaccessible at this point.

Game was feeling linear in beginning; approaching a more sandbox like environment? I like that now your ( upto four man) team can now move somewhat independent by hitting j-key. It appears that game is leading us to the point where we can possibly recruit human survivors. Will all people be possible to talk to? or just a few scripted ones? Will a dialogue option be added to support this? My current experience is to visit local park, be attacked and win then be told back at base that I am a ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥ for killing an innocent!?!  No control over that so I assume it's in fix mode.

Some positive ideas, good luck with them - your the smart ones making it appear in game.
I also would think more resources or replentishable resources might be needed; or even, (just ideas) a gas truck  location, truck is stuck can't move, but I can send team to collect gas once in a while. Or maybe more ammo stashes, or reloading options, or even black powder firearms options (imagine the chicken farm that gives food and potassium nitrate for powder).

Any chance on creating forward bases or safe houses, meeting other commnities for trade and safe haven. Imagine the house where you post a small team and can  add upgrades to or re-enforce. This would allow team to cover much more area on foot without the getting stuck and dying part.

All these criticisms and bugs aside, the game seems to have so much potential I can't help but love it. Good luck team, I hope you  guys make a  great game.

reviewText:
I'm really sorry to not being able to recommend this game.
In a nutshell: great story, lousy game mechanics. A pity.

I played it twice: first time, total disaster.
Second time, hyper-success (not challenging).
The story is fine, realistic... it's clear there's a novel writer behind the game.
The negative part is... the game itself. Seems incomplete, lots of unfinished features.
So the story and atmosphere are very realistic, but many game mechanics are unrealistic.

I am very disappointed, for the storyline is great as the atmosphere, yet too many bugs make it unenjoyable.

I was forced to quit the game for good when I saw that the car contents are not automatically transferred to the shelter stockpile and, even worse, when at your shelter, you can only transfer items from the car to your personal inventory and then, via another cumbersome interface, transfer them to the stockpile.

The breaking bug is that my character had little strenght and thus could carry few items at once, so transferring from car to me, and from me to stockpile was unbearably painful.

reviewText:
You can get a review of the features from different places. These are my impresisons.

Is the game perfect? No.
Is the game very good? No.
Is the game good? Maybe.
Is the game fun? Maybe.

Let's get the elephant out of the way early. Dead State has a host of issues. Combat is simplistic. The zombies aren't really a threat. There are numerous bugs and I have experienced numerous crashes. Certain game concepts are poorly explained. The UI can be rough in places, especially dealing with inventory. You can't eject people from the shelter. Areas don't get monster respawn. Enemies are always in the same place on every game, limiting replayability. The list goes on. So there are many legitimate reasons why some people may not like it.

Yet I enjoyed it for a while. The game feels old-school, almost in an original Fallout sense. It plays slowly and methodically and you have a chance to really get to know the world. Issues and situations are thrown at you, sometimes with no easy answer. It has that one more day
date: one more turn" feel that most good games have. I always have something to do
hoursPlayed: build and always a new situation to handle. The person who is bit - do I get them out of the shelter because they're using up all my antibiotics? Or do I do the merciful thing and keep them here? How do I handle an abortion issue?Does a woman's right to choose outweigh the necessity of repopulating the human race? Do I go fishing for food or do I try to scout that new camp to find supplies to reinforce our wall? Combat at times is difficult and after a fierce fire fight you can feel tired

reviewText:
Early Access Review

The First Seven Days of Dead State's Zombie Apocalypse Tactical Survival Game

The game as it is just a glimse into the final product, call it as an early access, demo or whatever, it is just the first seven days of the storyline with limited access to some of the features. Still, I am very impressed and excited by the game.

First of all it is a very traditional old school roleplaying game, the combat is great turn-based, very similar to Jagged Alliance 1 or 2, or Fallout 1 and 2, even to UFO series (the old ones especially). There is character sheets and stats to improve which have some effect in game. Obviously in the end game we might see better how these skills and attributes (and even perks that is not yet in the game but planned) will influence the game and give a boost to replay value.

The theme is from the Romero's zombie movies mostly. Zombies are slow, dead bodies, no mutations and freak abilities, differs mostly by the state of corpse. If you are fan of Romero's movies you would like this. If you are expecting a huge range of monsters then you will be disappointed. But if you can get along with it you might have a nice experience. The true enemy is the conditions, the lack of resources, other human beigns who compete for what left, ad your own group. There is a good amount of social dynamism even in such early state of the game and this will be just better. You influence your group morals by what kind of job you assign to them, who are you taking out to the dangerous scavenging missions, how much you listen to their advices and who do you listen to, and so on. There is a hint that there will be some power struggle among the group in later in game.

The tactical combat is good enough, if you learn the tricks it is not very hard, but honestly sometimes it can be difficult if you are not careful and the game can punish you very much if you are not careful or do a mistake. That is good in fact and makes the game just more interesting. If you are fan of turn based tactical combat, this game is for you. Weapons do have some special attributes, like cutting weapons can cause bleeding to living beigns, crushing weapons can cause disorientation, with some weapons you can knock your enemy prone and so on. Also there are some psychological conditions in effect, like panic when you are overrunned by zombies (a sure way to die quick).

There is penty of improvement to be made of course, and I list some which I think would make the game even in early access better.

1) Inventory screen: at this point I could not be able to reach the other survivors inventory at the base, and as you only able to command your main character in the area you have only a very ineffective way to equip your companions. A screen where your in-party companions could be equipped from the base storage would be great). Also it would be nice to be able to drop items to ground or just simply to exchange with others in the tactical maps. At the moment I only found one solution to trade items with companions, and that is to utilize the 'containers' already placed in game, put the items there and then change the control to other character and get those.

2) It would be nice to see some notes or hints in the maps you have. You encounter empty houses, or places with some corpses and you wonder what's happened there. It would add to the horror if either you might able to collect clues what happened or youhave your companions comment on the situation.

And finally I want to praise the music. It is great, melancholic, sad, but also in a way calming. It gives back something of the theme wandering in a city emptied of life. Well done and thanks fr th experience. I am looking forward to the final game and any updates.

reviewText:
My thoughts on Dead State my first 2 trys at 20 hours each.
Well... fighting zombies, gangs, thugs, and bringing truck loads of loot to disgruntled NPC's only to end up being shot by a dude in a wheelchair I thought was my friend which prompty ended the game...both times.
However,
My 3rd playthrough is actually going smoother thanks to a few console commands to help with morale issues. (Even if an ally is in a good mood there's a negative penalty to morale. ???) Also I had to use a command to remove some negative permanent status effects not being removed on its own. (I had 3 characters that were on fire for 24 hours)

It's a pretty addictive game for the most part. It reminds me of the old-school icewind dale games to some degree. The AI could use some work, a cover system would be a nice touch during gun fights, but over all I found myself frustrated at the bugs in this game but kept playing away anyway.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

May 2nd: This is a really cool game, of course there are a few little things that could be made better but the overall experience of the game is a lot of fun, you can tell the game is heading in a direction that will really make it something special by the time its finished, I just hope that wont take too long.

Follow up (August 11th): Really liked this game, I played through the week and haven't played again since the last review, its been kind of dead lately, no updates or quirky posts to remind us of how impatient were being. I've all but lost hope and will probably play it again once after they've completed it. They're estimate was for July so it may come out soon or it may never come out for all I know, or maybe they meant next July. Even if they released it tommorow now I'd hesitate to play it right away because of how long it took, all the momentum I had for it is gone entirely now. I like the idea of the game but there's plenty other similar games coming out lately that can fill that hole. Im still cheering for the game completion though. Would I pay $25 for the game with the knowledge I have now? I'll say no. But I would buy it once its completed.

3rd Follow up: (Nov 17th, 2014) Ok, well the game now has upgraded A LOT. The game goes far and beyond 7 days now and theres new items and upgrades available, but theres 2 or 3 that don't work yet but don't effect the gameplay enough to cause problems, unless you build it without realizing it does nothing and screw yourself out of supplies. Some areas are still glitchy, but thats to be expected from a game still in development. I really enjoy playing it now, its challenging and fun with lots of new people and storyline to entertain. I really love the new intro and menu screen thats there now too, definitely makes you feel more immersed. If they had realeased this first it probably would have had a more powerful impact but thats fine because its here now and its pretty awesome. I would highly recommend it to anyone who enjoys turn based games like X-Com. I eagerly await the fully finished game but Im very happy with what it is now.

reviewText:
I really, really wanted to like this game.

I’ve been watching it for a long while and started playing around Halloween. I am a big fan of turn-based games, base-builders and the zombie apocalypse-survival genre. Dead State is mature in theme and has a lot of different luxury goods to try and keep your group happy

Dead State is a graphically good looking game, but unfortunately one rife with bugs.

There are typos, and floating inventory items – but these minor issues which can be over looked. A big problem in the game for me was when I had started building the well for my base. My project leader became sick and had to take a day off from working on it. When she returned to work the next day, the game refused to recognize that any of my characters possessed a crowbar, which was deemed a requirement for the task. I equipped her with three, in every imaginable slot. Nothing seemed to appease the game. While I was frustrated, I was determined to play on.

The Coyotes are a violent, enemy group of rival survivors and they are VERY powerful in the early game. After several attempts to defeat them (there were no diplomatic options) I decided that you had to run from them. The Coyotes fire their weapons discriminately in combat and the sounds draws wave after wave of undead reinforcements down upon you.  Added to this, there are situations where, in combat, your move options are limited by fallen companions, KO’ed foes, terrain and areas of control of standing combatants, effectively trapping your characters so that they cannot fight enemies, while your foes continue to pump you full of lead. In tight spaces this can be lethal for your group.

I finally quit in frustration. I really wished that this game could have been more polished.

reviewText:
Pros:
- Combat
- Base building
- Dialogue options that yield different results (cause NPCs to attack you, gain an ally, etc.)
- Overworld map and various travel methods
- Interesting random encounters and events

Cons:
- Base building, job board, character menu, daily results, and inventory UIs
- Looting and inventory management
- Random game crashes (10 crashes in 66 hours of game play)
- Lose an ally's items if they permanently leave your roster
- Limited camera angles
- On certain levels, the corpses of your enemies may disappear along with their loot

Played through once just to see to the end. It was fun for the first 30 hours. Would not replay on harder difficulties due to the tedious looting and inventory management.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

Game won't start.

Finally got it working, but it took a full windows re-install (joy).

The interface isn't as intuitive as I would like, you right click sometimes and left click others. And there is no 'sneak' option.

The AI is also pretty bad. Sometimes you can creep up on zombies, others you can't. When in a group, some attack at the same time, others just kind of stand back. But making noise does appear to spawn new zombies. Unfortunately, they just stand in your exit zone and are easily picked off.

The story has been pretty interesting though. And there are some really neat ideas about how to fix stuff up, distribute work, and gain the trust of your allies.

Overall, I would say this game would be worth checking out once it is released and has one good patch cycle behind it.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

After almost 17 hours of play, I can see the game has a lot of potential.  This version allows you to play the first seven game days of Dead State.  It gives you plenty to do and see.  I have played through twice.

There seems to be a solid framework starting to take shape concerning the characters and their personalities in the shelter.  Each seem to have their own needs and desires and balancing these while trying to be productive and survive will be a factor.

The combat is reminiscent of X com, with action points required to move and to perform different attacks (based on the weapon equipped). The Shelter, your base of operations, can be improved with different structures providing additional benefits (only the well" upgrade is available in this version) . Different characters have certain skill sets that allow them to perform task at the Shelter as well
date: some based on materials on hand
recommended: others based on what improvements you have constructed.\n\nYou must decide when you venture forth if your going to leave a person behind at the shelter to work on a task or an improvement
hoursPlayed: or

reviewText:
As I write I am desperately heading a scavanging party out into the wild once more.  It seems a blind foray hunting for meds, a dark sense of forboding as I know unless I track done a single dose of elusive antiboitics by the end of the day I join the hordes of undead.  Yet despite this it all feels irrelevant somehow.  Should I find that elixir I am still lost.  I am surrounded by one time allies who have grown to hate me - sometimes through bad decisions on my part but more often than not due to the cruel hand of fate.  With their ever growing sense of discontent they are sure to grow resentful and suspecious if I somehow buy another three days when so many of their loved ones have suffered the grim fate.  It feels as hopeless as the end of the world...which, of course, it is.

-----------

In short - I'm hooked.  This is not a perfect game but nor does it deserve the large number of negative reviews. OK, I've only come on board post-'reanimated' release, but it still seems harsh.  I suffer from the 'floating cursor' issues (note for devs - it is related to the graphics but not as simple as just the card - if I pull the interface to an old square VGA monitor the problem goes away; would also love to see scavanging without the main character to let them heal) but I feel compelled to try and work with it nonetheless...but only a minority seem to have this.  But it is immersive - when I'm playing, I'm in the game world and I have a taste of the pressures.  I feel the strain of the unresolved crisis - I know the right course of action but am unable to take it due to spent resources.  Initially put off by the archaic weaponry I expected from screen shots I instead find a mix - you'll have some gunfire but blended with other options.  So utilising everyday tools as lethal objects - as naturally they can be - is perfectly in keeping.  Hit someone with a crowbar and it feels as though it hurt.  The noise meter makes sense - a novel twist for an under utilised sense in turn based strategy.  Yet there is more than this.  There are characters which you will feel affection for and others you'll want rid of - just as in life.  You'll regret bad decisions - neglecting morale too much, spending too many parts on repairing a wall before I upgraded it, allowing too many of my ranks to become infected being mine - and feel a boost when fate smiles on you.

As far me I realise that all is indeed lost...perhaps time to restart without the option to allow the main character to become infected.  Three days in he picked up the strain and has gobbled meds ever since...to the detriment of colleagues.  Now the landscape seems dry perhaps it is time to start over after all...

reviewText:
Great game if you enjoy community building and management ... poured tons of hours into it.  The collection of things your community needs while searching the places that have been ravaged by the zombie apocalypse is quite fun.  The AI could use some buffing, as human opponents routinely go to guns first, then switch to melee weapons, often to their own demise as they summon more zombies than they know what to do with.

The interactions with your fellow community members are frequent enough to be interesting, but not so frequent that it becomes unbalanced.  Making sure your shelter holds it together while getting everything you need is a fine line to walk.

I really hope they make a sequel to this ... say, Dead Nation, Dead America, or Dead Country?

reviewText:
Early Access Review

Potential, potential, potential.

While there's not that much content yet (at least not released to public) and the updates are a bit slower than what I'd like... if you are fan of the zombie genre, this game is for you. It's not the ultimate zombie game, but it's a different take from all the other similar themed products out there.

If you are into the more psychological aspect of the zombie survival, buy buy buy. That's not to say there isn't combat, but that's not the reason why this game shines.

<< 09/26/14 UPDATE >>

So the game has hit BETA state and the first patch has been released. I've also become a bit more active in the game's forums and learnt a couple things that I'd like to share with potential buyers.

First, the game is meant to be SHORT. In game time is estimated to be about 3 or 4 months. This is worrysome when you consider that it'll probably take you less than 2 months to kill and loot EVERYTHING in the rather small area map you get to explore. This would mean that you'd spend a substantial amount of time either idle or simply dealing with repetitive task like assigning jobs or going to auto-gather locations.

Talking about locations, a lot are on the small size. In most cases, you get to explore an area with only a couple of enterable buildings, which further decreases game time.

Combat is still pretty straight forward and rather easy. My biggest worry hasn't been zombies or hostile survivors, but loot capacity. Once you know where you can find a good armor and a decent weapon (usually melee), you can go there almost straight away and get kitted out. Unless they substantially change how combat behaves (specially remove the player's ability to run behind an enemy and begin combat, thus always getting the first shot), I can't see it become challenging. Even big groups can be split appart by causing noise, which usually leads one or two members straight into your ambush just around the corner.

Can't really comment much on the game's story as of yet because a lot of the script and dialogues have not been implemented or are currently not working, but even though it does seem to be shaping up to be an interesting zombie survival story, the presumed lenght of the campaign worries me greatly.

I'd still recommend the game to any zombie fanatics out there, but be sure to know what kind of game you are getting into.

All in all, I would recommend you go check out Project Zomboid before you buy this one, because even though the graphics are worse, it's got the survival aspect nailed down MUCH better than Dead State, and survivor AI is also in the works there.

PD: There's no plans of allowing modding to the game either, at least from what I've seen and read.

<< 14/03/15 UPDATE >>

Well, after waiting for a good while for some kind of patch or content update I find myself abandoned by the developers. There hasn't been any major changes since December and from what I've seen, the Devs already said that the planned expansions" have been called off because the game didn't sell well enough. What does that mean? You'll get a few more patches that fix what should have been functional on release day and perhaps a few more game mechanics that also should have been there on release day. Then
date: it's game over for Dead State.\n\nI am angry at myself for thinking that this could be any good. I've been following this since Alpha and I should have known that this team could not pull off such an ambitious project. Ambitious because it was something new
recommended: not because it was something hard to do. Honestly
hoursPlayed: with dated graphics and game mechanics that seem out of the 90s
voteText: how could this game take them two years to make? And don't get me started on the ending and the plot holes and so much other stuff.\n\nBottom line
helpfulPercent: Dead State brings nothing new to the party. Combat hasn't been improved. Its boring
votesHelpful: repetitive and cumbersome (when it doesn't bug out). The story is lame and the characters - while they have a few moments - are blanks that say their lines (the very few they have) and stand around in your shelter doing absolutely nothing. Music is nothing to be remembered. The rest of the game mechanics - specially the survival aspect - are badly implemented
votesTotal:
break immersion or simply make no sense.

What more can I say? I've been warning the devs about these faults for a long time on their forums and I was always met with blind optimism or simple denial. Now we are 3 months after release and it's exactly what I thought was going to happen: A disaster.

To any possible customer:

You want Combat? > H1Z1 / DayZ Standalone / DayZ Mod
You want Survival? > Project Zomboid
You want story? > The Walkind Dead by Telltale Games
votesFunny: S1 and S2\n\nChanging my recommendation to a thumb down. Sorry
commentsCount: but you truly earned it DoubleBear."

reviewText:
I was pretty shocked to see that my original review of this game seems to have vanished -- it wasn't very flattering.  I can only assume it's MIA because now this is Dead State: Reanimated.

So let me begin by saying that I was an original backer for this game, and I have followed it's development closely.  It showed great promise and intrigue, and there appeared to be a great dynamic between the devs and community.  That was, until Christmas 2014.

In what was the most apparent and appalling cash-grab I have ever seen by any professional entity, Double Bear Studios knowingly and willingly released this game in an unfinished, buggy, crash-ridden state.  The flame war which ensued between the community and devs is the stuff that legends are made of.

I've hopped back to this game from time-to-time, in the hopes that it was finally completed in a halfway competent matter (again, great premise for a game and I love to support indie studios), but it looks like the project is finally been abandoned by the devs in a semi-working state.  It's still a POS final product, just not as big and stinky of a POS as when it was first released.

Pros:
Great premise of a game --  Walking Dead meets Jagged Alliance

Cons
Everything Else!
Game is still buggy as hell.  Don't even think about trying to play it on Windows 10.
Graphics and music are just okay
Combat is slow, slow, slooooooooooowwwwwww ... and equally boring.
Almost non-existent base building.  Some upgrades are available ... but .... meh.
Scripted locations and drops from scripted enemies.  Zero replay value because of this.  Almost zero percent random.
A few different endings ... but nothing really that special.  Nothing that would make a player want to go back, retrace his/her almost exact steps again while dealing with the bugs and crashes.
$30.00!!!!??  $30.00 for this POS buggy, game!??  Someone is seriously smoking crack if they think that's gonna fly.

In Conclusion:
I would suggest you don't buy this game.  Instead, spend a few hours reading through the forums starting at Christmas time, 2014.  The evolution of the flame war and the devs self-destruction of this game is far more entertaining and engrossing than the game itself -- and it's free.

reviewText:
I played it when it was just released unfinished in Dec 2014. Then  I finished it once as Reanimated. And then again. So yea, I liked it. I think i have 200+ hours in it.

I can only recommend to play it on hard difficulty and iron-man. Then you have to absolutely manage the noise, or you will get swarmed by zeds. Of course AI doesn't care about noise, so you have to plan accordingly.

I do agree that combat is kind of lackluster, but I've seen worse. And you have to love looting and screwing around with inventory. Tons of items: weapons, luxury items, food etc. If you decode the messages and then read them in order, you will get some backstory.

Game has some balance issues depending on your skill choices. For example if you go for the Lab ASAP (using your character) and take perk double antibiotics, on the long run it is very beneficial (you will end up with all skills maxed out +29 unused). But it will be hard first 10 days. Especially encounters with coyotes biker gang. Min-maxing makes game easier too, balanced chars are usually harder to play.

Playing good" hippy type is easier than complete ♥♥♥♥♥♥ (much harder as you will not recruit as many followers).

I never had a crash in reanimated. Shelter inventory window sometimes gets a minor bug which goes away after restart. My last play-through i haven't found Galaxy Wars limited edition
date: but it is not crucial (just a mood boost for ally).\n\nJuts try the demo and decide for yourself. It's so far the best turn based Zed-RPG IMO."
