reviewText:
Early Access Review

New Review:

The game's release was a travesty, and the cluster♥♥♥♥ of patches 2 weeks after release ruined the game for many, but lets not touch that, what is in past is in past.

Its been almost 4 months since release and the game is deader then dead. I havent seen any patches or any significance, no gameplay changes to make it less of a boring farmfest. The balancing is still ridiculous, problems with FPS are still unresolved. Far Cry 4 on max settings no lags, no problem, -> lags galore in Dead State.

The game's name defines the game state perfectly. Devs show absolutely no desire to fix anything. In fact i should have changes my review ages ago, but i still cradled hope that it will get better. It didnt, despite assistance from Iron Tower team, game is still ♥♥♥♥. Gameplay is boring as ♥♥♥♥ as before, no replayability of any sort.

No achievements, no development or 'support' of any significance for the game, In fact let me tell you about developers. One of the most hardheaded moderators on the forums ive seen, extremely agressive and unpleasant. The ♥♥♥♥ing head developer seems to have made it his mission to be reviled by community. Well done Mr Mitsoda. And here i was thinking 'the person was lead writer for my favourite game of all times, i better support him'. Brian Mitsoda is an unlikeable ♥♥♥♥ who should be removed from gave development industry. Before i blamed publishers for Troika's demise, now im not so sure. I can totally see the situation where there is inspection of how game is coming along back in 2004. In comes 'lead writer' and after a chat with him, publishers wisely decide to get out of this deal be it competition with hl2 at launch or bugs.

I know that guy is now involved in helping with new Torment and im not happy with it one damn bit.

Do not buy this game unless its on sale, - on oversaturated with zombie games market with BETTER games available for cRPG or management as alternatives there is absolutely no reason to get this game.

I give it 4/10. Rushed cashgrab with no support by scumbag developers. If anyone purchased the game based on my old review during BETA which seemed to be very early version of what can be an incredible game, i am sincerely sorry. Please accept my humble apologies.


DO NOT BUY THIS.





Old Review (was back when there looked like game will be in 1year + more dev time).
While having absolutely ♥♥♥♥ graphics and sort of boring at times gameplay, this is a real gem of a game. With its believable characters and novelty shelter management of resources, people and time.

There is innovation in this game, something a lot of AAA titles do not have. It also has a soul. A bug ridden unfinished and poorly balances/optimised soul at that, but a charming one none the less.

This is not just 'another zombie game' hell, zombies arent even that relevant here at all. They stop being a threat 1-2 weeks into the game. With frequent patches and team hard working to make this game better then it is, it has potential to become a great addition to any rpg lover collection or just anyone with great taste of games.

Now, unfortunately, because of many flaws of the game, right now it can get only 7/10. But it has the potential to be an easy 9/10.

If you want more creative, well conceived games with unique gameplay features, support the developer and buy the game. You definitely get your moneys worth.

reviewText:
I've enjoyed it.  This last patch is kinda buggy, which is unfortunate that it's the release patch and so many people are getting down on the game.  More than my money's worth in entertainment, but like I said, the release patch is kinda buggy and crashy, but it will be patched up.


As an example, in my best run, I had about 40 survivors with me, each with their own abilities that level up, we travelled by horse everywhere and did our best to survive by picking fruit, fishing fish, and killing zombies.   As the game progresses of course zombies became less and less of a problem, and different human groups became the problems, including the police, army, bikers and survivalist groups that just didn't like the look of me and  my raiding errrrr hunting party.

If what you are looking for is a game with:

a) zombies (And angry barely surviving humans)
b) fortifying your base (Watchtower, stone fence, garage, garden, shooting range, etc)
c) medium level Role play (Most role play actions are done just at the start of each day, and can range from your people asking you for a day off because they feel ill, or asking for particular items out in the world, or a crisis event which may be someone murdered another person in the group)
d) exploration (The map has a bunch of stops with maps of varying sizes)

reviewText:
A great indie title by veteran AAA game developer talent (formerly of Troika and Obsidian). The Zombie Apocalypse meets the narrative-driven styling (and structure) of the classic Infinity Engine games. If you like strategy RPGs, choice-driven narrative, and/or the setting, then this game is well-worth your time.

Update 06/10/15:

I spent a lot time with the game in beta and a bit at launch, but held off playing the game all the way thorugh because every crowdfunded game needs a while to work out the kinks. reviewText: Day 9. Didn't sleep a wink, Elaine was on the stairwell sobbing again setting everyone on edge. Doug's been needling me to take her on a scavenge and leave her gutshot out by the old church. He figures it will draw them out as we slip in the back, given it was an emergency shelter before it was overrun. A lot of provisions in there Doug says, and with Elaine gone, one less mouth to feed means one more meal for me. But I doubt Davis would buy it, that wily cripple likes to remind us of how he took us in. And now the bleeding heart's handing over the last of our antibiotics to some Mexican kid with the bite. I swear to the God that abandoned us, I'd walk down the halls putting a bullet in each of them as they slept if it weren't for the fact that the fence has a hole you could fit a bus through and the noise would bring them in from three counties. Now isn't the time for division. No one survives out here on their own; looters, the dead, or Coyotes, one of them will find you. Make enough noise like the Sheriff did, and maybe it'll be all three.\nSo I hunker down, listen to Elaine bleat and I earn my keep... bushwhacking and scavenging, two or three times more than most. And for what? Another week of waiting to die chewing half rations of Mr Munchie bars and mouldy fruit.\nI guess it ain't all bad. The new guy that showed up just gave me some chilli sauce and some rechargeable batteries. With all that's wrong in this messed up world, I have to admit, my mood's better already.

reviewText:
Turn based!!!

1000's of ways to die, or well, 1000's of infected and non infected ways to be killed.  Fairly sure this is my new go to game when lounging around the apartment (not at home of course, well maybe).

Strategic and Tactical decisions required at numerous points of the game impact key areas of food, material, who lives and which allies go by the wayside. Some allies are quest driven, some are just zombie bait, remember, though, just because Joe is useless today, doesn't mean that they won't be useful later and when your skills increase.

A murderer was found today at the shelter, tried, and convicted, death by hanging at 1700, do you want to know more!?  Face it, the folks that survive a major pandemic are probably not voted, most likely to succeed in a, what is considered a normal, moral society.  Figuring out their problems, solving their problems and saving them from themselves are what a leader of a group does right?

With the current release Dead State has got even more functionality and continues to amaze me.

Warmest Regards,
Suralle

reviewText:
I'll try to write this review as objectively as I can, but this is my dream game.  I have been waiting for a turnbased zombie rpg with base building most of my life.  Overall the game fulfills this dream.  All it needs to be perfect is a sandbox mode for after you've played through the story several times and seen all the endings.  The devs have stated they may add that some day.

The writing and characters are the best I have seen in a long time.  This is due to the writing talent and experience the devs bring.  The head dev is Brian Mitsoda, the head writer for Vampire: Bloodlines.  His wife, Annie VanderMeer Mitsoda of Neverwinter Nights 2: Storm of Zehir, also contributed her writing talent.

Some may find the combat simplistic, but this game is an rpg, not a strategy game and the combat is no simpler than a classic rpg like Baldur's Gate.  There is enough variety in weapons, armor, and special gear to keep combat interesting and allow for a variety of tactics.  Especially with the inclusion of the noise mechanic that attracts zombies.

Other reviews may mention bugs, and when it was first released it had a few major ones.  However they have been resolved and the remaining ones can sometimes be annoying but there is nothing game stopping.  The devs work hard to fix them and have released several patches since release.

Considering they raised just over 300,000 on kickstarter, I think it is amazing what they pulled off.  I can only imagine what they could have done with the millions other rpgs had raised on kickstarter.

So in summary, if you like classic turn based rpgs with some base building added in, you should like Dead State.

reviewText:
Dead State is a fun tb-strategy rpg game mainly concerning scavenging, battles, resource management, building a secure base and dealing with other survivors during a zombie outbreak.

I like the way of leveling survivors, where they earn stats and skillpoints by completing certain goals. During scavenging there're a lot of different weapons and armor to be found, so I can play my own suitable combatstyle. Except battling zombies there're also many social challenges through dialogues between survivors which I like to solve.

I've played Dead State since beta came out. The game has still bugs, but the devs are doing a great job frequently releasing patches and showing that they care. As a die-hard fan of survival games I really enjoy Dead State.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

If you're looking for a very fun point and click based RPG based around survivors in a zombie apocalypse this is it.

Dead State has been coming out for quite some time now and just recently got released under early access on Steam, if you aren't a HUGE fan of it please do not buy it or you will be disappointed with the length.

Basically the game consists of you surviving in a world gone mad, you have to make sure your shelter is adequately protected, maintain relationships with other survivors, beware of threats etc. You can currently only build a well for the shelter but by the looks of things there's going to be quite a lot to upgrade in the full game.

You get a map where you venture out to various locations, to collect supplies, etc and fight zombies and looters.

All in all its a FANTASTIC game and I'm in love with it and cannot wait to play more.

P.S. You'd be looking at 8-12 hours of game-play for the 7 day demo if you explore all the locations etc and do everything.

reviewText:
I've played this game for over a year now, starting way back when it was limited to a 7 day run.  In that time, it has grown and evolved immensely.  If you've played games such as Fallout 1-2. Brotherhood of Steel, or the Final Fantasy Tactics games, or even any of the X-COM franchise, new or old, the isometric view and turn based combat will be familiar and nostalgic.

The game is not a graphical powerhouse, and was never intended as such, it is much more focused on the story, on the myriad and drastically varied group of people thrust together into a desperate survival situation.

Every one of the more then 40 characters is unique, from the first handful you start out with to the dozens more you can find and recruit over time, they each have their own desires, demands, and (in some cases) psychosis.

The zombies, while an ever present obstacle, aren't the real threat, but then, they really never are.  From as far back as the first forays into the genre, (Night of the Living Dead, Dawn of the Dead, etc,) the zombies are a foe, but not the major threat.  The major threat is, as always, other people.  The dead are easy to predict, simple and direct.  Your living foes, the duplicitious, under handed, cruel, desperate or just good old fashioned bat crap crazy other survivors of this world of central Texas are where the real challenge lays.  They are, by their very nature, completely unpredictable, and profoundly deadly.

Over all, this game, while it certainly does have its rough spots, is absolutely worth the money.  The dedication and detail that the development team has put into this title shows through any of the realtively minor remaining bugs, and will likely provide many hours of enjoyment.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

I am not a big fan of RTS games (I'm old and slow) so I tend to really gravitate towards turn based games.  So naturally I was very interested in Dead State and followed its development for some time (seems like a really long time).  I didn't actually buy it and begin playing until update 3. I really wanted to wait until release but curiosity got the best of me.

There aren't a whole lot of games that do turn based isometric combat really well.  Dead State doesn't do anything new in that regard either, in fact the combat, even though it can be quite a challenge until you get decent armor, weapons and skills it is really very simple. There is no cover, crouch, stealth or very many combat options at all. But it still manages to be very engaging and fun.  With that said it really isn’t the combat that make this game so engrossing.

Dead State does a great job of drawing you into the world it’s created.  You need to struggle to survive. You need to struggle to keep your base running. You need to struggle to get along with your ever growing group of personalities, oops I meant fellow survivors.  You’re in charge but you’re challenged to stay in charge.  You have to choose whether to allow in, or to keep some useful troublemakers.  Word of warning some people might not be what they seem to be!

As the game has developed through various updates; it’s now on update 5.5, the dialog has gotten a little more polish. It is fairly deep as it is but it could be deeper, just a slight knock in that department. The stories are compelling but a little shallow. There is plenty to do at the base, but also not much to do at the base at the same time. I know that’s confusing let me explain.

The game progresses at the close of each day, sort of a big end of turn".  Every day you set up your job assignments and go out into the word to scavenge. Back at base after you talk to your fellow survivors
date: there a few lines of dialog and dialog choices and that’s pretty much it. So even though you begin to care about some of your survivors and your base there really isn’t any way to satisfyingly interact with your base or fellow survivors.\n\nIn closing what you have here is a very solid good time playing in a zombie apocalypse.  It isn’t very deep but it is still very satisfying and it will eat up a big chunk of your time as you get into that
recommended: "well let me just see what happens tomorrow" (or the just one more turn) mindset\n\nOverall I’d rate it a solid 7.5 out of 10
hoursPlayed: it loses points because its combat is somewhat primitive and the stories inside your home community are a little shallow.\n\nThis game is well worth the cost and well worth your time if you are at all interested it this genre

reviewText:
Very well written game with interesting story and good atmosphere. Do not expect it to be mainly combat focused as the combat is bit trivial.
What I find really outstanding are the personnal stories of the cca. 40 survivors you can have in your shelter.

Very nice addition to the game is the possibility to decode messages and files(150 of them) from other survivors where you can read stories how the disaster happened and some other interesting reading. Conspiracy theories etc. fitting well with the overall atmosphere of the game.

Building and running your shelter and its inhabitants is done nicely even if it might not be challenging for experienced players.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

I personally think this is a gem in it's genre. If you never played a turn based tactical rpg before, just try it. What is there to lose? If you already did, great!

When it comes to turn based tactical rpg's, I have played a lot of them. We all agree we loved Jagged alliance 2, but all others have been received with mixed feelings. Not many of them could break out of the standard formula of a squad of six, besides silent storm, the setting was always more or less the same.

This game doesn't feel like jagged alliance at all and that makes it so great! The setting is very, very well chosen. In a post apocalyptic world money becomes unimportant, so you have to start building yourself. The combat system is primitive, but handles very nicely.

Also, living people and zombies live side by side. Every now and then that makes for interesting combat situations. Don't let knocked out foes lie around when zombies still roam the combat area!

On top of that, a lot of what you will be doing is managing. Your team will consume food, gasoline, antibiotics and so on. They will not all like eachother and you will sometimes fail.

Personally, I think the game has a lot of potential of becoming a new benchmark and making the genre surpass its never found glory. I am pretty happy that I helped the makers a few euro's closer to keeping up the good job.

reviewText:
First of all, I love this game. (8/10)
It has right the amount of progress to keep you playing, looting and dealing with moral choices...
But it has some major issues too:

1) You can stalk up to enemies in realtime and most of the time make the first blow. BUT the pathfinding Ai is really bad for your team (not the selected player that one is good). (especially with 4 ppl in the party) So you end up with one to two ppl next to the enemy and 2 ppl more than one round away.
You can't do that in Turn based mode, cause the enemy instantly knows you are sneaking up to them even if they didnt see you comming.

2) You can not pause the game to make changes or give orders. That wouldn't be bad, if the turn based mode would not just end after no one is close by. (You see someone is comming, hit Space Key and want to reload before the actual combat begins. Yea.. right.. damn picked the wronge Character, Space again.. realtime continues.. bam they see you.. combat starts... all weapons shot empty -.- )
Having a complete Party movement without going to realtime would be great. (or a Pause mode with beeing able to give orders)

3) Loads. Having loot that has weight is a nice game mechanic and (Warning potential Spoiler:) later when you get to use a car, you can load stuff into it. All nice, but im missing the possibility to have additional Horses or a Trailer for your car (cause it can only hold 200pnds of loot... even a Fiat 500 can pack more Stuff)
And you must unload the car by hand. (every Character has the option to choose the whole inventory and move it to the shelter stash. But the car is no Character so you have to unload the car into your player char inventory and after that you can move it into the stash.

4) Sorting of the Task Board.... it just does what it wants, after you have changed one task.
Sorty by Job... Change Char XY from No Job to Guard Duty... and complete chaos. (if its a problem with the code.. just don't sort after a change)

5) Science Skill... i played now for 30+h and I only got one char in my group with science above 6... but he has NO mechanics skill.. so i can't build armor -.- (because it needs Science to research in the workshop but you need atleast 1 point in Mechanics to unlock the Workshopmenue in wich you can resarch it)

If there are coming more Patches and new content, this game will be awsome.
Until then its great, and if you see it in a sale.. buy it.

(Maybee you noticed, im no native speaker, so please forgive me my mistakes)

reviewText: The world ended and I got to loot a Twinkie Snack Cake factory.  Best Christmas ever.  10/10 Would apocalypse again.\n\nSome crashing, but generally speaking just hitting quick save before changing zones made it a minor irritation.  Had the same trouble in Fallout back in the day.  It's almost nostalgic crashing, in a way.  Other than that, no major bugs for me to date.  For a more serious review, I give it a solid 7-8/10.  Graphics are reasonable, challenge level is reasonable so far, and the premise and execution are interesting.  No major UI irritations.   Story and character interactions are decent.  All in all it's a phenomenal concept that I can't believe hadn't been done in this form before.  If you like X-Com type turn based combat, it's a great entry in that genre.  If that's not really your bag, it's probably more of the 7/10 I gave it above.  Still well worth playing.

reviewText:
The game's released. It's been a rocky launch technically.They probably rushed it a bit too fast, but it's pretty solid. If you have the patience to put up with bugs and glitches you will find a good game here. The developer seems intent on stabilizing the game in that regard.

It's an interesting mix of survivalist group management and turn based tactical resolution. The combat AI is fairly linear (You aggro zombies and looters and they attack), but that works fine for this genre. My biggest complaint is that gun combat mechanics are VERY weak once you start fighting militia and rogue soldiers. It's the exact same run-n-gun AI from the early game except these guys have assault rifles, body armor, grenades, and a firm desire to expend all that in killing you.  Consider carefully before starting a campaign in Ironman mode.  The game keeps you on rails to start with limited options, but that opens up as you go.

For me the game's become more rewarding the longer I've played. I like it a lot.

reviewText:
A very good idea which unfortunately wasnt executed well enough. therefore I can not recommend it to others.

The game was released before it is ready, probably due to sales season.

In an early access you expect bugs, but in the (finished!!) version the amount of bugs were immense. I am not going to list all, as there are forums for these. but I will go through some bugs that ruined my experience below.

Good sides,
Turn based, tactical combat (not great as there is not cover system etc, but decent)
Survival (in the first few weeks you really have to fight for each chocolate bar and manage parts and morale) later on they become irrelevant.
open world and a big map.

Graphics
Graphics are old but i like it anyway, I am not after shiny textures. Gameplay matters for me.

Audio
Audio is unfortunately quite poor as music variety is quite limited and static, and there is almost no voice in the game. Characters on levels communicate with subtitles over their heads, which you can easily miss if you are looking elsewhere. There is no message log (like in fallout). There is a combat log which could use some improvement. Sounds effects are below decent.

Gameplay.
Pathfinding and AI in general is terrible. My characters kept sliding to their destination often through walls. Enemies can also sometimes shoot through obstacles. Enemies can knock down your entire squad without a direct line of sight, using a single granade. (maybe they have thermal vision, which isnt implemented in the game :)  )
Interface could really use some polish. there is almost no info on statuses, just an icon which doesnt tell you if that character has reduced strength or perception, etc...
Armor in late game is too strong both for you and your enemies. Assault rifles can have problems without critical hits. Zombies are only a threat during first weeks, later on they become a joke, which destroys the mood for a zombie game.

Minor bugs are somewhat ok.
However, after hours of battling 10+ soldiers/mercs with full armor and assault rifles (to combat is slow, which I like as it is expected in such a genre), to crash to desktop on the last soldier is not fun. dont know about others but I have had so many CTDs. (dont tell me to update my graphics driver, or restart my computer)

The quests are also quite poorly made in the sense that the choice you make earlier is not reflected to the next day and people in the shelter complain (or are sick) as if you made the other choice in the crisis event a few days ago. quests dont get ticked off, or people in shelter keep saying the same things over and over.

The game is based Looting and keeping your people safe/well fed/ healthy. However in order to loot large maps I had to return to them 10 times.

I dont want to sound so harsh (although I probably did with all the critism). it is  a small company and I appreciate that they try to bring old turn /squad based RPG back to life.  it was just an unfinished product with a lot of bugs released earlier than it should have been. if they lack manpower, they should have waited a bit more to polish the game.

reviewText:
Some people will say it's unfinished. It's true.
Some people will say it's buggy and rough. It's true too.
But the REAL truth is - it's an old-school RPG masterpiece, with a great potential, made by a little group of people, who are constantly fixing the bugs and planning to expand the game even more.
It's not Skyrim. It's not Witcher 3. It's simple, and yet surprisingly addictive.
If you like Fallout 1-2, X-Com and Jagged Alliance - this game is definitely for you.

reviewText: Game has some bugs but overall it has been well worth the money.  Basically it is similiar to the original X-Com in combat mechanics and has some neat base management elements.  The game also mixes in the need to get various resources and adds crisis events so that just when you think you safe things can take a turn for thr worse very quickly.  Add in the zombie theme and the narratives and overall it is an great game for those of us who enjoy this kind of game play.  It is a very old school style of game so it may not be for everyone but I have loved it so far.

reviewText:
Despite the lack of polish, glitches, crashes, character clipping, erratic character movement, minimal sound, frustrating dialogue options with seeminlgy no results and constantly moody NPCs, Dead State has really got it's hooks into me. At it's heart, it's a fantastic game idea which I can't put down.

Trying to coordinate the daily run(s) to grab supplies and, more than likely, get hurt a lot by both the undead and the living whilst trying to unearth valuable supplies, antibiotics and gas in particular, whilst also ensuring that you've got the right people doing the right jobs to upgrade your base is highly engaging. Finding the two antibiotics that you desperately need on the last looter that you down really gives you that excitement that all good games provide.

Is it finished? No, not by a long shot. But can I work with that? Yes. That being said, I also cannot wait for the final, polished version. For someone who has had a 15 year hiatus from old school PC gaming, I was lured back by Wasteland 2 and have been well and truly sucked in since. If the devs can get Dead State up to the same level of quality that the guys behind Wasteland 2 achieved, that would make me a very, very happy man.

Double Bear, please keep the work going. You've got the bare bones of a fantastic game. It just needs a really good wax on the top coat.

reviewText:
Awful. Was suckered into this by almost all positive reviews; seems peculiar that those ones popped up early, and most reviews since have been damning (and rightly so). Would be surprised if those positive ones were legit, based on their claims and timing.

-This game has basically non existent sound design. Barely any music to speak of and no voiced characters (which I sometimes see as appropriate, but this game needs anything to liven up the dull repetitive dialog it has).
- Combat is supposedly like X Com or similar. It *wants* to be like that. But then it decides to have inconsistent rules, unclear directions, and a ridiculous scarcity of options or depth.
- It's suggested that the Base building mechanic might function like that in State of Decay. No. The big empty building you're given remains as such.
- I will readily accept that games needn't look good. But this one has a complete lack of polish, and plays like it's still an Early Access game. Very disappointing.

I can't recommend this mess in any way, and hope other people aren't misled into getting this.

reviewText:
Before purchasing this game, you have to realise this is an INDIE title made by a small team with a small budget. It cuts some corners, it's not as polished as the bigger titles. Can you live with that? If yes, then it's a little gem of a game.

It's a turn-based zombie apocalypse fallout-esque loot the world" RPG. Like scavenging? Like old-school "dumb slow" zombies? Like exploring stuff and building up your home camp? This is it.

At the moment of this writting
date: be aware that there are still quite a few bugs in the game
recommended: but most of them are minor or can be overlooked and the game is still enjoyable. However
hoursPlayed: the devs have been very visible and present and it's obvious they are working on those right now; expect many patches in the weeks to come.\n\nIt's not a tactical combat game; the combat is not as integrated as some dedicated game like X-Com. Don't go in expecting a ton of tactical combat options
voteText: as almost everything is organic
helpfulPercent: and battle is closer to chess than an actual firefight. Movement and positioning are as important as the type of equipment you bring to the table
votesHelpful: and personally I like it that way; there's no artificial game effects
votesTotal: everything is part of the way you handle your squad. Getting swarmed by zombies? Pull back and use a choke point. Getting mowed down by human enemies with guns? Move behind cover and force them to come into melee range
votesFunny: or pull them into the nearby pack of zombies
commentsCount: etc.\n\nThe rest of the game contains a lot of dialogue and decision-making. Dealing with your ever-growing pack of survivors keeps you on edge
column16: as you never know what kind of event is going to pop up each day

reviewText:
This game should be much more fun than it is. All the pieces are there, but the fun seems just out of reach. Interface awkwardness is one of the biggest hindrances in the game. The story and the feel of the game are great and there is massive potential here, but the devs really need to make a few improvements to make the game more accessable and therefore more fun.

I almost didn't want to recommend this, because that's like giving the devs permission to leave this game in what I have to say is an unfinished state, despite the fact that it's been 'released'. I want so much to immerse myself in the game, but frustrating bugs and poorly designed mechanics keep pulling me back out. In short, this game really lacks the refinement needed to call it 'released'. To be clear, I am NOT comparing this to modern AAA titles, in fact I play mostly indie games, but this game still needs some love to be not held back by design issues.

You can expect a classic Fallout-esque RPG experience, with sadly few interface improvements over those older generations of games. The biggest dissapointment is that the crafting and base improvement mechanics seem so thus far to be completely on-rails and thus much less engaging or fun than they could be. This style of combat system has also come very far since those days, yet this game encorporates none of those advances.

If this was a base 100 rating system and not yes/no, I'd probably give it 72/100.

reviewText:
There are dead people attacking you. There is a shelter you need to manage. There are dilemmas to handle. There  are rouge military and police. What is there not to like?

Looting and building the shelter is fun. So is handling the whiny survivors. As my character evolves I pick different followers for the looting missions. I find horses, upgrade the car to use the trunk and so on. I really liked the atmosphere and the challenge.

I am an optimizer. The game got a bit too easy too quick and there isn't (so far) a difficulty setting. Given I haven't finished the game yet (I am at day 35 - my impression is that it will go to 100) I cannot say if there will be more surprises yet. I have not visited every location, nor found every follower. But regardless I have had a lot of time and I want to congratulate the indie developers for adding this piece of well tasting candy to the bland world of mass produced computer games.

Money well spent! Kudos.

reviewText: I picked this game up because it seemed like a decent zombie RPG, which very few seem to exist except for some crap subscription ones. I found the price a bit steep, but I believe eventually with more content (multiplayer even?) this game has real potential to be the next Dayz.\n\nOverall I'd give this game an 8.5/10, it's far from perfect but pretty damn fun and unique.

reviewText:
You've probably played a lot of zombie games over the past few years, the market is flooded with them, but trust me when I say Dead State is worth your time.

Taking the idea of old-school turn-based RPGs and giving them an undead twist, DoubleBear has created a game that insanly fun and just the right level of challenging.

If you are in any way a fan of either zombies or surivial games, then DS is going to have something to keep you interested. Instead of being rewarded for mowing down hoards of zombies with impossible weapons, you gain your experience by improving your shelter, helping survivors, and picking up whatever small creature-comforts you can while you walk across a large and dangerous landscape looking for food, weapons, and any friendly faces you can come across.


Dead State is by no means a perfect game, but it's one that I find myself coming back to quite a lot. Even now, bugs are being fixed, features are being added, and everything about the game is improving. I can not urge you enough to give this game a try, even if your taste in zombie games has gone a bit stale.
voteText: 9 of 20 people (45%) found this review helpful

reviewText:
I rarely bother to write reviews, even for games that I enjoy, so understand that for me to bother putting pen to paper (so to speak) means that I am blown away.

Dead State is an incredible RPG; it's everything that I want and look for in a roleplaying game. This indie title blows contemporary AAA RPGs out of the water. The turn-based combat offers lots of options and tactics. The map roaming with spontaneous Point of Interest discovery harkens back to Fallout 1 & 2. The decibel system, which shows you how much noise you're making, encourages you to be creative instead of running in to every fight with guns blazing; the last thing you want is to attract more zombies. The stronghold improvements that you can make, and managing the morale of the people you lead, makes this game about more than just killing.

Take a hike, Bioware. DoubleBear just showed you who's the RPG master.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

I admit to being a sucker for almost any game with zombies in it, and not all of them are great. But this title has a lot of originality and potential. The foremost I'd like to point out is the leveling system. The food and resources you bring into your shelter count as experience gained. So leveling is dependant on your ability to obtain what the shelter needs to survive instead of just grinding XP on zombies and looters which is very refreshing after years of playing rpg's. The characters you can interact with feel alive and well written. Which makes me excited for when we start to see more dialogue interaction added to the game.

I preordered this game well over a year ago, and while this game has taken a long time to get to beta; In my own opinion it was well worth the wait. Not all of the shelter upgrades work yet, and I've only run into one bug that has caused trouble during gameplay which is when the camera gets stuck outside of the border of an area. The game seems to run remarkably stable, as I've had only one crash after 14 hours of play. My only real gripe isn't a bug, but a current feature in the game. If you don't return to the shelter before midnight, the survivors will supposedly give up on you and it's an instant game over. This doesn't feel very realistic, and should be changed.

That said, this game is hardly feature complete. This is an early beta so if you buy, that's what you should expect. I have had a blast playing so far. I like the combat; I like the leveling system, and the writing is good in my own opinion. I expect a lot from this game in the future, and I'll keep on playing it as updates come out.

reviewText:
I was looking forward to this. So far I must say it is a good effort but beside that it should still be in early access, I don't think it is priced properly. I am all about helping indie devs but for $29.99 I would expect something better. This game is lacking in most areas. To name a few:

1. I did not find a way to remap controls. WASD it is... I guess.
2. Managing your base and the interface choices the devs made are just non intuitive, and cumbersome. You need to walk to certain rooms just to access a certain menu i.e. the job board. Why? How is this a good choice from the player's perspective? There are many great examples out there. Why not just copy one?
3. The tactical part is weak compared to Jagged Alliance or other turn based games. Run to close distance, shoot, or smash, repeat... No hiding, no sneaking, no crouching, no aiming. Really weak...
4. Player and NPC skills are overly simplified.
5. Tactical maps are very small.

The good:
1. The only zombie turn based out there right now. At least I am not aware of another one.
2. Graphics are not bad for an indie game.
3. I like the way survival is managed. You need to keep scavenging, manage morale, etc. I find this original.

Overall... I still can't recommend this at full price. I would say this is a good $15-20 game. Not $29.99! I am sure the bugs will get fixed, but there are major flaws in gameplay.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

This game is very much still in early access. They released the game far too early in order to grab a slice of the Christmas sales.

The game is playable in it's current state, but it still feels a lot like playing a beta. Lots of graphical glitches, lots of UI anomolies (even during character creation), maps that involve stairs are still very buggy.

The game itself sees you as a survivor joining a survivors commune and attempting to...well...survive. You can upgrade various rooms in your base to provide medical facilities etc, but they haven't bothered to create a seperate graphic for the room before and after the facilities creation. So on day one the base looks exactly the same as it will once you've fully upgraded it.

The game is limited in that there are a finite number of areas, and once you've fully looted an area there is no reason to go back to it. Zombies don't respawn and while there are some random encounters they are still very buggy, areas are reused and once you've visited one area type and looted it, any subsequent encounters that use that area type spawn fully looted so are pointless (you get no XP" for kills).

I've played through this game 4 times now
date: and have always hit a game breaking bug and stopped. Why do I recommend this game then? I'm still holding on to hope that they keep working on it and get it properly release ready
recommended: it has a lot of potential."

reviewText:
Dead State seems to be an unfinished product. I really started out _wanting_ to like this game; feeling the need to play a good RTS game for quite some time and was left disappointed.

The Interface is, on its surface, intuitive-looking but is in reality quite difficult to use. As an example, when your main character is fatigued, it is not recommended they be used for 12 hours due to a 25% penalty to dodge and accuracy. There is no way for you to use a different survivor to go on a mission for supplies, etc. The game's passing time" (fast-forwarding time whilst in the shelter) doesn't seem to affect this.

Combat is awkward
date: clumsy and frustrating. Reloading takes too many action points on the occasion where you're desperate enough to use a gun and as for melee combat: good luck. 80% of the time your character fails to connect with your victim leaving you swinging wildly at your attacker/victim and burning up precious action points which could have been spent healing yourself/party member if you're lucky enough to find bandages. On the opposite end of combat
recommended: your attacker/victim is almost guaranteed to hit you. You'll spend much of your time on a losing battle regardless of what weapon you're carrying. I do like the fact the melee weapons need to be at an adjacent square in order to attack but getting within range early on is difficult due to no armour
hoursPlayed:
limited action points for attacking and not really having faith your attack effort will pay out at all. I once was in a combat situation where I was attacking 3 or 4 times a turn and ended up missing 100% of the time for *5 turns!* Needless to say I loaded from an earlier save and avoided the area all together.

Party member's stand idly whilst attackers approach you without so much as mentioning you're about to be attacked.

Random encounters are a literal roll of the dice. You might find yourself equally matched (yet still using the awkward combat system) or completely outnumbered/overpowered and may as well load from an earlier save. I've gotten into the habit of saving just prior to venturing out into the world due to the complete randomness of the encounters.

The games manual touts not being able to gain experience by simply killing zombies or using any other skills directly. The way you actually level up your characters is by assigning them tasks on the job board or picking up enough of X item to meet the needs of the various types of goals. While this might seem like a good idea in theory (an interesting way to make the player level up and gain skill) it falls short due to the items being discovered are left to random change when your "zone" seed is generated. This makes gaining skill points feel like a long-dragging chore instead of a rewarding experience. Doubly so if you cannot guarantee your party members are going to be in fighting shape for their randomness that is the combat system.

Overall DoubleBear has done a pretty good job but there are some things that indeed need tweaking. The combat system is fun when you're able to actually affect the outcome of the situation but for the time being it seems to be completely random and demoralizing.
"

reviewText:
Early Access Review

This game gets better and better with every update. It can be tough and stressful. Requires patience and strategizing. There are a few features that can be annoying but only really add to the strategy, such as the movement squares in confined spaces. Be prepared to have your allies in the right position or lose them. Quicksave will be your best friend.

It would be nice if they added another few or even another 7 days to the early access, but it's good to play through here and there to see what's changed with the updates. Will take about 4-5 hours to beat in its current state (doing everything right) but it used to take a bit more as some areas have been consolidated and / or removed. There are now customizable characters and random encounters that can vary the game time depending on how you roll your character. You'll probably wanna play through again just to perfect your interactions with characters to reach that kind of game time.

Some of what I've said will only be relevant for now, the next update could change a few more things, but the core of the game is damn solid and I can't wait until it's finished.

reviewText:
Updated 1/24/2015:
TL;DR: Dead State remains quite combat focused, and while there is a lot of interaction to be had much of it may not be seen in a single play through the game. For a strategy RPG created on such a limited budget by a small team I consider it to be an entertaining experience that was well worth my time and money, and look forward to seeing what Doublebear does in the future.

Dead State remains an entertaining experience, but although it is released it still has some balance issues. Late game there is practically no reason to use the apocalypse armor over the Advanced Tactical Vest, which is a required component of the apocalypse armor. Combat can be rather enjoyable, but for experienced players it may be too easy. That being said, I've seen numerous complaints on the forums that it was too difficult, so I suppose they've struck a reasonable balance. I'm looking forward to the release of Iron Man modes, and although the game has passed the 1.0 mark Doublebear continues to flesh out the experience and address issues in the game itself.

If you're new to the strategy RPG genre and are looking for an experience that can be completed without a lot of combat this is probably not that title. Conversely, if you're adept at playing Strategy RPGs and want consistent end game challenges, this is also not that title. Doublebear has managed to create a fairly engaging game that revolves around both combat and crisis events and ally management. Unfortunately for the experienced player, they may never lose any ally and therefore won't have a problem getting so much morale that they never experience the darker aspects of the title. Meanwhile those who aren't able to manage the combat portion of the game may well lose so many allies that they have a hard time keeping allies.

I enjoy Brian Mitsoda's writing style, and overall I found Dead State to be a very entertaining experience. That being said



Dead State is shaping up to be a really enjoyable zombie survival RPG, and while it has tactical combat, the primary emphasis is going to be on the survivors and their personalities. Making sure that everyone has some semblance of normalcy in their otherwise upended lives and navigating the perils of the post-disaster world will eventually entail a lot of the experience. As the game stands, a lot of it is about the combat. It makes sense that they would want to expose the most replayable aspect of the game and get users opinions on it, and while it does strongly resemble the Age of Decadence on which the game has been built AoD has varied enough options for tactical combat that Dead State has a solid foundation on which to build in that regard.

As of right now (6/29/2014), the first seven days is all that is open to players for exploration and testing, but in the not so distant future plans are to open up more content for eager fans who want more. While I have only played through the first seven days twice I am likely to wait on that update before I dive back into Dead State. While the combat and potential choices in the first seven days is appealing, I'm rather more interested in how the game unfolds with regards to various factions and additional allies. At the end of the day, the first seven days is a fun tactical experience released to acquire feedback on aspects of the game that are still able to be changed. The game will revolve largely around the shelter and keeping your survivors from killing one another or hating your leadership enough to fracture your group into factions that each pursue their own agendas.

If everything unfolds in the direction it seems to be heading, you could potentially apply a variety of the shelter aspects to another type of disaster and the transition from zombie apocalypse to plague or famine or the destabilization of the magnetic poles and ensuing havoc EM radiation would have on unshielded electronics and minus the scavanging expeditions where you had to bludgeon people to death with a baseball bat things could feasibly progress in a similar fashion.

I honestly love this game and cannot wait for the finishing touches and the complete game. Hurry, hurry.
Do I recommend this game? I must admit that I was reluctant to purchase an early access game but I really believe that the finished product will be well worth purchasing. So from me it’s a definite yes.
Happy skull cracking guys.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

Awesome game so far. As of this review, the game has been released only the day before, and is only the demo of the first 7 days. The premise is fairly simple: basically, hoarde loot from missions on an overview map while also assigning jobs and tasks to npcs in your bases, which includes being able to take them on missions with you. Pretty good concept, and definitely fills a niche and itches a scratch of building a defense against zombies and hoarding loot [food, weapons, ammo, etc.]

Approximately a 7.5/10 at the moment, I'd live to give it an 8 or 9 but it could use more polish and so far its in early access beta with a limit on game time. At present, it is really good, but I definitely look forward to the finished product.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

Very enjoyable, considering the game is currently in early access, looking forward to the full release!

I finished this 7-day version of the game in about 7 hours, but I haven't explored a couple of locations yet, so I guess it could take somewhere around 10 hours to complete this if you do everything. People claiming to have finished it in 40 minutes are either lying, or just rested or rushed through content every day without exploring anything. A single combat can last for 10 minutes or more.

The game is not finished yet, being early access, and it does have some bugs. I had about 5-6 crashes, and got stuck in combat once. It also lacks a lot of functions, that will be implemented later, like character creation.

The game puts you in a situation, where you, after surviving a plane-crash, becomes the leader of a small group of people, trying to survive during a zombie-apocalypse. You have a homebase that can be upgraded (but a lot of this is not available yet, I could only fix the fence and the well in this version of the game), and in order to get building materials, food, weapons, and other stuff essential for survival, you have to explore locations like a shopping mall, a church, a camping site and other places in your surroundings.

There's a lot of tension when exploring, death can be waiting around every corner, in the form of zombies, or armed and hostile looters. A careful approach is required, sneaking up on zombies, taking them out one by one, or avoiding them. It's also important to be quiet, guns are very effective, but the sound will attract more undead.

There are interesting things to discover (when exploring), and the world doesn't feel copy-pasted. Maybe you encounter a man who has barricaded himself inside his house, writing warnings trespassers will get shot" on the wall

reviewText:
I am not giving this game a Thumbs Down because it is a bad game.  I do so because it is not finished, and because I hope that it will be a better game six months from now.

I got my money's worth out of this game.  68 hours for a $30 game is worthwhile to me.  I am simply frustrated because I believe I would have enjoyed the game much more if I had played it after more bugs had been worked out, references to commented-out content had been removed or restored, and the pacing and event timers were changed.

This game felt much more like an Early Access title than a final build when I played it.  If, a few months from now, you see new reviews indicating that this game feels like a complete product, then I encourage you to check it out.  In its current state, this is not the best game that Dead State can be.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

This game impresses me more and more each time I play it, with the amount of content and play through that is avaiable. With the final release set for next month if you are thinking about buying it I would definitely get it come release.

This game sat on my wishlist for 3 months before I brought it because I was unsure about spending $30 on an early access game. When I finally brought it I did not regret it in the slightest and think it is well worth the $30.

There are so many aspects to the game, you have your main character with abilites and stats management and then the array of weapons you can use and the different attacks available for each weapon. then you can have specaility items, armour and your inventory management. This also crosses over into your party, managaing 3 more characters weapons, armour and inventory.

Travelling round the map you have a wide range of locations to visit, with different layouts and a wide variety of loot to find.

Intially i was not sure if i would like the turn based combat but quickly found this to not be an issue. You not only have to fight zombies, but wild dogs, and enemy npcs each brining there own separate style of combat. You also have travel options on the map running, horse riding and driving a car.

Base management is a whole differnt aspect in itself, building upgrades, assigning jobs, managinging moods keep you occupied while you are not out smashing heads!

This game combines all my favourite aspects of zombie/survival games and has so far provided me with hours of entertainment and I look forward to a whole lot more. (ps my steam hours do not cover my complete hours on this game).

reviewText:
Hmm, It's early (almost an hour) and I don't know about it. I only put a thumbs up as steam wouldn't let me just skip the thumbs review. I think others should give a chance.

Some thoughts though. Just my experience as a person who enjoys games and as a person who designs games as well. Take them for what they are : opinion.

UI - clunky. Should be intuitive, at the beginning of the game it says to go in some directory find some manual that's more in depth. What putting a tab in the game was too much trouble?

Reloading a gun - I don't even know how to do this. I thought it would be obvious like drag the correct ammo type on a gun. I have a snubnose .38, it says it takes .38 ammo - I think I should be able to A) right click or whatever and say load ammo B) drag and drop ammo on it C) I don't know, something else.

Instead I have no idea. Someone saying Well you need to read the manual" How about a nice cup of shut the hell up. Reallly.

I'm not asking for a hand holding - I hate that. I would at least like some idea of how the hell you are supposed to something basic like that.

Combat - clunky. It's trying to be xcom but it's not. The presentation of showing a zombie right next to you

the 3rd person rotating camera I'm actually ok with.


I can't say I recommend or not recommend this game.  I don't think a game should be a case of "Well you will get used to it" or "You need to read about this and that" or "Well you are not playing it right" or whatever lame excuse someone wants to cook up. A game should find the fun. Period.

reviewText: I really wanted to like this game. I've actually had in since it was in Alpha and just a one week demo. It's gotten considerably more content from then, but not much real polish. I like the idea of this game, but the execution of the design is rather clunky. First off, as people mentioned before, the interface leaves much to be desired. It's quite easy in the heat of combat to try to click on the HUD and accidentally move that character too far away to do anything useful in a single click. You are able to walk over dead bodies, but you're going to have a real hard time finding a spot that doesn't highlight the body to loot rather than the space below it to move on. Rotating the camera is necessary a lot of the time, especially when searching for hot spots where you can loot items, but a lot of the time it's in vain actually because there are usually very few places you can loot things from, although you do need to scour the whole map to find them. The turn-based/real time aspect is kind of weird in cases like where you're trying to break down a locked door. It goes into turn based for a second, makes noise, and the zombies in the area come to your location rather quickly. Like I appreciate trying to jump into combat faster but zombies aren't THAT quick. Another aspect that leaves much to be desired is the real time movement before combat. You can have up to 4 members of your team and they don't run that close together, they run sort of in a staggered formation that when you go into combat mode there's 1 person in the front that can attack and the rest are usually too far to do anything the first turn.

reviewText:
I like this game.

I always like a game where you build your character (RPG), build your community and survival is your driving force.
Combat is turn based tactical.
Community building is GUI only (via the white board in the cafeteria of the school)
There's a lot of depth and many ways to skin the cat.
The choices do matter (though you don't necessarily know what choices impact what)

Things I didn't like:
Not a lot of replay value. Unless you're an obsessive perfectionist, once or twice and you pretty much exhaust all of the choices.
Many of the choices are benign in nature, which make it difficult to tell which ones are important enough to impact the story.

reviewText:
Anyone who read my previous review of this will notice that I have changed my opinion. This is simply because the last post full release patch has fixed many issues and the developers continue to improve this product (the next big patch is due mid-late January). In my opinion it should have stayed Early Access until this latest patch.

This is a deep game that rewards patience in the early stages. You start out with just a handful of allies and very few options but as you venture further from your base, discover more locations, and find more survivors (who come with their own individual traits and problems) then things begin to get interesting. You can develop your base far more quickly and new options for addittional facilities start to appear as new survivors bring their unique skills to the table. Plot events progress in a similar manner with most being specifically linked to certain characters and your enjoyment of Dead State will snowball as you gain momentum.

Dead State is not an easy game to quantify in terms of genre; being a combination of man-management and resource allocation, Sims-like character appeasement, building development, open world exploration, and story-driven role play elements. But the CORE of the game is none of these things but rather an XCOM-like, turn based, tactical combat. And this last, despite being highly enjoyable when taken in context with everything else, still has a few rough edges. Regardless of its flaws (which are becoming increasingly less significant as the developers continue to listen to the community and improve the game) Dead State has finally flowered into something unique and satisfying IF you can push through its slow start. With the promise of further improvement in both game mechanics and extra content it has been turned from something best waited on to something you shouldn't really be without.

Previous score 67%, current score 82%, expected to finish in the high 90's.

reviewText:
This is a great turn based strategy game set during a zombie apocalypse. It plays very much like fallout 1 / 2 with an added twist of also developing a base filled with NPC characters. While the zombie plague leaves your members forced to scramble for supplies you will encounter human adversaries who are often much more dangerous foes.

The game also uses an interesting sound mechanic where to much noise can attract attention of zombies or looters. Break down a door with a sledge hammer and you can bring down a wailing horde of zombies... or a looter double barrel.

The game has been polished up nicely since early access. You may still get a bug here and there or a crash... but my experience has been very good.

I am happy to say I kickstarted this project and the game came out great.

If you are a fan of old school turned based games and into CRPG this game is great. A refreshing setting for an RPG while also having great strategy and downtime while in your base. Easy 9/10 from me.

reviewText:
When i first started playing this game I was caught hook line and sinker. I love the 3 genre it combines (zombie survival, classic rpg and non-linear) and thought that this was going to be one of my favorite games. However as you progress through the game you quickly realize how many flaws there are not only in coding, but also game mechanics. As for positives about the game...really nothing. The only reason why I was able to tolerate it for 20 hours is like I said, I am a sucker for the genre but as for the game in and of itself there is nothing that it brings to the table that can't be fulfilled from dozens of other games without all the bugs and hassle.

Cons-
Player Character has 1 line of backstory...don't get me wrong, I love customization, but backstory for the main character is vital in an RPG. The only succesfull rpg series I can think of with limited backstory is the elder scrolls series, but those games use the prologue to shape the character's development. This game on the other hand has one of the most limited and useless prologues I have ever played.

The most repetitive turn based combat I have ever seen. All of the zombies are the same, the human npc have terrible AI with nothing intruiging about their movements, and the biggest baddest npcs in the game are a joke since they have such high armor class, if the player goes into a fight in the same armor its practically just flailing at each other for a few turns doing nothing strategic...sort of like a failed rpg hack and slash combo

The game uses a failed view system called fog of war" which basically means that if you aren't in line of sight of an enemy then you can't see them and they can't see you
date: but it does not work for this game. In a turn based rpg if you can't find an NPC that you accidently aggroed you might be running around tiles with limited action points just wasting away your life.\n\nHorrible shelter morale system- some of the NPC express themselves almost like they are in an emotional polarity shift

reviewText:
Dead State has gone a bit under the radar of most people, and that is a shame, because even though I got wind of it too late to Kickstarter-back it, I bought it the moment it was fully released and I haven't regretted it for one minute, except for the fact that it's eating up virtually all of my free time.

Simply put, Dead State is an amazing game. Granted, it's not bug-free (though no real game-breaking bugs so far) and the interface can be a chore (as well as an enigma at times), but once you're used to its quirks, Dead State becomes an incredibly addictive and involving experience.

Yes, we're all tired of zombie games, but I will gladly make an exception for Dead State, and I promise, so will you. If I describe it as an interesting cross between Fallout, State of Decay and X-Com: Enemy Unknown, then it should probably be enough to make the hairs of any serious gamer stand on end. And rightly so, because the game pulls off all its aspects perfectly. And it even has a well implemented 'timer' mechanism: you're pressed for time since morale decays and food supplies dwindle daily, but on the other hand, you don't feel like you're being rushed all the time. There's no clock counting down, no constant reminders. You set your own pace, and as long as you don't waste your days doing nothing, you should usually be fine. I scavenged every day, trying to take on at least two locations per run, which is as far as you can stretch your daytime (and your characters' backpacks!), but I am currently sitting on a comfortable stockpile, so there's no need to micromanage and fuss over every single hour of every single day. But you know damn well that you can't sit still either.

During your travels, you'll meet other survivors. Some you'll just stumble across, others will even knock on your door of their own accord. While you can turn them away, it's ill-advised to do so. Sure, every survivor you take in means another mouth to feed, but they pay off their food consumption by working for you. You can give them jobs yourself, like putting them in the scavenger party, making them construct shelter upgrades, guard the fence, and all other kinds of work. And as the days go on, the needs of your shelter grow as well, making it critical to recruit every survivor you can find. Every survivor has his or her own backstory, dialogue, demands and specializations, making for a diverse and lifelike feel of the shelter, where you have to assign jobs based on their capabilities.

The shelter itself can be upgraded, X-COM: EU style, to provide benefits and make new things possible. You can construct facilities like a workshop, a garage, a rooftop garden and even a chicken coop and a recreation room. All of these upgrades, however, take time and parts, and you'll find yourself strapped for the latter very often, so don't think you'll be able to just build everything from the get-go, it requires careful decision making, especially since unexpected events will also require manpower and parts, so you need to keep some in reserve. This makes for a paced game experience, where you'll constantly have things to strive for, instead of falling into the build-everything-then-be-stuck-with-idle-workers-and-no-real-goal"-trap many similar games have perished in.

The scavenging party

reviewText: Very bad game.  Bad controls, cliche characters, repetative and way too much done to add difficulty just to drag the game out.  You need fencing, but you can't salvage the miles and miles of fencing you will see in the cut-and-paste locations you visit.  Need parts to fix a car? Zero chance the missing parts are salvageable from the dozens of cars you will pass.   A book store had three books and two magazines, just to keep resorces scarce, and a town only had two stores in it?  Zombies are attracted to noise, sure, but clearing an area first before you make the noise should mean it's safe.  Instead, zombies appear out of thin air in a town with a population density of 10 people per square mile.  Lazy and cliche game design all the way around coupled with a crappy combat system.

reviewText:
I can definitely see where the positive reviews come from and the brief amount of negetive reviews appear.
Dead state looked very very promising when I started playing it. I had various bugs and crashes occur which I thought: ok this is probably just because this is a game in progress. Then I realize its a fully released game and I start to hope the devs fix the problems. I notice I continually have updates for this game which encourages me to continue playing the game. Overall however I've slowly felt like I'm beating a dead zombie with this game. So here's how the story goes.

1st Game Play: Awesome. Loving it. Seems like this is going to occupy a good week to 2 weeks of my time and probably have good replay value. Get somewhat far into the game and it crashes... continuously.
2nd Game Play: After an update I load up the game only to find that my previous saved game has been completely corrupted and thought: "oh well
date:
Ill just start over. Its got the official release. Maybe there is a bunch of different additions to the game. NO. NO THERE ISN'T. But I digress.
3rd Game Play: I know the 2nd game play didn't really end anywhere other than I just stopped playing it for a couple days. But with the 3rd and final game play (atleast until the bugs are fixed) I get further into the game than I've gotten in the prior 2 game plays. Yet now for some reason the travel by horse has become slower than traveling by foot and for some reason when I add NPCs to my "search party" they don't come with. I don't quite know how to fix this bug (if it is a bug) but its annoyed me to point where I just stopped playing and decided I'll wait it out.

So to make a long review short. This game needs some real fixin' And until then. I don't really see the point in playing the game unless you're going to be able to enjoy it the full way through. Please please please fix this game up. I really do enjoy it (for the most that I can play) and would like to see the future potential in it."

reviewText:
Early Access Review

Warning: At the moment of this review the game is still in beta, we are aware that several features may be missing/broken/incomplete and will not take this into consideration for the current review. It may be updated once a full release is made.

Dead State ... Me... And then there is you, reading and asking yourself : Should I purchase this or not? Let me start with the facts: Dead State is a survival RPG where civilization has collapsed due to a pendemic turning people into zombies. There are still other humans out there but most of them are hostile. If you don't like zombies, survival and exploration then this game ain't for you. For those still with us and asking what's the game?, let's elaborate with the following key points :

-The game is set in 3rd person and most if not all actions are issued with the mouse. So no random shooting, gun blazing, taking shots -NO-
-But there is combat of course. Combat is turn based and relies on characters stats as well as probabilities (luck).
-RPG elements are not classic : You won't get points for how many you slaughter but for the objectives you accomplish. Therefore you shall focus on survival objectives rather than bloodbath.
-Combats are not meant for lenghty bloodbath and encounters for several reason 1. The noise meter limits greatly the use of firearm, to the point where it becomes a last resort kind of option 2. Injuries are common and healing will take valuable equipment and action points (AP) 3. You will rarely encounter a horde or group unless you bust the noise meter (hitting 200 will spawn zombie in the sector) 4. Combats are not exactly thrilling and are often not at your advantage. For all those reasons it is best to avoid combat.
-The map is divided in sectors. To leave a sector you must access the entry points (usualy on the corners of the sector). Once you do that you can select the travel option and open the large map where you can travel to various areas, idly wonder randomly or go back to your shelter (a public high school ... ugh school of all the places in an apocalypse really?).
-Speaking of the shelter it is a microsociety with a struggle for power, where everyone has needs and where you can eventually assign tasks to members. Shall they join you on the field or repair something or clean around etc... You will have to set a daily objective. This society has needs as mentionned, the first one being food. You will often find yourself packing every piece of food you will find on your trip. You also want luxury items to bring up morale. Finding building material is also a priority since there are many things to build and repair.  Other loots include weapons, ammos, protection, fuel, tools and medical gear. Quick mention to antibiotic : A member of the group who becomes plagued with zombie infection cannot be cured with antibiotic, he can be preserved as human. Therefore each contaminated member will consume 1 antibiotic a day. Since antibiotic are rare, you might have to end up asking some of them to leave. Ugh sad.
-Last word about the shelter: You won't have much to decide about the building location or else. It is that building, end of the topic.
-Save often is a precious advice. Loots can be somewhat random but opponents too. Running into a troop of bikers armed to the teeth will often lead to all of your characters death and if you main character (you) die, it's game over.

It's time for What's the Game pro's and con's
Pro's :
-Rich variety of weapons and gears
-Decisions have an impact
-Real feeling of crisis and survival
-Good ambiance
-Open-world style game with good replayability
-Interesting concept
-Loots don't respawn, feeling realistic

Con's :
-Combat system can be frustrating and dull
-Graphics could be re-worked (Feels like 2001 graphics)
-Limited party size (4 members)
-No real sneaking/crawling/stealth mode

Our final verdict:
Is it worth buying ? Wait for the full version unless you get it from a bundle (Humble bundle or else). For those of you willing to put the cash in, it's a good game that will cost you a movie ticket but offer you many many more hours of fun. Decent game but not a hit.

reviewText:
I would like to warn anyone who is thinking of buying this game - it is definitelly 100% overpriced.
Please do not take me wrong. It is a decent game which would definitelly find it's fans. It has a cool system of interpersonal relashionships management, lots of loot to play with, RPG traits and HQ development. But. The graphics are ridiculosly simple. The characters animation robotic. The choice of choosing a static picture to represent your character without any animation is pathetic. I can not care what is goin to happen to this pictuers who are constantly popping out lots of BS. Also, I came to the point when my character's face in all the dialoges was one of a Caucasian guy but there  was a black guy running in the game itself. So incongruent and off-hand the whole approach to the graphics is in this game. Another big thing, the combat system lacks depth, it is all about getting to the correct distance from the zombies to hit them first. From the variety of weapons the actual choise of combat options is limited. Due to the fact that more powerful weapon requires more action points to spend, it seems that all the weapon differes in the name but pretty much the same effectiveness wise.
All in all, Dead State is not a bad game. Moreover, it is still in alfa. However, animation wise as well as the character development wise it falls miles and miles  low from even TellTales Walkind dead. Similar to that, combat wise it has nowhere near to stand to brilliant Xcom enemy series.
When you start thinking that there are such games on the market like Alien Isolation, new Dragon Age and even Evil Within which you can buy for roughly the same price Dead State seems to be undoubtedly overpriced. Consider yourself warned.

reviewText:
I like tactical RPGs like X-Com, Jagged Alliance, etc.  So I thought I'd like this game, and I did for a while.  Until the complete lack of polish started to get to me.  I don't FEEL like I'm in a zombie apocalypse.  I feel like an errand boy for a bunch of whiners.  Characters in the game are always the same, they always want the same thing (deoderant, coffee, batteries) which raises their mood level (gotta keep morale high).  However since they are unchanging, it feels like I'm constantly grinding to keep their mood high by bribing them with things I find.

For example, the one cop you start with has a gun but he says he's never used it before.  You can ask him for it but he refuses.  You can continue to ask him for it forever and he will always refuse.  I don't understand why these dialogue options exist if they do nothing.  This game is also quite flat and has very little in the way of randomization.  If you restart the game you'll find all the same loot in all the same places.  I do understand that this is an indie developer, however I don't think they should've undertaken such an ambitious project.

I payed full price for this game, but after playing it, I'd say I'd pay about 10$ for it.

reviewText:
Beware of Spoilers

I helped fund Dead State through Kickstarter and genuinely wanted to like the game but in the end I have to give it a thumbs down.

The combat isn't the worst but I felt it missed some golden opportunities. Specific target locations on enemies' bodies(We are always told to go for the zombie's head, you know...), a better cover system, and overwatch would all have been nice additions.

The maps were believable but grew old after a while. Been in one pharmacy, been in them all. There were a few exceptions to this rule but not enough.

The crafting system was nicely done, but somewhat hard to gain access to. The science lab in particular required very specific characters or the player aligning his character's skills in a very specific way. I also wanted more items but I understand that may come down the line.

Dialogue was spotty in some ways. There is quite a bit of profanity. Some places it is quite believable, like where one character( a D.J.) rants about how depraved mankind has gotten but other places it was overdone. Many of the conversations contained misfires about events that had already occurred. Some of the characters seem more straw than others. I do want to congratulate the writers on the shelter survivor Davis. He was totally believable as a former firefighter injured in the line of duty who won't let a wheelchair slow him down. He was one of my favorites and a an all too rare character with a physical challenge. DoubleBear didn't shy away from emotional or mental challenges either and my hat is off to them for it.

I did think the characters were a bit whiny given what all I was bringing in. But hey that might have been just me.

The survival aspects were thought out but again I thought more could be done. With so many unburied bodies the diseases that would have been percolating... Zombie bites should not have been the only risk of infection.

Don't look for super vivid graphics or ultra cool sound. I personally thought the visuals were okay. Sound... iffy.

Again I should stress that this game was made on a Kickstarter budget and had limits but I still feel it could have been so much more.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

Been stalking this game sense before they had a kickstarter and was excited to be able to play some of it.
Though I did run out of things to do in the first seven days, the game lived up to everything I have been waiting for. I did however find a handful of bugs that I'm hoping will be resolved by the time the full game is released.

Things to notice before purchase:
The full game is listed at $30 when released if you know you want it, now is a better time to purchase.
Find the manual before running game. It doesn't appear anywhere noticeable after download and is online for anyone curious about how the game runs. I skimmed it at best due to its long length. But might be an insight for someone unsure on this game.
This demo only runs the first 7 days with limited things to do. I wouldn't purchase it unless you are sure you want the full version which is still under development. If you can wait for the full version to come out a demo will be free at that time.
Be prepared for bugs. Though annoying they didn't manage to ruin my gameplay but could easily become frustrating.

Personally I loved being able to control my own group as I loot the surrounding areas for all they're worth and would easily recommend the game to anyone with a love of zombie survival.
