reviewText: Early Access Review\n\nGraphically Dead State is on par with the general expectation of a top down turn based game. in it's present release state it should be considered a nothing more than a liner prequel story 7days before the main game play that would come with the main release. Mechanically the game is sound, with exception given to the combat system which has a tendency to lock up the game's global mechanics; this commonly occurs when engaging the Zombies or those things" as they are commonly referred to within the story line; as the word zombie seems to be taboo with the developers when they were writing the games story line. The use of the word "Demo" within the main menu screen has thus far caused no end of trouble for the developers recently. As this has implied that this present itineration would not be update or replace with a full version upon its release. I would implore the developers clarify in pure and simple terms
date: what will happen to this release when full version is deployed and to replace the word "demo" in the main menu with "prequel". until the present bugs are fixed and clarification is given in a formal announcement on stream; I cannot in recommend this game to others. despite its obvious potential to be a really decent game."

reviewText:
Early Access Review

so do we get the full game considering we paid for it? i've never seen it not work like that but it's a little confusing considering... the game itself is everything i wanted from dead state, its a little hard to figure out (actually almost impossible) but it runs like a dream, the graphics are above expectation and the style is rare but golden. you don't get many decent turn based games these days. i have recomended this game to my friends, but i have also warned them that it is a demo at the moment and i'm not sure if the full release will incur a second charge, even if i personally consider this early view of the game worthwhile. but if you decide that your going to charge me, or anyone else an extra $30 on top of the early access game fee (which it doesn't look like you will but based on comments i have seen so far i have to mention) i at least have to post this message as a warning

download at your own risk... this may end up another world Z

reviewText:
Early Access Review

(the time played indicated doesn't reflect the real hours spent on this game because I only play offline)

This game is a MUST HAVe if you are fan of survival zombies + lots of exploration on a quit big map + ressources gathering + team management + strategy (how the ressources should better be used, which PNJ should be let join the team of not (more manpower but also more mouth to feed, and so on), also what should be the short term/long term strategy to adopt) + some crafting + turn based fights + old school look (a bit like Wasteland 2 but slightly less good).

If you are not a fan of all that, this game is probably not going to fit your tastes.
But if you are fan of all that, you are really going to enjoy this game, even if it's still in Beta so still has a few bugs but nothing major as far as I can tell.

Personnaly I love it, so thanks a lot to the small studio that did it ! :-)

reviewText:
Early Access Review

First of all, let me say that I am very impressed with Dead State so far.  I love the concept, and the interface, and I can tell it's destined to become a great zombie/survival game.  It is clearly still a work in progress, but that doesn't bother me.  I wanted to write this review to give the developers some intel on the bugs I've encountered so far during gameplay, so hopefully they can be addressed in future updates.  I love the game, but find that it has gotten a little more glitchy and harder to successfully play since the release of the last update.  Please note that these are notes I have taken since I started playing, and some problems listed here may already have been fixed.  But I just wanted to note everything, just in case.  So here we go...My notes are as follows:
(1)  I wish you could split stacks of the same items in your inventory screen, so that you could easily split resources (like ammo) among party members or drop some (but not all) on the ground.  Right now, I feel like I have to load all the guns I have with my main character because I can't figure out how to divvy up ammo among party members, unless they each pick up some ammo for themselves here or there in scavving.  This also becomes an issue when dealing with weight, since some characters can carry more than others, and it could be possible to split heavier items to distribute the weight better among the party members.
(2)  In my game, when there are battle effects to a party member (which appear as small icons to the right of the party member's face on the left of the screen), I cannot hover over those icons to determine what effects they are having, and how to cure them.  Instead, I have to have to open the game manual (or just use my memory) to be able to figure it out.  It would be easier if I could gain info while hovering over these status icons.
(3) The stats for weapons in inventory should show how many action points are required to use the weapon (at least for basic attacks).  It's helpful to know, before you equip something, that it takes 7 AP to use, rather than 3.
(4)  On the job board, the stats for party members should show their HP, so I can be sure to assign the healthiest members of my group to active party/scouting/scavving/fighting duty.
(5)  It would be nice if I could trade/provide equipment to various party members directly from the main storage shelf in the shelter, instead of having to equip them on the field with only items in my main character's inventory.  (Or if I could at least have a way to see the inventory of these other players while stationed in the shelter.)  I find it difficult to know what other party members are carrying, unless I've recently been in the field with them.
(6)  The pike weapon (the pitchfork) doesn't actually attack when mangle" is selected.  It simply uses 7 AP while nothing happens.
(7)  Priscilla's dialogue has some minor grammar errors:  "I barely every left my family's farm" should be "I barely ever left my family's farm" or "I barely even left my family's farm" and "I saw Todd's program and he preaced about tolerence" should be "I saw Todd's program and he preached about tolerence."
(8)  When asked to make a decision about whether to engage in water purification system repairs
date: I was only given the option to side with Vic and refuse to make the repairs.  I don't know if this was a glitch
recommended: or something that resulted from my negotiation or leadership skill levels
hoursPlayed: or maybe my relationships with Vic and Todd
voteText: or maybe my lack of appropriate stored resources.  But I thought I'd mention it anyways.\n(9)  When Max joined the group

votesHelpful: even though he was supposed to be recovering after we found him at the gate.  So it was weird when he "woke up" in the game for the first time

reviewText:
Early Access Review

Pretty much what it says it is... a demo. Not a whole lot to be done. Will be interesting to see what the final product looks like. As it stands; quite a few freeze-ups/bugs, and fights are so sloooooooooooooooow. (Could really use some faster animations.) Also lacks a few characteristics of favorite RPG's such as character customization/creation and so forth. I'm also hoping it's more open-world than the demo indicates.

Edit 6/11: Lot of bugs have been fixed, but still have problems with random crashes. I suspect they will be fixed too as the game is still updated frequently. Some of the stuff such as character customization has now been addressed and the game is pretty open world. My only complaint at this point is how slow fights go. For example if you are fighting two or three zombies on a map with 25+ zombies that you haven't engaged yet... you still have to wait until the game cycles through ALL of the zombies before taking your next turn. I have literally spent more than an hour in one fight, particularly when using weapons and creating noise, more zombies will spawn to cycle through.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

The game overall is playable. I like the overall concept of the game and its been holding my interest and I have been wanting more. Still a bunch of bugs and not all game features and areas are in or complete. I personally would not call this a Beta, still more alpha to me, but I have been enjoying myself. I would not recommend buying the game if you don't like to help find/fix bugs and have random crashes and currupted save games. Wait a few months or buy it when its released. If you want to support the game and help, make sure you read the known issues list so you understand what to look out for and what are the current limitations of the game.

This game has a tons of potential and I like that the developer is very responsive. I will be playing and watching this one closely.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

Very excited to finally get some hands-on time with Dead State even though it is only a small taste. It has everything I've been looking for in a zombie game. As expected in any work in progress build there are a few technical issues and features not yet implimented but the team has addressed them on the forums and I have no doubt everything will be taken care of in the final build.

Quick summary, It's fun and very challenging. It has replaybility because it's easy to bite off more than you chew at first, so alternate methods are easy to explore. Can't wait to see more! Keep it up Doublebear!

reviewText: Early Access Review\n\nThis game has a REALLY solid foundation to build upon. I Kickstarted this game a while back and have really been looking forward to it. Think Walking Dead (show) with turn based combat or State of Decay (another solid game) with turn based combat. While for the beta you can't create your character, you will in the full game along with the dog(e) companaion. You have to manage a base, resource, moral, and most of all your sanity dealing with other people. If you played the Facebook game, Last Stand: Dead Zone, this is similar to that game minus the Facebook give us real money for XYZ or bug your buddies". I'm on day 3 in the demo and I'm enjoying what I'm seeing so far. I'm aware it has some jank to it
date: not all features are activated but I'm liking what I'm seeing so far. The game has a ton of potential and a must for those of use that enjoy turned based combat and "base" building."

reviewText:
I really need to say a few things about Dead State

Dead State is an amazing concept for fans of not only survival games, zombies, but general story-telling and in-game representation of real people reacting to the chaos of a world falling apart.

The game starts out strong, with an interesting storyline, detailed interactions, and interesting exploration of the world around you - not only by physically going out there but hearing and reading about how things came to be this way and what's happening because of it.

I frankly adored the first few hours of playing - and then this games seams began to show

Characters that only showed up the day before rebelling, no dialogue options to solve certain problems, and an ending that truly made me wonder why I began playing in the first place.

What was the point of playing if - no real spoilers - the game simply fades out after a picture of essentailly JOB WELL DONE" flashes on the screen.

If you read this review before buying - don't buy this game."

reviewText:
Despite a few present bugs, and as much as people seem to be ♥♥♥♥♥ing about bugs, I've honestly enjoyed my time spent playing it. It really scratched the 'long term' zombie survival itch, something which is missing from most every zombie game presently.
There seem to be a few weird attempts to shoehorn in issues that are politically charged, like This gay Texas ranger shows up, the guy is really useful, really high stats, but he shrugs off his 'partner' dying in a car crash and just carries on without any problems, I know the guy was in the Army, but jeez. Knowing this 'controversial character' thing, the issue of him being gay will probably come up and you'll have to choose a side. and at one point a lady helicopter pilot wants an abortion and the preacher who was a missionary and worked in foriegn countries wants her to keep it, and you gotta choose a side, and theres more NPC conflict interactions like that, most of which aren't issues if you've got good negotiation and leadership skills.
Maybe its just me understanding that issues like these are inserted into games, not to make a meaningful message, or take a stance, but, added to try and generate 'buzz' or 'controversy' That sort of thing feels a little hamfisted, but npc dialogue isn't that important anyways, and whats present is pretty good, nothing absurd, but, I think the writing is a bit lacking in the overall amount of it, it would be nice to see more circumstantial responses and general dialogue.

Now, lets get to the meat of it, the game: Turn based like fallout 2 and a S.P.E.C.I.A.L"-lite stat system
date: with actions that use AP in combat with free movement when out of it. It works
hoursPlayed: I like it very much. There are the occasional out of combat pathfinding bug
voteText: but thats not a problem really. Its really enjoyable.\n\nWhat should be added: The ability to reload a single shot for less AP or something like that on certain weapons

etc.

I really do hope the developers keep adding content or open the game to being modifiable by the community and stick it on the steam workshop.

Its a good game

reviewText:
I just wanted to update this saying it's also really excellent if you've ever lived in texas. I lived in austin for about 9 years and it's cool to see the towns around texas represented.

Also, is there another way to x-fer items from npcs into storage, or does it always have to go through you... cause this is the biggest drawback in seamless gameplay for me...

The characters are fun, and I think I got different ones in 2 play throughs, There are still some bugs and some issues with inventory imo, but nothing that's going to ♥♥♥♥ you off too bad. reviewText:
Early Access Review

Dead in the water.
( An early access review of Dead State(2nd attempt))
by Merit Coba.

Imagine you are in a restaurant downtown and you are invited by the waiter to come over to the kitchen to help the cook select the ingredients for your dinner, tell him how much you want and describe how to cook it.  You then return to your table. When the waiter arrives with three plates, he puts one plate down and then tosses the contents of the plates on top of the others. What do you get?


On the 31st of October a release date was announced for Dead State: the 4th of December.
This means that the game must by now, writing early November, be in a state to be sold after some minor tweaking and polishing.
Is that the case?

Now on the upside this game has many things to commend it.
For one is that they made your character's improvement part of a goal system instead of  the usual experience system.
Next to that you can kind of improve you other party members by assigning them jobs and at times influence their progress through dialogs.
Also commendable is the way they give the game a kind of flow. At the start even a single zombie is a challenge for your group, let alone a group of them, but after a while zombies are no longer a danger but hostile people, those with guns and armor.
Another great idea is how the zombies can kill your party members and enemy humans and make them zombies to. One of the craziest encounters is  when your party runs into a shootout between two gangs while zombies attack from all sides.

At the core there are good ideas but this game is far from finished and beset with many issues. Here is a random list.

The game lacks a general story line, it is either not there or just not finished. There is a kind of conflict brewing between the militia at one hand and the military at the other, but  when I tried to talk to either side I was told to get lost.  There were some small incidents, like the military asking me for supplies and a proclamation from the militia, but  this didn't seem to open up more dialog.
Storylines are broken. An example is the one of Fiona Parks, a girl who is devoted to you. At some moment I was approached by Davis, one of the survivors, telling me how sorry he was about what Fiona did. I had no clue what he was talking about and Fiona was fine. This went of every morning until at one point it was announced that Fiona had killed someone. She duly got a trial(in which she supported the side that demanded her death), then a minute later she was reported to have killed again, was put on trial again and banned. Since then the Davis conversation happens every morning. (At least it makes sense now.)
Most zombies don't roam but just stand around so you can take them out one at a time, mostly by attacking them from behind.
Groups of zombies or people stop being a danger because you can kill them one at a time by bashing on a locked door that is out of their view, which will then draw in your enemies one at a time(and the door will be restored to full points when you reload a saved game, so you can repeat this until all the enemies have been taken care of). That way you can gang up on one of them and thus take down stronger enemies that would normally wipe your party out.
(One tip: give Vic a shotgun. And if you can get the combat shotgun he becomes an unstoppable force. In fact after a while you are pretty invulnerable.)
Unfinished maps, empty maps, maps that don't work, doors that don't work properly, invisible barriers, barriers that you can walk through(the Coleman side entry).
Dogs can only be attacked from the front and the back and sometimes not be shot at.
Fifth party members showing up unexpectedly.
The chicken and egg issue: to build your chickencoop you need to find a chicken, when you do it gets slaughtered when you take it home because you don't have a chickencoop.
Some quests are broken(Aggro asks you to get Alan, but he never shows).
There is a quest for swapping food for medicines, but you can't get food from your storage, although you can fish for fish. I did so and took the fish with me to this deal. Then the deal was made, but no exchange happened yet I got a message that the deal went really well.
The game doesn't keep a record of the locations that you already visited agains the locations that other survivors tell you about, so you get a message that they marked a  new location on your map, but nothing shows because you already discovered it.
When fully upgraded the fence can't be repaired(unless it is completely destroyed I guess).
Some upgrades on your shelter are described not to function.
Some items have no icons.
The storage of your shelter is bugged for sometimes the tabs won't work. This seems to effect mostly the ammunition tab and this might have something to do with creating ammo
The radio you can create to assign jobs doesn't work.
Ammo you can create yourself and it only costs you a one time price to give you access to an unlimited supply of them. So in the end you can just bang away as ammo isn't an issue(this might by intendend)

On and on goes the list of issues.

I was amazed about all these issues for people seem to think well of this game, so I checked the game agains steam several times and even have reinstalled it from scratch. I even tried to see I could download a recent upgrade from the double bear website, but they just point me to steam. Maybe steam is hosting a old game or  perhaps what I describe is the current state of the game.
I suspect the latter as I see in the forums many of the issues being mentioned.

Maybe the game is remarkably patched by the time it gets released but based on what I experienced above and based on the price I still give it a thumbs down.

No doubt someone is going to say that what I say is not true, so what I would suggest is that you just look around on the forums that talk about this game and, if it is available, download a demo.
I hope that the game developers finish the game properly.. it certainly has it's merits.
I have another review here which shows pictures so you have also visible proof of what I am saying.
http://meritcoba.com/2014/11/15/a-game-review-dead-statea-tale-of-errors-a-chicken-a-murderess-and-a-ghost-and-lots-of-zombies-too/

Log:
22 November: added a header.. corrected some writing mistakes. Removed some sentences.

reviewText:
This is NOT yet a complete product. It should still be in early access. I experienced a bug that causes a permanent negative status effect on my party members. It makes the game nearly un-playable. When I visited the game's web site seeking a fix I found that others were experiencing the same problem and there was no fix. I also found that their forums were full of celebatory posts about hotfixes for other game-breaking bugs that were fixed post-launch.

I chose not to buy this game in early access for a reason. If I'm going to buy a game I want a complete, playable product. I was excited to buy this game at full-release only to receive a product that was more glitchy and unplayable than most early access projects are.

Maybe one day this game will live up to its' potential, but as it is now DO NOT BUY. Save your money for complete games, or wait until there are enough patches for this to be playable. These developers need to learn to wait until their game is playble for full release rather than mostly playable"."

reviewText:
I read all the reviews and still bought the game even though they were overwhelmingly negetive. I did the same with Wasteland 2 and I enjoy and still play that. SO I figured I'd give it a shot. I wanted to give it a chance because in theory it is everything I want in a game.

Bad decision. I never write reviews but my exerience with this game has forced me to.

I don't nit-pick on things. I can get over the basic graphics. I can get over minor bugs.

I CANNOT GET OVER MY INVENTORY DISAPPEARING.

I spent a day playing through this mess. I got over everything because I knew that small amount of fufillment I would receive from heading out to the world and looting untl I had no more room, coming home and sorting through my spoils, would be worth it. Then I came back to the school and all my stuff is gone. I still have my weapons that were on my main character. But nothing else. Thats it. Forget the fact you can't drop items, or the graphics are weak and the battles are boring. If I am fine with cutting this game down to just basic exploration and looting and am fine with it. at least I would like to keep that loot.

Screw this game. Don't give it a shot. Don't wait for it to be fixed. Just don't. It's literally the worst experience I have ever had gaming. It burns so much more knowing I dropped 30 into this. Its criminal.

INVENTORY DISAPPEARS WHEN YOU COME BACK FROM EXPLORING. ****

reviewText:

Dead State is a dead state. A virus travelled around the globe and wiped out everyone. Well, nearly everyone. You are trapped in a school with struggling survivors. Theres one thing for sure. Texas, America will NEVER be the same again. Build appliances that raise morale and scavenge for supplies, weapons or medical meds in a world gone wrong. Ladies and gentlemen! This. Is. Dead State.

If you want a review of a game you want a review from, buy the game for me, and Ill write a review ASAP.
Your pal, Spud.

reviewText: I'm guessing the game got good reviews based on the genre and not the actual game.  As a fan that has been watching and looking forward to the development and release, only to be utterly disappointed.  The writing has the elequence and style of a 15 year old boy (although that is debatable as I think the average teenager might have been able to come up with better writing).  The game touts the decisions you make affecting he outcome of the game.  What that really means is that the dialogue comes to a grinding halt until you figure out what the character needs,  The controls are clunky, I would say the original X-COM has a better interface and flow.  I knew that the game would have graphics on par with what you'd find 15-20 years ago, but that being said I kept an open mind as there are great games that don't necessarily have modern graphics.  Sadly this is not one of them.  I'm a super fan of the zombie genre and would recommend either Left for Dead game or Dead Island would be money better spent,  What I expected was a game on par with say the new X-COM Enemy Unseen or at least close to that level of production and what I got was a 1996 classic, that would have been great 20 years ago, but has as much appeal to me as firing up the old adventure game on the atari 2600.
